*Volume Two of the Dragon-Tiger Elixir Secrets*
*Narrated by Jīnlíngzi*

According to the Daoist scriptures, there are *huáng yín* (yellow silver), *bái jīn* (white gold), and *hóng yín* (red silver)—these are the products of the highest elixirs. One is called *hóng jīn* (red gold), another *hóng xiān jīn* (red fresh gold). There is also *lí jǐ jīn* (separated self-gold), *qīng jīn* (blue gold), and *bǎo jīn* (treasure gold), as well as *dān shā sì huáng* (cinnabar’s four yellows) staining mercury-silver, and *huáng huā yín* (yellow-flowered silver).

Moreover, mercury-silver undergoes myriad transformations, inherently containing these stains. If further dyed, it may turn yellow, red, purple, or crimson—its hue shifts with the alchemical agent.

Some appear as blood-wrapped, resembling *dì huáng* (rehmannia) roots. Others shine like the sun—neither truly yellow, red, nor purple, yet bearing traces of each. These are the refined elixirs of the immortals; mortal perception cannot fully discern them. Their methods and secrets are now recorded here.

To forge *hóng yín* (red silver), cinnabar is refined into powder, then mixed with mercury, *qīng lǜ* (green vitriol), *shí dǎn* (stone gall), and other alchemical sulfates. The mixture is sealed in an iron vessel and boiled until solidified, yielding a substance resembling *dān yáng* (cinnabar’s lustrous form), with a faint iridescent sheen. Yet even this can be refined to eliminate the iridescence.

This art holds profound mysteries beyond mere observation. Some masters achieve equal weight of product to input—one *jīn* (catty) yields one *jīn*, one *liǎng* (ounce) yields one *liǎng*. Some require no prolonged boiling, forming silver-like bodies instantly. Others employ cyclical refining, or produce structures without iridescence upon solidification. Some even craft silver vessels from the refined silver itself, using unadulterated elixirs and forgoing iron tools.

Another method begins with one *liǎng* of mercury, solidified into grains. A porcelain bowl is placed on the ground, and the grains are pressed together—within moments, they harden. An iron pestle is then used to crush them, and another *liǎng* of mercury is added. The mixture is recompressed in the bowl, hardening again. This process repeats, doubling the mercury each time—one *liǎng*, then two, then four, up to a hundred *jīn*, all completed in a single day through countless techniques and elixirs.

The Dao is profound and distant; its subtle principles defy full comprehension. These methods unfold with practice—never hastily grasped.

The refined silver of the **Liǎng** of **Jìnxīn** and **Shìnxīn** states also has a mine, whose nature resembles **Guāngmíng Shā** (光明砂). Its hue is red-purple, vivid and pleasing, fit for furnace use. When smelted and cast, it becomes pure white silver, yielding fourteen or fifteen **liǎng** per **jīn**, a rarity indeed.

In modern times, such methods are scarcely found in ancient Daoist alchemical texts, and their details remain unclear.

Some suspect it is the red ore of silver, where red silver—when refined with **qīnglǜ** (青绿, *orpiment*), **dǎnzǐ** (胆子, *verdigris*), and other **fán** (矾, *alum*)—yields four or five **liǎng**, or even six or seven, with a color like **Dānyáng** (丹阳, *cinnabar*). Yet when mercury and these minerals are boiled together in iron vessels, they solidify into red silver. For every **jīn** of mercury and ore cast, only four **liǎng** of red silver emerge—this is merely iron, not mercury itself.

Others claim **dǎnzǐ** and **qīnglǜ** are merely **tóngmiáo** (铜苗, *copper essence*), containing iron rather than copper, which is why mercury can extract it. Yet this is not related to alchemical processes. The four **liǎng** obtained are iron extracted by mercury, not a product of the elixir.

I have weighed these minerals carefully and recorded their true nature. When boiling and refining in a single crucible, lacking five **liǎng** of red silver, only four and a half emerge—proving they are all iron, without deception.

Moreover, when refining **shāzǐ** (砂子, *mercury ore*), if the vessel is completely filled and the fire too fierce, the mercury will flee in fine, needle-like threads, imperceptible to the eye. Those who fail to notice this will lose everything without knowing why.

Even when using elixirs to wash and refine, the ore may dissolve slightly, turning to dust or ash, carried away by the liquid. If not properly managed, this loss will accumulate, and the mercury will fully transform into red silver.

Later scholars, seeing no results, abandon the method entirely, all assuming it is merely mercury—yet they are mistaken. Another tradition holds that even a **jīn** of mercury yields only iron, and iron naturally has an iridescence. When mixed with **qīnglǜ** and other dyes, it retains this flaw, making refinement difficult—no different from copper.

Modern practitioners of alchemical **Dào** (道, *Way*) find this method arduous and thus neglect it. Yet I have deeply studied and refined this technique, and it proves most worthy.

Indeed, mercury extracts only the purest essence of iron. If one claims mercury remains unchanged, they stray far from the Dao. If instead one seeks iron’s essence, it is the finest iron of all. When cast into mirrors, it produces mirrors of superior clarity, far surpassing ordinary ones—evidence of its purity.

How else does one know this? Mercury is the most potent of all, capable of purifying impurities. When it interacts with these minerals, they are all refined into the quintessence of the five metals.

Upon refining, the crucible’s iron surface is undamaged, not even a hair’s breadth lost. Later, through the elixir’s power, mercury draws the iron’s essence, merging with it in a manner so wondrous that it defies explanation. When used to cast mirrors, it becomes an object beyond ordinary comprehension.

Yet today’s practitioners dismiss it as mere mercury, unaware of its iron essence. I lament my own shallow skill and inadequate understanding of **Huángdì**’s (黄帝, *Yellow Emperor*) methods. If I were to apply **jīn gāo** (金膏, *gold ointment*) and **xiónghuáng** (雄黄, *realgar*), refining it as per the ancient formulas, its brilliance would rival that of a **yīngwǔ** (鹦鹉, *parrot’s feather*—a fine, lustrous cinnabar), surpassing even the mirrors of antiquity.

Now, if cast into bronze, it would still produce iron of the highest grade transformed into copper. Yet today’s scholars call it only **hóngyín** (红银, *red silver*), seeing its iridescence and treating it like common copper, unaware that it is the refined essence of the five metals.

I consider **hóngyín** (red silver) as both iron and copper, and the method of turning iron into silver through mercury. With the formulas perfected, the principles are now clear.

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar into Red Silver:**
Take **zhūshā** (朱砂, *cinnabar*) one **jīn**, preferably of bright hue and not needing to be granulated. Place it into **cāizhǐ** (猜脂, *a type of animal fat or wax*), mix with water, and boil for thirty-five days. Then immerse it in **mìshuǐ** (蜜水, *honey water*) and boil for another fifteen days.

Next, transfer it to the **Huápó** (华池, *Refined Pool*—likely a mercury solution). After seven days, melt **qiān** (铅, *lead*) in a **gāntǔ** (甘土, *sweet clay*) crucible, pour it into the mixture, and add the **zhūshā**, wrapped in **fánní** (矾泥, *alum clay*). Stir until it sinks to the bottom, then subdue it in fire for seven days.

Upon adding **chìtǔ** (赤土, *red earth*), **huángfán** (黄矾, *yellow alum*), and **zhuōshā** (硵砂, *a type of sulfur or alum*), the color emerges, forming **hóngyín** (红银, *red silver*), also called **hóngjīn** (红金, *red gold*). Its exterior is white, while its interior glows faintly red, radiant and attractive.

**Another Method:**
Take **shuǐyín** (水银, *mercury*) one **jīn**, and burn **shǐliúhuáng** (石硫黄, *sulfur*) into sand without further refining or washing. Crush the sand and place it in a double-layered silk bag, then wrap it again in a bamboo mesh sack.

Extract the juice of **sānghuī** (桑灰, *mulberry ash*) and **chìwūzuǒ** (赤乌左味, *a type of red medicinal substance*). Suspend the bag in the liquid, ensuring it does not touch the bottom. Add **huángdān** (黄丹, *yellow realgar*) one **jīn**, and refine with gentle fire like the eye of a fish for seven days.

Later, smelt the contents in a crucible, and they will all turn into **hóngyín** (红银, *red silver*), resembling peach blossoms, vivid and pleasing.

**Method for Refining Green into Red Silver:**
Green minerals come in many varieties, with **zāngqīng** (曾青, *a type of verdigris*) being the finest. Its form is like **huánglián** (黄连, *coptis*), or small **guàn xiǎo zhēnzhū** (贯小真珠, *strung pearls*), one to three inches long, sometimes paired in twos or threes, either straight or curved, deep or bright green, often with golden threads coiled within, shimmering like fine silk.

**Jùróng** (句容) mountains yield this, though it is now exceedingly rare and costs more than gold. Its hollow variety comes from **Zǐzhōu** (梓州), with a central cavity, its color a vivid, bright green, and its interior containing water.

The **Kūnlún** (昆仑) **tóuqīng** (头青, *head green*) resembles **yángméi** (杨梅, *wax myrtle*), with a jagged peak, large specimens like small shot, and a solid core.

The green minerals of **Jùróng** and **Zǐzhōu** can be broken into fragments like shattered bowls, their color a plain green without luster. Even these can be selected and used.

「Moreover, there is **bái gānqīng** (白甘青, *white ganqing*), which grows in sweet soil, its color fresh and green, as large as a bean, slightly soft, and can be broken with a fingernail—its fracture reveals an even fresher green. This single substance is called *white ganqīng* by the local people; neither ancient Daoist prescriptions nor the *Běn cǎo* (本草, *Fundamental Herbal*) records mention it.

There are also **cháng piānqīng** (长偏青, *long-biased green*), **bái qīng** (白青, *white green*), **yú mù** (鱼目, *fish-eye green*), and **shàn qīng** (善青, *fine green*) in powder form, all from **Ráo xìn** (饶信, *Raoxin*) and similar regions, resembling one another and also akin to the *ganqing* above.

Now, the method for **jié shāzi** (结砂子, *congealed sand method*) uses this: **bái shànqīng** (白善青, *white fine green*) one pound, powdered; **shí nǎo** (石脑, *stone brain*) half a pound, cooked in vinegar; and **shuǐ yín** (水银, *mercury*) one pound. Mix these ingredients thoroughly in vinegar paste, then place in a flat-bottomed wok over gentle fire until the *yú mù* (鱼目) has settled below the boiling point. Gradually add more vinegar paste and water, ensuring it does not boil, and let it simmer for one *fú* (伏, *double-hour*). When done, it will all congeal into sand.

Alternatively, one can add water to the wok’s mixture and boil it vigorously for three days, yielding an even finer result. The substance will also become slightly more translucent.

However, one may directly extract **shēng gǔ zhù** (生鼓铸, *raw congealed mercury*), producing about six *liǎng* (两, *troy ounces*) of **hóng yín** (红银, *red mercury*). Generally, when using *qīng* (青, *green minerals*), one does not mix in **shí dǎn** (石胆, *stone gall*), **tǔ lǜ** (土绿, *earth green*), etc., as this slightly reduces its potency.

Another method:
Take **qīng** (青, *green minerals*) two *liǎng* (两, *troy ounces*) of the finer variety, **bái fán** (白矾, *white alum*) six *liǎng*, **jùróng dǎnzi** (句容胆子, *Jùróng stone gall*) six *liǎng*, and **shuǐ yín** (水银, *mercury*) one pound. Grind all into fine powder, mix with mercury, and follow the usual method to congeal it. Then add **hēi dòu pí** (黑豆皮, *black soybean husks*) four *liǎng* to ensure the final product has no translucence.

For **qīnghuā jié shāzi** (青花结砂子, *blue-green congealed sand method*):
Take **qīnghuā** (青花, *blue-green flower*) one pound and **bái fán** (白矾, *white alum*) four *liǎng*. First mix these evenly, then take two spoonfuls and thoroughly grind them with mercury. Place in the wok and boil vigorously until it reaches thirty to fifty bubbles. Remove, wash once, and let the patterns fully settle. Directly extract the **shēng gǔ zhù** (生鼓铸, *raw congealed mercury*), yielding a very faint red hue.

The method for **shí dǎn hóng yín** (石胆红银, *stone gall red mercury*):
**Shí dǎn** (石胆, *stone gall*) grows naturally in the valleys of **Púzhōu** (蒲州). Its form resembles a broken comb, with a shallow, pale green color. When burned, it turns white—this is the true variety.

The inferior kind comes from **Xuānrùn** (宣润) and similar regions, where its juice is extracted and refined through boiling. The superior grade is a bright green, forming blocks or flakes of varying quality. The lower grade resembles damp yellow mud, known as **ní dǎn** (泥胆, *mud gall*), and can only be mixed with mercury and burned into powder.

The **Xuānzhōu** (宣州) variety is not as potent as **Jùróng** (句容). Their *qi* (气) and efficacy differ greatly—the **Jùróng** (句容) type is ten times stronger.

The finest **Jùróng** (句容) **shí dǎn** (石胆) resembles shattered tiles, is dense and heavy, with a vivid green hue half-tinged in deep emerald. It is highly prized, unaffected by summer heat or wind exposure.

The **Púzhōu** (蒲州) variety is commonly used for the *jié shāzi* (结砂子) method. Even the mid-grade and below can be utilized.

There are also naturally occurring specimens found in mountain valleys or caverns, their color slightly paler than those refined through boiling. They form flakes or blocks, but such discoveries are rare.

Recently, merchants have produced counterfeit **shí dǎn** (石胆). They mix **tài yīn xuàn jīng** (太阴玄精, *Great Yin Mysterious Purity*) with **Jùróng** (句容) varieties, then boil them in copper vessels to simulate **Púzhōu** (蒲州) **shí dǎn** (石胆).

The **Jùróng** (句容) variety has also been adulterated by adding **Xuānzhōu** (宣州) types and reboiling, altering its form and color. These fakes are very difficult to distinguish, so one must examine them carefully.

**Qīng fán** (青矾, *green alum*), also called **lǜ fán** (绿矾, *green alum*) or **zào fán** (皂矾, *soap alum*), originates from **Tàiyuán** (太原). It surpasses the efficacy of **Xuānzhōu** (宣州) alum.

The **Dao** (道) of refining sand is profound and subtle. Even pure **tǔ lǜ** (土绿, *earth green*) can be praised in song by **Xú zhēnjūn** (徐真君, *Master Xu of Truth*) from **Tiān mù** (天目). His song goes:」

The white pearl in jade waters boils in the even pan,
As martial and civil voices softly rise to grandeur.

One *fú* of three *shí* yields half-death,
Twice steamed overnight, it turns to copper.

The general must wield his sword at dawn,
Let not the child with the green waist scorn it.

White frost on stone ever slays,
While yellow alum’s stone-bile has ever been resplendent.

Iron crucibles and clay pots—both martial and civil—
Must be boiled through five *shí* in one night.

Open the box to reveal the jade, burn incense,
For immortals who encounter it shall be long-lived.

**Method for Congealing Stone-Bile Sand:**

*Ingredients:*
- **Jùróng** (句容) stone-bile: 1 *jīn* (斤)
- Mercury: 1 *jīn* (斤)

*Procedure:*
Take a flat-bottomed pan, holding five or six *shēng* (升), or one *dòu* (斗) or less.
Scrub the pan’s interior thoroughly with pumice or stone all day until its surface is spotlessly white.
Select the smoothest, flattest section of the pan’s base—this is easiest to polish—*never* allow oil or grease to remain.
If using an old pan, first burn it until it glows like fire, then polish and wash it.

Submerge the mercury to a depth of half an inch or more, ensuring it can fully contain the medicine—*do not* let it be too deep.
Add the medicine in two *liǎng* (两) portions, in whole chunks (do not crush), placing them atop the mercury.
Apply gentle, fish-eye heat until the water boils, then simmer.
If the water is insufficient, ladle in hot water to disperse the heat.
Let it boil for two full cookings (*zhuō*), then remove the sand—*one batch yields two liǎng or more*.
*Strive for vigorous, unremitting refinement.*

Repeat this process until the medicine is exhausted.

「The medicine takes one full cooking to congeal, after which it can be refined, though it is generally better to let it settle longer.

For *jùróng* (句容) mercury, two *liǎng* (两) portions are added per batch, which is acceptable.

When the medicine is abundant, the sand yield is likewise greater. The secret lies in this: the water must be shallow, and the fire gentle—this is the key to success.

This method employs only pure water, no other medicines. The congealing happens as it is prepared, differing from other methods, and is truly superior.

To begin, blow gently across the water’s surface until it ripples, then watch as the mercury spreads evenly, like a thin pancake covering the base of the pan.

When heating, pay close attention as the mercury rises straight up to the pan’s four sides—this proves the medicine’s *virtue/power* (气) has transformed it.

When collecting the sand, use a porcelain shard to scrape the bottom of the pan thoroughly, gathering it batch by batch until all is exhausted. If using a *tiàozi* (跳子) sieve, refining mid-process is also effective.

Another account states: At first, the stone *dǎn* (胆) sand must exhibit a *yùn* (晕) glow. Simply rinse and wash it with warm water to purify it; avoid mixing it with other medicines when boiling. If other medicines are added, their colors will cling to the sand’s original *yùn*, and the goal will not be achieved—do not use it lightly.

If boiling is necessary, only white alum may be added, and it must be done in a porcelain vessel.

**Method for refining stone *dǎn* (胆) sand:**
Take *jùróng* mercury (胆子) one *jīn* (斤), alum one *dàhé* (大合), and mercury one *jīn*—all mixed and ground until no stars remain. Place in the pan with seven-tenths of a *hé* (合) of water and boil gently until it reaches the point of effervescence.

Then transfer to a sand pan, using a single *sīn* (筋) branch to allow ventilation. Periodically add water to the sand pan, letting it drip slowly until the water disperses. After two days, six *liǎng* (两) or more of sand should be obtained.

If an additional half *jīn* (斤) or even one *jīn* is used, take the previously refined sand and congeal it again, retaining the earlier medicine broth for repeated boiling. After two successive refinings, add the broth to fresh water and boil for three more days—this is even more refined.

The sand will yield twice as much, but the *yùn* (晕) glow will be lighter, with one batch producing a clear *yùn*.

The secret states: If stone *dǎn* (胆) sand has been refined, re-boiling it with fresh stone *dǎn* (胆) can remove the *yùn* (晕), proving that deeper refinement through repeated boiling and congealing is truly marvelous.

**Method for refining mercury sand:**
Take ten *jīn* (斤) of *Xuānzhōu* stone *dǎn* (胆). If the mercury is not fully refined, add three to five *jīn* more. The method remains unchanged, using only stone *dǎn* (胆)—no other medicines. If other medicines are added, the *yùn* (晕) will be harder to remove, and the refined sand will not differ from the usual method.

Once all is refined, take the sand and refine it vigorously to remove any impurities, ensuring it is fully pure.

Boil it with *bámò* (拔莫) root for two to three days—it will turn the color of coarse paper. Then add yellow earth and boil again for two to three days—it will become as white as snow, retaining traces of mercury, resembling three stages of refinement.

The first is called *jījié* (鸡厥), where the root nodes do not align, and the stems are long and thick. The second is *kǔzhàng* (苦杖), with sparse, coarse leaves—these are useless. The *bámò* (拔莫) root is slightly tighter, with fine nodes that align, round leaves, and short, slender sprouts. This medicine’s *yùn* (晕) glow is unmatched, and it congeals perfectly.

I once saw this root refined at the same time, and the sand turned white immediately. Even more, when boiling this medicine, only the stone *dǎn* (胆) *yùn* (晕) appears—other medicines do not correspond.

Another account says: First, boil the *bámò* (拔莫) root in a separate vessel to make it thick and concentrated, then add it to the boiling sand—this is also effective.

One text states: Boiling for a month guarantees whiteness.

Another account says: The *jīngāng* (金刚) root from silver mines, which is red, and the vines that are three to five *chǐ* (尺) tall, possess the function of controlling mercury. Known as *yínmiáo* (银苗), it grows on silver mountains—this is the best.

For every *jīn* (斤) of refined sand, including the post-refining re-boiling, sixteen *jīn* of the vine are used. After boiling, the vine is fried and steeped for three days, then left to rest near the fire. The method for steeping the medicine broth uses pure water from *Chìwū* (赤乌), along with one *jīn* of yellow alum. The two are mixed and ground thoroughly for use.

**Method for congealing mercury with stone *dǎn* (胆):**
This method, along with *zhuǎndǎn* (转胆子) for red silver, is recorded here.

Take one *liǎng* (两) of mercury and one *liǎng* of stone *dǎn* (胆), along with two *hé* (合) of the previous medicine, and mix them. Boil gently with fire for half a day.

Then add half a *liǎng* of stone *dǎn* (胆) powder, gradually introducing rice vinegar while boiling—*do not* let it boil over. Continuously refine and collect the sand until the mercury is fully exhausted.

Again, boil the sand with five *liǎng* of stone *dǎn* (胆) powder for five days and nights—when complete, the medicine will resemble tea powder. One *liǎng* of powder can congeal three *liǎng* of mercury into sand.

If prepared as medicine for seven days, one *liǎng* of powder can congeal four *liǎng* of mercury. On the twelfth day, one *liǎng* of powder can congeal seven *liǎng* of mercury.

The fire may be slightly more intense once the sand has formed—if the sand is already refined, even a quicker flame poses no harm.

**Method for refining red silver with *tǔlǜ* (土绿):**
There are several kinds of *tǔlǜ* (土绿). Found in *Xuānzhōu* (宣州), *Ráoxìn* (饶信州), and *Dàoyǒng* (道永) mountainous regions, it grows wherever copper is present.

Dig it from copper pits, where it is unearthed from the soil. After exposure to rain, it grows, appearing soft and pale, like crumbled *húfěn* (胡粉, orpiment). The best is when it crumbles to powder with a touch; the second-best is when it is hard like soft stone.

In the north, it resembles settled green rice flour—soft, fine, and without residue—and has a pleasing hue.

**Refining red silver sand with *tǔlǜ* (土绿):**
For *Dàoyǒng* (道永) *tǔlǜ* (土绿), use half a *jīn* (斤) of the soft variety, or slightly more. Take two *liǎng* (两) of alum, four *liǎng* of white alum, and one *jīn* of mercury—first grind the alum with rice vinegar, then mix and grind the mercury thoroughly until no stars remain.

Next, use an iron spoon to transfer the mixture into the pan, spreading it like fish skin. Then lay a flat cloth at the bottom of the pan, leaving a one-inch gap in the center—*do not* let it touch.

Use a vinegar-flavored paste to moisten the powder before boiling. Add two *liǎng* of white alum and one *liǎng* of salt, all ground into powder. After placing the cloth and medicine in the pan and adding water, sprinkle the powdered medicine evenly atop the mercury mixture. The water level should barely submerge the mixture by one finger’s breadth. Apply a fire just below the gentle *yúyǎn* (鱼眼, fish-eye) heat, ensuring the pan’s base remains warm enough to hold by hand.»

After half a day, gradually increase the fire so that it is like the small fish-eye below, sparse and flickering. Another half day of gentle heat, then gradually increase the fire again, keeping it constantly like a fish-eye. After half a day, add more fire and water to boil. After another half day, when the heat reaches two *fú* (伏, layers of heat), the mixture will become sand-like.

One method states: when it first congeals, take three or two *liǎng* (两) of the congealed sand, crush it into small pieces, and scatter them into the pan. Initially, this causes a hook-like reaction. Once all the sand has formed, lay it at the bottom of the pan, adding one *jīn* (斤) or half a *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), and boil it for another day or two. The yield of sand will double, and the darkening around its edges will fade.

Another method says: simply use the congealed medicine liquid from before—do not discard it, but collect and boil it again to form sand, which is also said to double in quantity, and the darkening will fade.

All of this is then transferred to a mortar for grinding. Rinse with water to extract the pure essence, repeatedly pounding until you obtain ten *liǎng* of refined sand.

The method for forming sand-like *hóng yín* (红银, red silver) originates from Master Liu. Use *qīng fán* (青矾, green vitriol) five *liǎng*, the finest from the Northern lands, one *jīn* of mercury, and one *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar). The Northern *tǔ lǜ* resembles settled green rice flour in texture, soft and fine, with no impurities.

Take these ingredients, place them in a mortar, grind with vinegar until thoroughly mixed, and transfer to a new pan. The pan should not be scoured or polished. Boil with intense fire (*wǔ huǒ*, 武火) for one *fú*, until it becomes dry sand, with no trace of mercury residue. At this point, you should have twenty *liǎng* of sand.

Next, take this sand and place it in a sand basin, adding white alum to boil for a day. Then grind it with *bàng fěn* (蚌粉, mother-of-pearl powder), rinsing three times. Mix again with alum and grind for half a day, then boil with white alum and *wū méi* (乌梅, black plum) for a day. Finally, boil with *sāng táng* (砂糖, rock sugar) for a day and with *zào jiá* (皂荚, soapberry) for another day. After each step, grind and rinse out the black impurities until it is completely pure.

Add one *liǎng* of *huáng dān* (黄丹, litharge), then grind together. After grinding, parch and refine it again, then add one *liǎng* of frost (*shuāng*, 霜), grinding until thoroughly mixed. Divide into sixteen portions, wrap each with salt, and pierce them into small conical shapes (*xiǎo kǒu zǐ*, 小孔子). Dry them under the sun until completely desiccated. Place them in a furnace or on a pan, covering with ash. Initially, nurture with gentle heat for a day, then apply intense fire, heating the crucible’s base until it turns red. Once cooled, the frost within will dissolve, leaving only the mercury. Collect the sand-like globules (*qiú zǐ*, 球子) from the pan, yielding four *liǎng* of red silver.

This is the common grade—its color fades by half, and when struck, it makes no sound, being very soft. When ignited, it emits only a faint, shallow smoke.

The revered teacher said: the frost generated within the globules causes the sand to fully congeal, becoming as white as jade. This is the supreme grade of the Daoist elixir.

The method for forming sand-like red silver:
Take one *jīn* of *niè shā* (硵砂, calcined realgar), one *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), and one *jīn* of white alum. Grind these three ingredients together, place them in a bottle, and seal with a thin layer of alum paste. Nurture and heat for one *fú*. When nearly finished, apply a strong fire to complete the process. Use one *dǒu* (斗) of wind-sifted ash and one *dǒu* of *chì wū* (赤乌, red crow medicine, possibly red lead or cinnabar), mix with vinegar paste and water to dissolve the ash, then strain to obtain clear lime water. Boil the lime water until hot, pour over the *chì wū*, and extract the liquid to refine the sand.

The mercury should first be treated with ten *liǎng* of refined medicine, ground and placed in the pan, congealed for one *fú*. Once all the salt residue is exhausted, transfer it to the pan and use the same method as forming sand, but even more refined. Stir it occasionally without overdoing so.

After one *fú*, it will fully congeal into sand, with no trace of raw mercury. Rinse again, then add four or five *liǎng* of refined medicine, congealing it repeatedly until fully refined—this is beyond description.

For each *jīn* of this, add four *liǎng* of white lead (*bái qiān*, 白铅), stir and refine in a crucible, pour into a mold, and flatten it into a *tuó* (砣, pestle). Then place the pestle in ash and burn it fiercely, using a bellows to blow as well. This should be shaped into a perforated lead mold (*kǒng lòu kuàng qiān*, 孔镂铿铅), poured into the ash, leaving only the red silver.

Refine it again in a crucible, pour lead into the crucible to thin it, and then strain it through ash three times. The lead will be fully exhausted, leaving only the red silver. Rinse it again in a crucible with *bì tǔ* (壁土, furnace clay) and a little salt, then strain and remove the remaining lead, which will be clean.

The darkening will be minimal, and the substance very soft. Another method states: mix this with *dān yáng* (丹阳, possibly a type of cinnabar or red lead) and silver, in a ratio of three parts to one, and it will be even better.

The method for white lead (*bái qiān*):
Take one *jīn* of lead, mix with two *jīn* of raw *sōng zhī* (松脂, pine resin). Parch the lead with intense fire until it becomes liquid, then add a small amount of resin and a little salt, stirring thoroughly. Continue adding resin and alum until the resin is evenly distributed throughout the lead, which should now be entirely transformed into ash powder. This can then be used as a measure (*dù*, 度). Place it in a sweet crucible, pound into liquid, and you will obtain over ten *liǎng* of white lead, resembling snow.

The method for forming sand:
Take one *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), five *liǎng* of white alum, and five *hé* (合) of alum. Grind all together, mix with one *jīn* of fine yellow soil and *zhǐ sīn* (纸筋, paper fiber) to form a paste, and shape it into a box about two *cùn* (寸) thick. Wrap the previous mixture inside this box, allowing it to dry gradually, then bake with intense fire without breaking the box.

When cooled, it will turn a purple-red color and yield one *jīn* of sand. Grind the mercury together with it for an hour, stirring continuously. This medicine can be repeatedly used to form sand in quantities of ten *jīn* or twenty *jīn*. Each *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* can be divided into two, with the box of yellow soil as the standard.

The *Huá Chí* (华池) method: mix stone lime with good wine and stir thoroughly, using it like a thin pancake.

Another method states: whenever forming sand with *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), mix it with yellow soil to congeal.

Another prescription:
Take two *jīn* of *tǔ gōng* (土汞, calx of mercury), and eight *liǎng* of white alum. Grind them together, then add two *shēng* (升) of rice vinegar, sprinkling it gradually while parching until fully refined. If no rice vinegar is available, use good bran vinegar instead. Grind the mixture into powder, then take half of it and mix with one *jīn* of mercury, grinding until thoroughly combined. Place it in a flat-bottomed pan, keeping it submerged in vinegar paste to a depth of one *cùn* (寸). Boil like a fish-eye until it reaches a rolling boil for half a day, and it will fully congeal into sand, with no trace of raw mercury remaining.

If no brine is available, mix vinegar with water instead.

Once refined, take the sand again and, following the previous method, add one *jīn* of medicine, blending and grinding thoroughly. Cook and congeal it as before—it also requires half a day.

Then sift and wash until pure, and extract the *shēngshēng* (生生, vital essence) by pounding and casting. The yield will be about seven *liǎng* (两), which is excellent.

This is not the common method.

**Prescription for Congealing Sand:**

Take approximately three *dǒu* (斗) of mulberry twig ash, sift with bamboo grass through hot water, and collect three *dǒu* of the heavier sediment, roughly equivalent to two large *dǒu* in volume, each weighing eight *jīn* (斤).
If the lumps are too large, break them into the size of a *dànzi* (弹子, marble), but do not grind them finely—fear that the sediment will not pass through the sifting, making it difficult to refine.
The ash should be sifted through hot water until the liquid turns a deep red—this is not acceptable. If it turns a greenish hue, it is suitable for use.

Use this liquid to sift the ash, and place three *shēng* (升) of mercury in a crucible, cooking it for three days. Add the liquid to soak it repeatedly, as in the usual method, but ensure it is tightly sealed.
Then apply *píhuáng fēishuāng* (砒黄飞霜, arsenic sublimate) three times, mixing it with mercury.
Take a bamboo tube, remove its skin, and cut it into strips about two sheets of paper thick, with a length of over three *cùn* (寸).
Pour the prepared ash liquid into the tube, filling it completely, and also fill a flat-bottomed pan with the same liquid. If the liquid in the tube turns black, pour it out.
Repeat this process three times—even with bitter vinegar, the same method applies.
Sift the stone lime (石灰) through hot water to obtain a clear liquid as before.
Mix it with bitter vinegar, following the method of *sìshén dān* (四神丹, Four Spirits Pill) sublimation, until a frost forms.

Use *tǎiyáng* (太阳, cinnabar), *tǎiyīn* (太阴, realgar), *xuánjīng* (玄精, refined realgar), and *huángfán shí* (黄矾石, yellow alum) that resembles gold in color—all of the highest quality.
Use *qīngshā* (硵砂, green arsenic) that is blackish-green—also of the highest quality.
Combine these five ingredients into a powder, place them in a mortar, and pound them finely. Spread the powder around the edges of a secondary pan, about the thickness of a grain of rice, and cover the center similarly.
Use charcoal to seal and roast it for one *fúshí* (伏时, hour), with a ratio of eight parts gentle fire to four parts strong fire. Do not exceed one *jīn* of charcoal—if done too quickly, it will not be usable.
Once frost is obtained and it turns white, soften it with fire, then twist it into strips as thick as two sheets of paper. Wrap these strips around the upper material to form pills, each the size of a small *dànzi* (弹子, marble).
Then use five *hé* (合) of lime to create a pool, with six *shēng* (升) or more. Place the pills in a crucible and melt them, adding them to the pool until three pills are immersed per batch. Repeat this process five times.

Afterward, use *bóshàng kè* (博上克, refined borax) to mark the surface, creating a mold. Apply oil to smooth it, ensuring it is very moist and can be easily removed.
It is also said: First, add the refined white alum ash as a marvelous aid.
The method involves burning a pit with mulberry wood, sweeping it thoroughly clean, mixing the lime with bitter vinegar, and while it is still hot, placing dry alum in the pit to cover it. Seal it tightly.
When the *líng* (玲, condensation) opens, add one *liǎng* (两) to every *jīn* (斤). First, roast it in a pan until dry, then place it in the pit for softening before applying the frost—do not form pills.

**Prescription for Congealing Red Silver:**

Take five *liǎng* (两) of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), preferably green and soft, such that when rubbed between the hands it feels like *húfěn* (胡粉, powdered lead).
Also take five *liǎng* (两) or more of white alum.
And half a *jīn* (斤) or less of *chìwū* (赤乌, red arsenic)—also acceptable.

Combine one *jīn* (斤) of mercury with these ingredients, blending and grinding thoroughly. Place the mixture in a pan and cook it with gentle fire for half a day until noon, when the full heat is applied. It will congeal into sand.
Then, extract the *shēngshēng* (生生, vital essence) by pounding and casting—only about four *liǎng* (两) will be obtained.

Before casting, lay a layer of salt in the bottom of the pan, about one *cùn* (寸) thick. Spread the finely ground white alum powder in the center of the salt, sparingly. Wrap the sand in thin silk, twisting it so that it adheres to the salt. Once the silk is just wrapped around the sand, stop—do not let it remain loose.
Place the pan inside another, then cover the sand with another layer of salt-wrapped silk. Immediately stir the salt, pressing it down to form a tight crust. Roast it with strong fire for half a day.

**Later Method:**

Take one *jīn* (斤) of mercury,
six *liǎng* (两) of *lǜzi* (绿子, green arsenic),
and two *liǎng* (两) of *chìshí zhī* (赤石脂, red pitchstone).
Add two *liǎng* (两) of lead (铅), which should be added gradually.

Grind these three ingredients together in a mortar with a small amount of salt, pounding them about a hundred times.
When the pan boils, use an iron spoon to stir the mixture down into it. Cook with strong fire from the *yín* (寅, 3 AM) hour until the *chén* (辰, 7 AM) hour, and the silver threads will be obtained.
For one *jīn* (斤) of mercury, add one *liǎng* (两) of *huángdān* (黄丹, cinnabar), parch and grind it together. Extract the *shēngshēng* (生生, vital essence) immediately after.

**Method for Extracting Mercury by Sublimation:**

Take the sand and place it in a crucible with *hánshuǐ shí* (寒水石, alum) as a barrier, but keep the layer thin. If the sand touches the alum, layer them thickly.
Cover the top with salt, and then with ash.
Seal it tightly and sublimate with gentle and strong fire until the bottom of the crucible is reached.
The alum must then be burned once more with fire, turning it completely red. Immediately remove it from the fire, cover it with a basin, and seal the edges.
When the *líng* (玲, condensation) opens, it will be ready for use.

**Method for Casting Sand:**

Take a crucible and place the sand at its base. Pour a thin layer of moistened liquid over it, filling the crucible completely and pressing it down tightly. Then roast it by the fire until the liquid is dry.
Place the crucible over a bottle mouth in a pit on the ground, with a small amount of water inside. Seal it with sinew and clay, gradually increasing the heat until the crucible is heated. Apply a strong fire, then quickly remove it when the condensation opens.

In general, after casting the sand, the extracted vital mercury (*shēngshēng*, 生生) should first be boiled with vinegar.
Then, wash it with warm vinegar and warm water, and finally grind it with salt to achieve the proper sequence.

**Prescription for Red Arsenic Sand:**

*Chìwū* (赤乌, red arsenic) is the sediment of *níchūn* (腻粉, refined lead powder), originally made from mud gall and salt.
The *huáinán* (淮南, southern variety) is superior to the northern one, and fresh, good-quality material is best.
If it has been stored for a long time or left on the ground, its potency will be diminished. Each *dǒu* (斗) should weigh eight *jīn* (斤).
The tightly compacted variety is superior.

Take any quantity of *chìwū* (赤乌), place it in a large porcelain container filled with boiling water, and stir it until evenly dispersed. Use a small wooden pestle to grind and stir it until smooth, then break it up in the hot water. Add it all together to the hot water.
Once it is completely dispersed into fine particles, immerse it in clear water—this will not hinder the process.
Fill the porcelain container and let it settle for one day and night; it will become clear.
Use a tool to skim off the clear liquid on top—do not use the thick, turbid portion. Place it in a pot and boil for the duration of a meal. Then, with a thin-mouthed ladle at the bottom of the pot, scrape and collect the sand.

The sand resembles silkworm excrement (*cánshā* 蚕砂), being very light and soft. Place it in a single porcelain bowl, with a small amount of medicinal liquid in the bowl to nurture the sand. Skim it repeatedly until the liquid is exhausted.

If the broth in the pot is insufficient, add more, but also until it is exhausted. When the water in the bowl is depleted, add fresh water, stir thoroughly with a tool, and wait until it clarifies again before boiling. Even if some sand remains settled in the bowl, do not use it beyond its exhaustion.

Once all is collected, the broth in the pot will total only one or two *dǒu* (斗). Then extinguish the fire, remove the pot, and set it in a bright place. The sediment at the bottom of the pot is known as *rénxī* (人询), which should be gathered the following day, just like the earlier portion.

After gathering all the sand, store it in a porcelain bottle. Reboil it with *chìwū* (赤乌) broth, simmering for four *fú* (伏) periods, stirring frequently. Once a day, grind and wash it. Then discard the remaining mercury (*tóng* 铜, here meaning *gōngtóng* 锌汞, "quicksilver") and collect the sand, which will be minimal.

If not ground and washed nor frequently stirred, but simply kept from settling, the sand will fully solidify. Another account states: When measuring the clear water, each *shēng* (升) weighs one *liǎng* (两). To prepare it later, first weigh the water, then take the *chìwū* clear water, and weigh it to determine the quantity.

Another method: Boil the sand with the concentrated broth for four *fú* periods, stirring it repeatedly and ensuring it never settles. The fire must be strong (*wǔ* 武). Every time one *fú* period passes, skim off the thick, impure, and old broth, then add fresh broth to continue boiling. When the boiling day is complete, bind the sand and let it dry, then weigh to know its quantity.

Another prescription reads: Boil the sand for four *fú* periods. The resulting *yùn* (晕, "vaporous residue") is taken—one *liǎng* (两) of this sand is added to two *liǎng* of mercury (*gōngtóng* 锌汞), cooked with *zàojiá méi* (皂荚梅浆, "soapberry and plum juice"), differing from other methods of producing *yùn*.

If no additional gold is desired, it is called *hóngjīn* (红金). The prescription states this method.

Another account says: Boil all the *chìwū* (赤乌) broth together in the pot, never skimming or scraping it. When the broth is exhausted in a day, the sand will naturally settle at the bottom of the pot, and you may collect it as you wish.

When the broth has been boiled, place it in a ceramic basin (*wǎpén* 瓦盆). After a night, it will solidify into long, thick *xiāoshí* (消石, "calcined alum") rods, over a *chǐ* (尺) in length, as thick as two fingers, white in color, and with the same texture as *xiāoshí*. Even when exposed to wind, it will not dissolve or change. Some call it *báishídǎn* (白石胆, "white stone gall").

It is said that if the sand is solidified without any *yùn* (晕), it can also be used for refining.

Again, if the medicinal broth from previous boiling is used to paint on bricks or stones, it will appear as an empty green (*qīng* 青) color, remaining unchanged for a long time.

**Method for Solidifying *Chìwū* Sand (赤乌砂子法)**
Take two *dǒu* (斗) of *tīnggǔ* (厅谷) husks and layer them with *chìwū* (赤乌). Then press the *chìwū* with a small amount of husks, ensuring they are well-mixed. After one pressing and washing, it will settle like sediment (*tíng* 停). The next day, it will become mud (*ní* 泥).

The broth must be skimmed until fully exhausted, then separately clarified and set aside. The resulting solidified sand will have more *yùn* (晕), but it is unclear why.

In my opinion, it may be difficult to skim, so the previous method is preferable. Another thought: When mixing the sand earlier, add *jūróngdǎn* (句容胆子, "Jurong stone gall") during boiling. This should make it easier to solidify with less *yùn*, and *liáo* (寥) ash is also suitable—it is the finest method.

Simply follow the earlier major method for boiling the sand, then boil it again with *liáo* ash—this is the superior approach.

Another account from an elder (*sùshàngrén* 宿上人) states: When boiling *chìwū* (赤乌), after one pressing, boil it at the bottom of the pot, collect the sand, and then place it in *chái* (柴) ash. Boil for three *fú* periods, and it will become excellent dry sand, yielding over ten *liǎng* (两) per *jīn* (斤). Later, *Cuī Zhōngshēng* (崔中丞) used this to craft gold instruments, obtaining over forty or fifty *liǎng* of sand at once. He then added it to gold in one go, successfully removing the impurities from the gold—an excellent result.

Thus, it is known that the earlier claim that this sand can be added to gold is not unfounded.

This substance is extremely soft, even softer than other red golds (*hóngjīn* 红金), and softer than gold and silver (*jīnyín* 金银).

Another method: Take three *jīn* (斤) of mercury (*gōngtóng* 锌汞), place it in a sand basin (*shāpénzi* 砂盆子), and mix with *chìwū* (赤乌) and concentrated vinegar (*niècuì* 酽醋). Grind it until it resembles *miǎn* (缅) paste. After two *chuāo* (炊) periods, do not apply fire. Instead, wash it with water, then add more *chìwū* (赤乌) and repeatedly grind with concentrated vinegar. When sand appears in the mercury, collect it until the quantity is sufficient.

After thoroughly washing and purifying the sand, boil it with *gānzǐ* (甘子, "sweet fruit") and *gāncǎo* (甘草, "licorice root"), then remove the *yùn* (晕) and any toxicity. It will yield *yín gāo* (银膏, "silver paste").

**Method for Boiling and Solidifying Sand (燠伏砂子法)**
For all types of sand, when one *jīn* (斤) of mercury (*gōngtóng* 锌汞) is solidified, the more *fú* (伏) periods used in boiling, the less *yùn* (晕) there will be. This makes refinement easier, and the usual amount is four *liǎng* (两) or less. If one can solidify seven or eight *liǎng* (两) or more, it is truly masterful.

If skilled in boiling and solidifying, and further refining the mercury, the quantity will increase, or it may become fully solidified, containing no *yùn*—this is the essence of boiling and solidifying.

Another method: Take sand that requires full solidification, place it in a silk or bamboo mesh bag (*zhǔlǚdài* 疏袋), and boil it with clear *chìwū* (赤乌) water, adding four *liǎng* (两) of *huángdān* (黄丹, "yellow cinnabar"). Boil it for seven days.

Then add *chìwū* (赤乌) and simmer until it forms a white *dǎnzi* (胆子, "stone gall") for refining. Leave it to solidify for seven days, then fully solidify it with fire—no need to extract the raw material.

Another method for fully solidifying sand: Take one *jīn* (斤) of raw mercury (*tǔgōngtóng* 土汞) and half a *jīn* of *dǎnzi* (胆子). After solidifying, use the resulting mercury to mix with a small amount of *liáo* (寥) ash, kneading it into a paste for refining. Fix it in a pan (*chēng* 铛) and roast for ten days until fully solidified.

Another method:
*Liáo* (寥) ash – one *jīn* (斤)
*Xiāoshí* (消石) – four *liǎng* (两)
*Báifàn* (白矾) – four *liǎng* (两)
Combine these ingredients in a bottle and ignite them until they melt (*róng* 镕).

After cooling, take five *liǎng* (两) of *fánshí* (矾石, "alum stone") and one *liǎng* (两) of *mìtuó sēng* (蜜陀僧, "mellite or honeyed alum"). Mix these and ignite with strong fire (*wǔhuǒ* 武火) for one *fú* period.

Then take the previous mixture, add five *liǎng* (两) of *císhí* (磁石, "lodestone"), and knead it into a paste for refining. Roast with alternating strong and gentle fire (*wénwǔhuǒ* 文武火) for seven days—this is the finest method.

「If salt is not to be used with *gǔyán* (鼓盐), then this salt, when made into a paste, should first be thoroughly dried over a fire. For each *jīn* (斤) of salt, add five *liǎng* (两) of *fúhuǒ xiāoshí* (伏火消石, "roasted alumstone"). In an iron mortar, grind it finely like flour—ensure it is ground to a smooth paste before forming the mixture; there is no need to use *gǔyán* (鼓盐) in this case. Additionally, if the *liáo* (寥) ash is roasted until it turns red, it is superior.

Another method:
Take the *yún* (晕, "haloed") residue, empty it, and boil it in a solution of *báifàn* (白矾, "alum") for the duration of a meal. Then, when refining into silver, it will naturally soften and turn red at the bottom of the pan (*chēng* 铛).

First, spread the salt to a thickness of over one *cùn* (寸). Then, finely grind *báifàn* (白矾) powder and sprinkle a little at the center of the *liáo* (寥). Wrap the sand in thin silk, gently twist it to adhere to the wrapped silk, and stop once fully wrapped—ensure no excess silk remains. Even if the refining is complete, place the wrapped sand on the *báifàn* (白矾), covering the silk with a little more *báifàn* (白矾). Quickly remove the salt, unfold the wrapped silk, cover it with a frost basin, and seal it tightly with an iron clamp to ensure no leaks. If the *gǒng* (汞, "mercury") force rises and there is any sign of leakage, the mercury will escape. Use strong fire (*wǔhuǒ* 武火) and burn fiercely—this is optimal. From dawn until dusk, remove the fire and wait for it to cool. The basin should contain frost and mercury mixed together. Then, remove the salt and collect the purple powder (*zǐfěn* 紫粉). Strike it with an object to produce a metallic sound—it is then ready for use in the furnace.

**Method for Extracting Red Silver Halo (*hóngyín yún* 红银晕):**
Obtaining red silver halo is extremely difficult. Why? The materials used are not of the highest quality. Even those skilled in refining lead and mercury (*qiān gǒng* 铅汞) may have slight discrepancies in their techniques, let alone attempting to use ordinary stones and herbs as medicines—where raw and processed materials differ so greatly—yet hoping to transform the mundane into the true. How could this not be difficult?

Now, when using these methods, one must carefully distinguish impurities, understand their nature, and measure the ingredients precisely—whether in sequence or proportion. If the process aligns with principle, it will not differ from the genuine. The slightest deviation will lead to failure. Students must study this thoroughly and apply it carefully.

**Method for Washing and Refining Sand Halo (*shāzi yún* 砂子晕):**
All colored sands must not be washed with cold water; warm water should be used instead. Avoid mixing with other medicines during grinding, washing, or boiling, as external medicines may bind the sand halo, making extraction even more difficult. First, empty the sand and wash it with warm water—repeat this process several times. Then, add salt and rice gruel, grinding it thoroughly. Use barley grain broth, *wūméi* (乌梅, "black plum"), and *liáo* (寥) ash, storing it in a large porcelain container over a chaff fire for ten days until thoroughly decomposed. Before use, add *zhānglù gēn* (章陆根, "stem of *Achyranthes bidentata*") and boil the sand until it reaches the desired consistency. After this, it can be used in any refining process.

**Method for Extracting Red Silver Sand Halo (*hóngyín shāzi yún* 红银砂子晕):**
Take washed sand, shape it into small rods, and place wind-dissolved lime (*fēnghuà shuǐhuā* 风化石灰) in an iron crucible. Insert the rods into the lime and seal the crucible—it may also be left unsealed. Refine with alternating strong and gentle fire (*wénwǔhuǒ* 文武火) for one month or more. After pounding, each *jīn* (斤) yields ten *liǎng* (两) of pure, halo-free product.

**Method for Reviving Halo from Raw Mercury (*chōushēng chūyún* 抽生出晕):**
Take sand and mix it with two *liǎng* (两) of *hánshuǐshí* (寒水石, "cold water stone"), one *liǎng* (两) of *fánshí* (矾石, "alum stone"), and one *liǎng* (两) of *zhānglù gēn* (章陆根, "stem of *Achyranthes bidentata*") per *jīn* (斤) of sand. Grind them thoroughly together for three to five meals' duration—the more grinding, the better. Wash and repeat the process with the same three ingredients twice more. The halo should now be fully extracted. Then, regenerate the raw mercury (*shēng gǒng* 生汞) and mix it with *hánshuǐshí* (寒水石) paste in the pan (*chēng* 铛), using vinegar as a binder. Place a half-*cùn* (寸) layer of *hánshuǐshí* at the bottom and a one-*cùn* (寸) layer on top, with the sand sandwiched between layers of *hánshuǐshí* powder—or shape it into thin sheets if preferred. Cover with *liáo* (寥) ash and salt, then refine with alternating strong and gentle fire (*wénwǔhuǒ* 文武火) for one *fú* period. Afterward, place it in a crucible and melt it into the *hánshuǐshí* pool.

**Method for Preparing the *Hánshuǐshí* Pool (*shí fǎ* 池法):**
Mix *hánshuǐshí* (寒水石) with saltwater into a paste like *miǎn* (缅, "Myanmar") glue, applying it in three layers until it turns as white as snow.

**Method for Roasting *Hánshuǐshí* (烧寒水石法):**
Take *hánshuǐshí* (寒水石), quickly remove it from the fire, seal the basin tightly, and wait for it to cool before use.

**Method for Pointing Red Silver Halo (*diǎn hóngyín yún* 点红银晕):**
One *liǎng* (两) of toxic frost (*dú fēng* 毒霜) and half a *liǎng* (两) of *jùróng dǎnzi* (句容胆子, "cholecyst from Jurong")
Mix these finely.

First, prepare lime by heating it as in the *lín huī* (淋灰, "lime leaching") method and leach it with white horse urine, obtaining about two *shāng* (升) of liquid. Place this in a porcelain bottle. Add the two ingredients, boil with strong fire (*wǔhuǒ* 武火) for two *fú* periods, then cool. Remove the residual liquid and impurities, mix with half a *liǎng* (两) of *fúhuǒ xiāoshí* (伏火消石, "roasted alumstone"), and knead into a paste. Place it in a medicine container and refine with alternating strong and gentle fire (*wénwǔhuǒ* 文武火) for two days. During refining, each *liǎng* (两) of medicine can treat one *jīn* (斤) of material like snow.

**Method for *Suì Zǐ* (遂子) from *Hóng Yín*:**
Take one *jīn* (斤) of thoroughly refined *hóng yín* (red silver), mix it with four *liǎng* of the mother substance, making a total of twenty *liǎng*. Form a thin *dàn* in a crucible—if it is too thick, pound it until even.

After pounding, heat it until it matches the fire’s hue, then boil and wash it clean. Use three *jīn* of *gǒng* (汞), place the *dàn* flat in the *gāng* (铛), and secure it tightly. Apply gentle fire, like that of a midsummer day, then gradually increase the heat.

Open the furnace every two days. If *gǒng* rises, slightly reduce the fire—only enough to prevent it from rising further.
After twenty days, recast it into a *dàn*. Repeat this process for another twenty days, then recast again.
After refining and nurturing for six [missing term], all haze will disappear, and it will become the true treasure.
(Note: One version states "six *liǎng* folded into two.")

When first refining, add a small amount of *kuángshā* (硇砂) and *dǎnzǐ* (胆子), then boil the *gǒng* for a day. The *dàn* should adhere to the bottom of the *gāng*, fully integrating with the *gǒng*—this is ideal.

Another method states: Take four *liǎng* of the *dàn*, mix one *liǎng* of *Běi Tíng kuángshā* (北庭硇砂), one *liǎng* of *shí dǎn* (石胆), and one *fēn* (分) of *jié lín yì* (骇鳞蜴). Grind these three substances together, then mix with rice vinegar into a paste and coat the *dàn*. Wrap it in yellow soil, one *cùn* and two *fēn* thick, and bake it in husk-fire for three days. Then burn it with white charcoal for three more days.
Remove the soil and place it in the original vessel with four *liǎng* of *gǒng*. (From the *Dān Shā Jīng* (丹砂经).)

Another version says: Before refining, line the vessel with *huáng dān* (黄丹) and *hú fěn* (胡粉) to form a paste. Place the *gǒng* and *dàn* inside, and after one refining cycle of ten days, there will be no haze—whether the quantity is large or small, it is at the user’s discretion, with ten *liǎng* as the standard.

Another version states: For *suì zǐ*, mix with *xiāoshí* (消石) and refine it for seven days, alternating between upright and inverted positions each day. After seven days, it will turn into black ash. Grind and wash it thoroughly, then refine it until it becomes white and fluffy.

---
**The Dao of *Suì Zǐ*:**
The essence of *suì zǐ* lies in its minimal haze—this makes oral ingestion easier. If the process seems difficult, this is the key insight.
Take one *jīn* of thoroughly refined *hóng yín* (red silver), mix it with four *liǎng* of the mother substance, making a total of twenty *liǎng*. Form a thin *dàn* in a crucible—if it is too thick, pound it until even.

After pounding, heat it until it matches the fire’s hue, then boil and wash it clean. Use three *jīn* of *gǒng* (汞), place the *dàn* in the *gāng* (铛), and add a small amount of *shí dǎn* (石胆) and *kuángshā* (硇砂) water. Boil for a day—the *gǒng* and *dàn* should fully integrate, with the *dàn* adhering to the bottom of the *gāng*. Then seal it tightly and let the *yīn* (阴) energy emerge.

The *Suì Zǐ* Method Continued:

At first, use two *liǎng* of *wǔ* (武), then gradually increase to two *liǎng* of *wén* (文). Use only the finest, most volatile *fēi shàng* (flying mercury), slightly refined.

Thus, after twenty days, remove the excess *shēng gǒng* (raw mercury), leaving only what fits in the crucible. Again, form a *dàn* as before, placing the mercury inside, and proceed as earlier. After twenty days, repeat this process.

A third time, form the crucible anew, and once more introduce the mercury to produce the *dàn*. In this way, over six cycles, the haze will fully dissipate, surpassing even mountain and river ores.

The *Jīnlíng Zǐ* says: The mercury used in each boiling and in refining the red silver will become impure. It can be purified by washing with salt, alum, or even rice washing—this is excellent.

Once the mercury is cleansed, use it again with refined results.

Moreover, I have seen in the *Qī Piān Dānshā Jué* (Seven Chapters on Cinnabar Secrets) that medicinal substances are used to nurture the gold crucible through this very method. Now, red silver should likewise be prepared according to this principle—it is superior.

The medicinal mixture applied to the crucible before firing consists of:
- One *liǎng* of northern *kuángshā* (硇砂),
- One *liǎng* of rock salt (*shí yán*),
- One *liǎng* of *qílín jié* (麒麟竭).

Grind these three together, mix with a small amount of wine to form a paste, and coat the crucible evenly. Then, wrap it in yellow clay, one *cùn* and two *fēn* thick, and fire it in the furnace for fourteen days. Afterward, burn with white charcoal for three days, following the prescribed method.

When firing white substances, the medicinal coating can be added directly, making the *Suì Zǐ* even more potent.

Another method for firing the silver crucible:
- One *liǎng* of alum ash (*bái fán huī*),
- One *liǎng* of *kuángshā*,
- One *liǎng* of *xiāoshí* (消石, niter),
- Two *liǎng* of salt, roasted in hidden fire.

Apply this mixture, wrap it in clay as before, and fire with husk fuel for seven days, then burn with white charcoal for one hidden period—this is the standard.

*End of the Lower Scroll of the Dragon-Tiger Reunion Elixir Secrets.*

chunks.original_text: 龙虎还丹诀 经名：龙虎还丹诀。 唐金陵子撰。 二卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部众术类。 龙虎还丹诀卷上 金陵子述 紫叶红英大还丹诀 夫还丹者，本自九天之精粹，受二十四真。 真水真火，外内包含，化五神运气，积而为水砂，禀积气极，乃号紫华红英之丹。 又从戊己中宫黄金，化质归离，功成於九。 是以阳金迁变，动用化机，运质易胎，合其五方之体，然后超於三元，脱质归真，号日还丹，殊灵化也。 其还丹无方，《金碧经》及《参同契》是其方也。 自古真仙，悉皆隐秘。 灵文藏於洞府，金简秘在仙都。 纵口诀书在纸墨，亦须师传，不可轻用。 理玄深而莫测，旨秘奥而难寻。 今有好道之士，志慕长生者，先须辨其药品高下，识其真汞真铅，知金石之情性，然后运火铅汞，为药之本也。 辨水银 按仙经隐号，一名河上姥女，一名长生子，一名汞，一名太阳流珠，一名神胶，一名陵阳子，一名玄明龙，一名玄水，一名白虎脑，一名金银席。 金陵子曰：水银者，五阳灵之神精，五神会符，合为一体，托胎於丹砂，位居南方。 其铆石中，五金七十二石，多受阴气，形质顽狠，至性沈滞，功力悬殊，不可比量。 易胎乃为壬水，水则见水银也。 故能轻飞玄化，感御万灵。 金石总其一体，号日丹阳，水包八石，内含金精。 其丹砂上有至灵至神，至圣至明。 怀袖中致一两，尚辟去邪魔，况伏治入於五藏。 五神吋符，会气托形为丹砂，是太阳至精，赤帝之君，金火之正体，通於八石，应二十四气，万灵之主，造化之根，明神之本，能变化也，故号日赤龙。 若翱翔，名之日朱乌。 其丹者，是金感於火，名之为丹。 汞者，是火去於金，而名日汞。 金火之精结成，含玄元澄正之真气，还丹之基本，大药之根源，德合则万象生焉，体离则杳冥难测。 经日：阳精赫赫，得之可以还魂返魄。 按《受寿记》亦云：阳精赫赫，固魂固魄，神仙之上品。 若得上品丹砂，不假烧合，便堪服饵，是自然之还丹也。 丹砂虽是正阳之精，灵於万物。 然为所出州土山谷，受气不同，而有数十种，大须精鉴。 只如凡人灵性，尚乃不等，乌兽肉血，亦有不同，须明辨之。 上品者生於辰锦州石穴之中，而有数色。 中品者生於交桂，亦有数类。 下品者生於衡邵，数种品类。 皆因清浊体别，真邪不同，降气分精，感通金石。 受正气者，服之而通玄契真，为上仙矣。 受偏气者，服之亦得长生留世。 且上品光明砂者，出於辰锦山石之中白交白床之上，十二枚为一座者，十二枚、九枚最灵，七枚、五枚生者其次。 每么座中有一大珠，可重十余两，为主君。 四面小者，亦重八九两，亦有六七两已下者，为臣周绕，朝揖中心大者。 於座四面，又有杂砂一二斗，回抱其玉座朱床。 於其座外杂砂中，拣得芙蓉头，安红绢上，光明通彻者，亦入上品。 又有如马牙成，外白浮光明者，是上品。 白马牙砂，有长似笑生，而红紫色者，即上品。 紫灵砂，若如石片棱角，生青光者，是下品。 紫砂如交桂所出，但是座生，及打石中得者，形如芙蓉头成，而光明者，亦入上品。 如颗粒成，三数枚重一斤，通明者，为中品。 片段成，明彻者，为下品，如衡邵所出。 总是紫砂及打石中得，而红光者，亦是下品之砂，如溪砂。

**Dragon-Tiger Reversion Elixir Formula**

**Title:** *Dragon-Tiger Reversion Elixir Formula*
**Attributed to:** *Jinlingzi* of the Tang Dynasty. Two scrolls.
**Source:** *Zhengtong Daozang* (Canonical Daoist Treasury of the Zhengtong Era), *Dongshen* (Cavern Spirit) section, *Zhongshu* (Miscellaneous Arts) category.

**Scroll One: Jinlingzi’s Explanation of the *Zhiyehongying* (Purple Leaf Red Flower) Great Reversion Elixir Formula**

The Reversion Elixir originates from the quintessence of the Nine Heavens, nurtured by the Twenty-Four Celestial Worthies. True Water, True Fire—encompassing both external and internal—refine the Five Divine Energies and the movements of *qi*, accumulating as *shuishā* (water-sand). When the gathered *qi* reaches its utmost, it becomes the *Zhihuá Hóngyīng* (Purple Bloom Red Flower) Elixir.

Again, from the *Wù-Jǐ Zhōnggōng* (Mid-Court of the Fifth-Sixth Heavenly Stems) Yellow Gold, the essence is purified through the *Lǐ* (Alchemical Process), and its completion lies in the *Jǐu* (Nine). Thus, the Yang Gold undergoes transformation, its dynamic *qi* and alchemical mechanisms shifting, its essence changing form, and it harmonizes with the Five Directions’ constitution. Only then does it transcend the Three Primordial Elements (*Sānyuán*), shed its material body, and return to its True Nature—hence the name *Reversion Elixir*, a marvelous and refined metamorphosis.

The Reversion Elixir has no fixed method; the *Jīnbì Jīng* (Golden Splendor Scripture) and the *Cāntóng Qì* (Grand Concordance of the Mysterious) are its methods. Since antiquity, true immortals have all concealed their secrets. Sacred texts are hidden in celestial caverns, golden tablets sealed within the Daoist sanctuaries. Even if the oral formulas are inscribed on paper, they must still be transmitted by a master and cannot be recklessly applied. Their principles are profound and unfathomable; their meanings hidden and difficult to discern.

Now, for those who love the Dao and aspire to longevity, they must first distinguish the quality of their medicinal ingredients—high or low—and recognize *True Mercury* and *True Lead*. They must understand the temperaments and nature of metals and minerals before refining Lead and Mercury with Fire, for these are the foundations of the elixir.

**Discerning Mercury**
According to the hidden names in Daoist scriptures, Mercury is called:
- *Héshàng Lǎonǚ* (Old Woman of the Riverbank),
- *Chángshēngzǐ* (Child of Longevity),
- *Gōng* (Mercury),
- *Tàiyáng Liúzhū* (Luminous Pearl of the Great Sun),
- *Shénjiāo* (Divine Glue),
- *Língyángzǐ* (Child of the Ling Mountain),
- *Xuánmíng Lóng* (Mysterious Brightness Dragon),
- *Xuánshuǐ* (Mysterious Water),
- *Báihǔ Nǎo* (Brain of the White Tiger),
- *Jīnyín Xí* (Mercury-Lead Mat).

Jinlingzi says: Mercury is the divine essence of the Five Yang Energies, where the Five Divine Energies converge into one. It takes form in *dānshā* (cinnabar), residing in the South. When it is extracted from minerals, the Five Metals and seventy-two stones—most of which absorb excess *Yīn qi*—become coarse and rigid, their nature sluggish and their potency far inferior. Thus, Mercury is called *Rénshuǐ* (Ninth Water), for it is water in essence. It can ascend lightly, transform subtly, and command the obedience of all spirits.

In totality, it is called *Dānyáng* (Elixir-Sun), as water encompasses the Eight Stones, containing within itself the essence of gold. Its cinnabar holds the most refined and divine, the most sacred and luminous. Even a mere two *liǎng* (ounces) held in one’s sleeve can repel malevolent spirits; how much more so when it is ingested and harmonized within the Five Viscera?

The Five Divine Energies converge, the *qi* coalesces, and the form is born as cinnabar—this is the purest essence of the Great Sun, the sovereign of the Red Emperor, the true body of the Gold-Fire, in communion with the Eight Stones, responsive to the Twenty-Four *qi* Movements. It is the master of all spirits, the root of transformation, the foundation of the Luminous God, capable of change and metamorphosis—thus it is called the *Chìlóng* (Vermilion Dragon). If it soars aloft, it is named *Zhūwū* (Crimson Crow).

The elixir is formed when gold is affected by fire, hence its name *dān*. Mercury is when fire departs from gold, hence its name *gōng*. When the essence of gold and fire conjoin, they contain the pure and settled *qi* of the Mysterious Primordial, the fundamental essence of the Reversion Elixir, and the source of the Great Medicine. When their *virtue/power* (*dé*) is harmonized, all phenomena arise; when their substance is separated, they vanish into the unfathomable.

The scripture states: *"The Yang Essence blazes resplendent; obtaining it allows one to return the soul and restore the spirit."*

According to the *Shòushòu Jì* (Record of Receiving Longevity), it is also said: *"The Yang Essence blazes resplendent; it solidifies the soul and steadies the spirit, being the supreme grade of the immortals."*

If one attains the highest-grade cinnabar, it requires no further refining or fusion—it is already fit for ingestion. This is the natural Reversion Elixir.

Though cinnabar is the essence of the True Yang, surpassing all things in its luminosity, its origin varies by region—mountains, valleys, and lands—each absorbing different *qi*, resulting in tens of varieties. One must carefully discern them.

Even among ordinary people, their spiritual nature is unequal; the flesh and blood of birds and beasts also differ, and must be clearly distinguished.

The highest-grade cinnabar grows in the stone cavities of the *Chénjǐn* (Zhenjin) Prefecture, manifesting in multiple hues.

The middle-grade cinnabar is found in *Jiāoguì* (Guangxi-Jiangxi), also with several forms.

The lowest-grade cinnabar is from *Héngshào* (Hengyang-Shaoyang), with various qualities and grades.

All are shaped by the purity or turbidity of their constitution, the true or false nature of their *qi*, and the division of their essence as they resonate with metals and minerals. Those that absorb the True *qi* can be ingested to attain communion with the Mysterious Dao, making one a High Immortal. Those that absorb partial *qi* grant longevity and worldly survival.

For instance, the *Guāngmíngshā* (Luminous Cinnabar) of the highest grade emerges from the stone cavities of *Chénjǐn* Mountain, atop a white bed and white stratum, in clusters of twelve or nine pieces—these being the most potent. Those of seven or five pieces are of secondary efficacy.

Within each cluster, there is a large pearl weighing over ten *liǎng*, called the *Zhǔjūn* (Master Sovereign). Surrounding it are smaller pieces, also weighing eight or nine *liǎng*, or even six or seven, called the *Chén* (Subordinates), which encircle and defer to the central pearl.

On the four sides of the cluster, there is also a mixed cinnabar of one or two *dǒu* (bushels), embracing the jade-like cluster and its crimson bed.

From the mixed cinnabar outside the cluster, if one selects the *Fúróngtóu* (Peony-Head) variety, places it upon red silk, and it remains luminously transparent, it is also counted among the highest grade.

Another variety resembles *Mǎyáchéng* (Horse-Tooth Form), with a white exterior and floating brilliance—this is the highest grade.

The *Báimǎyáshā* (White Horse-Tooth Cinnabar), if elongated like a *xiàoshēng* (smiling figure) and colored red-purple, is also the highest grade.

The *Zǐlíngshā* (Purple Luminous Cinnabar), if it appears as stone fragments with sharp edges and emits a greenish glow, is of the lowest grade.

The cinnabar from *Jiāoguì* (Guangxi-Jiangxi), if it grows in clusters or is obtained by striking stones and forms like *Fúróngtóu* (Peony-Head) while remaining luminous, is also of the highest grade.

If it appears as coarse grains, with three or four pieces weighing a *jīn* (pound), and is translucent, it is of the middle grade.

If it appears as flakes or fragments and is clear, it is of the lowest grade, such as that from *Héngshào* (Hengyang-Shaoyang).

In summary, cinnabar obtained from clusters or by striking stones, if it emits a red glow, is also of the lowest grade—such as *Xīshā* (Stream Cinnabar).

chunks.original_text: 有颗粒成，而通明者，伏治饵之，亦得长生留世，未得为上仙矣。 如土砂生於土穴之中，溪砂养於溪水砂土之内，而出者相杂，故不中入上药，服食所用。 如座生者，是最上品之砂。 得其座中心主君砂一枚，伏治入於五藏，则功勋便着，名上丹台，正气长存，超然绝累。 更服至七返九还，轻举也。 故知阳之真精，降气而圆光周满，无有偏邪。 但是伏治之砂，作芙蓉头成，而圆光通明者，即是上品神仙服饵之药。 经言丹砂者，自然还丹也。 又只如玉座之砂，世人总知之，如金座、天座是。 太上紫龙玄华之丹，非俗人凡夫之所见知也。 其玉座则俗流志士积功，修治服之致仙。 其金座则宿有仙骨，清虚治神，隐之岩穴，则其神仙，采与食之，便当日羽化，升腾其天座，则太上天仙真官所取服饵，非下仙之药也。 其玉座砂，受得六千年阳虚之清精，则化为金座。 金座则座黄色当中，有五枚，层层而生，四面四五小珠周远。 金座受万六千年阳虚之清精，则化为天座。 天座则座碧色，当中有九枚，层层而生，四面七十二枚周绕。 在於飘飘太虚之中，常有太一之神护持。 上元之日，真官下采，其山忽开，光明照曜，一山如火。 其天座砂，真官收采，世人不可得也。 其光明砂，每一斤只含石气二两，抽得水银十四两。 其白马牙砂一斤，含石气四两，抽得水银十二两。 紫灵砂，含石气六两，抽得水银十两。 如上色通明溪砂一斤，抽得水银八两半二其石气有七两半。 其杂色土砂之类一斤，抽得水银七两半，含石气八两半。 石气者，火石之空气也。 如水银出后，可有石胎一两，青白灰耳。 其光明砂，受太阳清通澄朗正真之精气，结而成砂。 服之一两，力敌白马牙砂四两。 白马牙砂受太阳平和柔顺之精气。 服之一两，力敌紫灵砂八两。 紫灵砂受山泽之虚气，其溪砂土砂杂类等，俱受浊滞不真之气，结而成砂，不可比量也。 此既辨其丹砂品位，即知水银高下。 夫修至药，切忌水银杂。 此是真诀。 《 大洞真经》 皆秘其真汞，取上品丹砂，一色不杂者，抽得水银，转更含内水内火气，为之真汞。 故经云：杂类不同种，焉能合体居。 同类者，是其真汞也。 亦名子母。 仙经秘而不泄。 金陵子日：投汞於金上生砂，而成朱砂，此亦是金座砂也。 真汞者，则上品丹砂中抽得汞。 转更含内水内火之气，然后名为真汞。 右取筋竹为筒，节密处全贮三节。 上节开孔，可弹丸许大。 中节用小孔子，如筋头许大，容汞滴下处，先铺厚蜡纸两重，致中节之上。 次取丹砂细研，入於筒中，以麻紧缚其筒，蒸之一日。 然后以黄泥包裹之，可厚三分，埋入土中，令筒与地面平，筒四面紧筑，莫令漏泄其气。 便积薪烧其上，一复时，令火透其筒上节，汞即溜下，於下节之中，分毫不折。 忽火小汞出。 未尽灰犹黑紫，依此更烧之，令其汞合火数足。 诸法之中，此为要妙。 丹砂虽同类，抽出得水银，未可添合於金砂中，不出须受内水内火之气。 治汞法 汞一斤　石硫黄三两 右生梼研为粉，致於瓷钵中，着微火，续续下汞，急手研之，令为青砂。 后将入瓷鉼中，其鉼子可受一升。 以泥固济，令可厚二分，以盖合之，密固济全。 致之炉中，用炭一斤，於鉼子四面，长须有一斤炭。
chunks.translated_text:
There are grains that form and are translucent—if one refines and ingests them, one may achieve longevity and remain in the world, though not yet ascend to the rank of an *upper immortal* (上仙).

Cinnabar from the earth, born within earthly cavities, and stream cinnabar nurtured in the sandy soil of streams, when they emerge, are mixed—thus they do not qualify as *upper-grade elixir* (上药) for consumption.

The *seat-grown* cinnabar is the supreme grade of the elixir. Obtaining the central *master cinnabar* (主君砂) from its seat—one grain—when refined and ingested into the five *zàng* (viscera), its efficacy becomes manifest, and it is called the *upper-grade cinnabar elixir* (上丹台). The vital *zhèngqì* (正气) endures, and one transcends all worldly burdens.

Further, after refining it through seven *fǎn* (returns) and nine *huán* (retreats), one attains effortless ascension. Hence, the true essence of *yang* (male, luminous) *qi* descends and coalesces into a radiant, full orb—untainted by any *piānxié* (perverse, pathogenic) influence.

But the refined cinnabar of the *Peony-Head* (芙蓉头) form, which is luminous and round, is indeed the supreme elixir for *immortals* (神仙) to consume.

The *scriptures* (经) state that cinnabar is the *natural elixir* (自然还丹).

Moreover, as with the *jade-seat cinnabar* (玉座之砂) commonly known by the world—such as the *gold-seat cinnabar* (金座) or *heaven-seat cinnabar* (天座)—

The *Supreme Purple Dragon’s Mysterious Elixir* (太上紫龙玄华之丹) is beyond the comprehension of ordinary mortals.

The *jade-seat cinnabar* is refined by those of *common aspiration* (俗流志士) who accumulate merit and cultivate its essence to attain immortality.

The *gold-seat cinnabar* is obtained by those with *immortal predisposition* (仙骨), who purify their spirits and refine their essence in seclusion within mountain caves. When they gather and consume its cinnabar, they ascend instantly, their bodies *avianizing* (羽化). Ascending to the *heaven-seat cinnabar* (天座), they then partake of the elixir of the *Supreme Celestial Immortals* (太上天仙真官), not the medicine of lesser immortals.

The *jade-seat cinnabar*, having absorbed the *pure, luminous, and refined essence* (阳虚之清精) of sixty thousand years, transforms into *gold-seat cinnabar*. The *gold-seat cinnabar* is yellow within its seat, bearing five grains layered in growth, surrounded on all sides by forty-five small pearls.

The *gold-seat cinnabar*, having absorbed the *pure, luminous, and refined essence* of sixty thousand years further, transforms into *heaven-seat cinnabar*. The *heaven-seat cinnabar* is verdant in color, bearing nine grains within its seat, layered in growth, and encircled on all sides by seventy-two grains.

It dwells in the *floating void* (飘飘太虚), perpetually guarded by the *Supreme Unity Spirit* (太一之神). On the *Upper Primordial Day* (上元之日), the *true officials* (真官) descend to harvest it, and the mountain suddenly blazes, its light radiant as fire.

The *heaven-seat cinnabar* is gathered by the *true officials*—common mortals cannot obtain it.

The *luminous cinnabar* (光明砂), for every *jīn* (pound), contains only two *liǎng* (ounces) of *stone qi* (石气) and yields fourteen *liǎng* of *mercury* (水银).

The *White Horse Tooth Cinnabar* (白马牙砂), for every *jīn*, contains four *liǎng* of *stone qi* and yields twelve *liǎng* of *mercury*.

The *Purple Luminous Cinnabar* (紫灵砂), for every *jīn*, contains six *liǎng* of *stone qi* and yields ten *liǎng* of *mercury*.

The *upper-grade, luminous stream cinnabar* (上色通明溪砂), for every *jīn*, yields eight *liǎng* and a half of *mercury*, with seven *liǎng* and a half of *stone qi*.

The *mixed-color earth cinnabar* (杂色土砂), for every *jīn*, yields seven *liǎng* and a half of *mercury*, with eight *liǎng* and a half of *stone qi*.

*Stone qi* (石气) is the *void essence* of *fire stone* (火石).

After the *mercury* is extracted, a *stone residue* (石胎) of one *liǎng*—greenish-white and gray—remains.

The *luminous cinnabar*, having absorbed the *clear, refined, and true essence* (清通澄朗正真之精气) of the *Supreme Sun* (太阳), forms into cinnabar. Consuming one *liǎng* is equivalent in power to four *liǎng* of *White Horse Tooth Cinnabar*.

The *White Horse Tooth Cinnabar* absorbs the *balanced, gentle, and compliant essence* (平和柔顺之精气) of the *Supreme Sun*. Consuming one *liǎng* is equivalent in power to eight *liǎng* of *Purple Luminous Cinnabar*.

The *Purple Luminous Cinnabar* absorbs the *void qi* of mountains and marshes, while the *stream cinnabar* and *earth cinnabar* of mixed grades all absorb *turbulent, stagnant, and untrue qi* (浊滞不真之气), forming into cinnabar—none can compare in potency.

Having thus distinguished the grades of cinnabar elixir, one knows the hierarchy of *mercury*.

For the cultivation of *elixir medicine* (至药), one must absolutely avoid *mercury* of mixed grades. This is the *true secret* (真诀).

The *Great Cavern True Scripture* (大洞真经) conceals its *true mercury* (真汞), taking only *upper-grade cinnabar* (上品丹砂) that is of a single hue, extracting its *mercury*, and then infusing it with *internal water and internal fire qi* (内水内火气) to make it *true mercury*.

Thus the *scripture* says: *"Mixed grades of different kinds—how could they unite in form and reside?"* (杂类不同种，焉能合体居). Only those of the same kind are *true mercury*—also called *mother-child mercury* (子母).

The *Immortal Scriptures* keep this secret and do not reveal it.

The *Child of Jinling* (金陵子) says: *"When mercury is cast upon cinnabar, it produces cinnabar grains—this is also the gold-seat cinnabar."*

*True mercury* (真汞) is obtained by extracting mercury from the *upper-grade cinnabar*, then infusing it with *internal water and internal fire qi* before it can be so named.

**Method for Extracting Mercury from Cinnabar:**

Take *jīnzhú* (筋竹) as a tube, storing it fully in three *joints* (节). Pierce a hole in the upper joint, large enough for a *bullet* (弹丸). Use a small hole in the middle joint, like the size of a *tendon* (筋头), for the mercury to drip through. First, lay two layers of thick wax paper beneath the middle joint.

Then take finely ground cinnabar and place it within the tube. Secure the tube tightly with hemp rope, and steam it for one day.

Next, wrap it in yellow clay, making the layer three *fēn* (fingers-width) thick, and bury it in the earth. Level the tube with the ground, and firmly pack the surrounding soil so that no *qi* escapes.

Pile wood atop and ignite it. After one *cycle of fire* (复时), let the flames penetrate the upper joint of the tube. The mercury will then flow downward into the middle joint, undivided by even a hair’s breadth.

When the fire is small and the mercury begins to emerge, the remaining ash is still black and purple. Repeat the process until the mercury is fully gathered, ensuring the fire is sufficient.

Among all methods, this is the most essential and wondrous.

Even if cinnabar is of the same kind, once its mercury is extracted and mixed with other cinnabar, it must again absorb *internal water and internal fire qi* before it can be used.

**Method for Refining Mercury:**

Mercury: one *jīn* (pound)
*Shíliúhuáng* (石硫黄, sulfur): three *liǎng* (ounces)

Grind the *shíliúhuáng* into powder and place it in a porcelain basin. Apply gentle heat, and drip the mercury in slowly, stirring vigorously with the hand until it becomes *green sand* (青砂).

Then transfer it into a porcelain *retreating vessel* (鉼, *huánluán* vessel), which can hold one *shēng* (pint). Seal it with clay, making the layer two *fēn* thick, and cover it tightly. Secure it completely.

Place it in a furnace, using one *jīn* of charcoal. Around the vessel on all sides, arrange the charcoal in long strands, totaling one *jīn*.

chunks.original_text: 三日后，便以武火烧之，可用炭十斤，分为两分，每一上炭五斤，烧其鉼子。 忽有青烟透出，即以稀泥急涂之，莫令焰出，炭尽为度。 候寒开之，其汞化为紫砂，分毫无欠。 又取前紫砂，以黑铅一斤，将其黑铅先於鼎内镕成汁。 次取紫砂细研，投於铅汁中，歇去火，急手炒令和合为砂。 致鼎中，细研，盐覆盖，可厚二分，紧按令实际，令武火飞之半日，灵汞即出，分毫不欠，此名为内水火也。 金陵子日：阳精火也，阴精水也。 阴阳伏制，水火相持，故阳阴制之。 又其丹研水银。 虽辨别其品位高下，亦有曾被秽恶者。 水银非论杂乱，曾近死人来者，甚难辨识。 其丹砂若经生死秽触者，向上一重朱衣便落，其颗粒却光净无其衣者，是曾经秽也。 今但拣择取上色丹砂一色者，自抽飞变，取水银用为精妙也。 辨真铅 按仙经隐号，一名立制石，一名黄精，一名玄华，一名白虎，一名黄芽，一名河车，一名黄池，一名黄龙，一名木锡。 又真铅，按《龙虎经》云：故锡外黑内华，金体。 又按《潜通诀》日：玄白生金公，巍巍建始初。 金陵子日：真铅者，取其铆石中烧出，未曾灶抽伏治者，含其元气，为之真铅。 《大洞真经》皆隐秘其真铅，不可轻泄。 其真水内火者，黑锡石硫黄是也。 铅锡俱禀北方壬癸之气。 锡受壬精，铅禀癸气，金终於癸，故铅察於阴极之精也。 按仙经：铅若不真，其汞难亲。 故铅须真也。 又诀 夫大还七返九还者，异名而同体。 返者是砂化为金，还者是金归於丹。 经云：反我乡，归我常，服之白日朝玉皇。 其丹炉鼎，亦须合天地人三才。 其鼎用药金二十四两，应二十四气。 内八两为盖，可受九合。 取甲辰旬中戊申日，於西南申地，取净土为炉，内径一尺二寸。 三台十二门，门须具扇。 以上品光明砂一味而成，以铅、石硫黄、赤盛、马牙消等佐助。 七返九还，是住世长生升飞之药也。 以丹砂一斤，碎如麻颗许大，和石灵、马牙消，以水煮四十日，阳药阴以伏也。 然入鼎中，以阴阳火候，飞伏五日。 内四日，用坎卦。 一日，用离卦。 坎卦者，煮四日。 离卦者，火飞之一日。 如此五日为一候，三候为一气，用八气二十四候，一百二十日，其砂伏火矣。 更须用盐花包之，重以黄土为泥，紧曩固济金鼎，入炉，武火烧三十日。 即将鼓出银，亦名黄火银，更一两，转便成黄金。 如此七返，其丹以成，名为玄真绛霞砂，服之长生住世。 点水银及五金，并成宝。 又将此绛霞砂，鼓取紫金十五两，取其真铅一斤，石硫黄五两，三物相和，入鼎烧之六转，转添阳硫黄，用金为鼎，立坛炉，每从甲子日子时起火，两月六十日为一转。 其丹欲成，紫气连天，日月失辉，山河震动。 其丹成也，赫然轻飞，脱离於质，如芙蓉九层，连於鼎盖，十五两分毫不欠。 其鼎内有滞灰二十四两，如紫金色。 其紫灰一丸如麻子大，立制汞一斤，及五金尽化为上宝。 古仙有品类真，则一同其七返之砂，功力甚着，服之亦得为高仙。 尚未证其真何也，绿药尚有室碍之体，未能轻化，离於五神，犹为真水世火而所销铸。 且九转之丹成，飘飘轻化，迥脱凡质，圆光洞曜，紫气冲天，遇物而化，无有凝碍，千鼓万鞘，终不销镕，而精光转益矣。
