Three days later, apply *wu* fire (violent fire) to burn it, using ten *jīn* of charcoal, divided into two portions—five *jīn* above, five *jīn* below—the vessel. When green vapor suddenly emerges, immediately coat it with thin, diluted clay, lest flames escape, until the charcoal is exhausted.

Wait for it to cool, then open it. The mercury will have transformed into *zǐshā* (紫砂, cinnabar sand), without loss of a single grain.

Again, take the previous *zǐshā* and mix it with one *jīn* of black lead. First, melt the black lead within the cauldron to form a liquid. Then, finely grind the *zǐshā* and toss it into the lead liquid. Remove the fire and quickly stir-fry it by hand until the mixture congeals into sand. Return it to the cauldron, grind it finely, cover it with salt to a thickness of two *fēn*, and press it firmly to ensure contact. Apply *wu* fire (violent fire) to it for half a day, and the refined mercury (*línggǒng*, 灵汞) will emerge, without loss of a single grain. This is called *internal water and fire qi* (内水火).

The *Jīnlíng* adept said: The essence of *yang* is fire, the essence of *yin* is water. When *yin* and *yang* are subdued and balanced, water and fire hold each other in check; hence, the *yang* and *yin* are governed by this principle.

Again, regarding cinnabar and mercury: Though one may distinguish their quality as high or low, there are instances where they have been tainted. Mercury, regardless of impurity, if it has come near the dead, is exceedingly difficult to discern. If cinnabar has been exposed to the *shēngsǐ* (生死, life-and-death) defilements, its outermost layer of vermilion will fall away, leaving the grains bright and clean, stripped of their coating. This indicates it has been tainted. Now, only select the cinnabar of the finest hue, for it alone, through sublimation and refinement, yields the purest mercury.

**Discerning True Lead:**

According to the *hidden names* in the Daoist scriptures, true lead is called by many names: *lìzhìshí* (立制石, stabilizing stone), *huángjīng* (黄精, yellow essence), *xuánhuá* (玄华, dark splendor), *báihǔ* (白虎, white tiger), *huángyá* (黄芽, yellow sprout), *héchē* (河车, celestial chariot), *huángchí* (黄池, yellow pool), *huánglóng* (黄龙, yellow dragon), and *mùxī* (木锡, wooden tin).

The *Lónghǔ Jīng* (龙虎经, *Dragon-Tiger Classic*) states: "Lead is black externally, dark and splendid internally, with a golden body."

The *Qiántōng Jué* (潜通诀, *Subtle Penetration Canon*) says: "The dark and white produce the golden *gōng* (公, sovereign). Majestic and towering, the beginning is established."

The *Jīnlíng* adept said: True lead is obtained by extracting it from *lìshí* (铆石, lead ore) through sublimation, without prior smelting or refining. It retains its primordial *yuángǔ* (元气, original qi), making it the true lead. The *Dà Dòng Zhēn Jīng* (大洞真经, *True Classic of the Great Cavern*) conceals its true lead, and it must not be divulged lightly.

The true *water and internal fire qi* (真水内火) are black lead and sulfur. Lead and tin both draw upon the *qi* of the northern *bīng* (壬) and *guǐ* (癸) stems. Tin absorbs the *bīng* essence, while lead imbibes the *guǐ* qi. Gold ultimately depends upon *guǐ*, so lead is the refined essence of the utmost *yin*. As the Daoist scriptures say: "If lead is not true, the mercury will not bond with it." Therefore, lead must be true.

**Further Canon:**

The *Great Return* (大还) and *Nine Returns* (九还) are different names for the same process. *Return* (返) refers to sand transforming into gold, while *Return* (还) refers to gold reverting back to cinnabar. The scriptures say: "Return to my native place, revert to my eternal form. When taken, I will ascend in broad daylight to the Celestial Sovereign."

The cinnabar furnace and cauldron must also harmonize the *Three Realms* (天地人, *Tiāndìrén*) of Heaven, Earth, and Man.

The cauldron should be made of *yàojīn* (药金, medicinal gold) weighing twenty-four *liǎng*, corresponding to the twenty-four *qi* (气, seasonal breaths). Eight *liǎng* are used for the lid, which should hold nine *héng* (合, cups). Take it during the *jiǎchén* (甲辰, *Jiachen*) decan, specifically on the *wǔshēn* (戊申, *Wushen*) day, from the southwest *shēn* (申, *Shen*) direction. Use pure soil to construct the furnace, with an internal diameter of one *chǐ* (尺, foot) and two *cùn* (寸, inches). It must have three tiers and twelve gates, each gate equipped with a shutter.

With the finest *guāngmíngshā* (光明砂, luminous cinnabar) as the primary ingredient, assisted by black lead, sulfur, *chìshèng* (赤盛, red abundance), and *mǎyǎxiāo* (马牙消, horse-tooth borax), the *Seven Returns* and *Nine Returns* are the elixirs for longevity and ascension in this world.

Take one *jīn* of cinnabar, crush it into pieces as fine as hemp seeds, and mix it with *shílíng* (石灵, stone spirit) and *mǎyǎxiāo*. Boil it in water for forty days, as *yang* (阳) medicine is refined by *yin* (阴) means.

Then place it in the cauldron and refine it with *yin-yang* fire methods for five days. Four days are spent in the *kǎn* (坎, *Kan*) hexagram method—boiling. One day is spent in the *lí* (离, *Li*) hexagram method—flying with fire. Thus, five days constitute one *hòu* (候, period), and three periods make one *qì* (气, breath). Using eight breaths and twenty-four periods, a total of one hundred and twenty days, the cinnabar will have undergone sublimation.

Wrap it with *yánghuā* (盐花, salt flowers), then seal it with yellow soil as clay, pressing it tightly to secure the golden cauldron. Place it in the furnace and burn it with violent fire for thirty days.

Then extract the sublimated silver, also called *huánghuǒyín* (黄火银, yellow-fire silver), adding one *liǎng* at a time, until it gradually becomes golden. After seven such returns, the cinnabar will be complete, known as *Xuánzhēn Jiàngxiā Shā* (玄真绛霞砂, *Mysterious True Vermilion-Crimson Sand*), which, when taken, grants longevity and worldly immortality. It can also transmute mercury and the five metals into treasures.

Again, take this *Jiàngxiā Shā* (绛霞砂, vermilion-crimson sand) and extract fifteen *liǎng* of *zǐjīn* (紫金, purple gold). Mix it with one *jīn* of true lead and five *liǎng* of sulfur. Combine these three substances, place them in the cauldron, and refine them for six cycles. In each cycle, add *yang* sulfur, using a golden cauldron and erecting a furnace platform. Begin the fire at the *Zǐ* (子) hour on *Jiǎ* (甲) days, and each cycle spans two months, sixty days.

When the cinnabar is near completion, a purple vapor will rise continuously, obscuring the light of the sun and moon, causing the mountains and rivers to tremble. Upon its completion, it will ascend with a radiant glow, detaching from its gross form, resembling a nine-layered lotus, clinging to the cauldron lid—fifteen *liǎng* without loss of a single grain.

Within the cauldron, there will be twenty-four *liǎng* of lingering ash, colored like *zǐjīn*. A single pellet of this purple ash, the size of a hemp seed, can transmute one *jīn* of mercury and the five metals into supreme treasures.

Ancient immortals who mastered its true essence could, with a single dose of the *Seven Returns* sand, achieve extraordinary potency. Why has its truth not yet been verified? Because the *lǜyào* (绿药, green medicine) still retains its obstructive form and cannot yet ascend freely, remaining bound to the five elements as mere *shìhuǒ* (世火, mundane fire) and being consumed by it. Yet, with each of the nine transformations, the elixir becomes lighter and more refined, transcending ordinary matter, radiating a round and brilliant light, and its purple vapor ascends to the heavens. It encounters substances and transforms without obstruction, enduring countless refining cycles, never being consumed, and its essence grows ever more potent.

chunks.original_text: 炎火之内，亦不烧手，得服之者，当则羽化玄飞，为高上真人也。 夫道以据贤明志，诚君子得之，则福寿无疆。 轻泄之人，殃及九祖。 亦不可诬言而蔽之道，慎莫露志於凡情。 贤愚可熟，鉴之而已。 龙虎还丹诀 金陵子曰：大还者，难乎哉。 故经云：夫大还者，先授之於天，而还之於人。 若非积功苦行，行合於真，不可及矣。 圣人有言日：人命逝速，似於流水，倏忽形腐，生死之门殊大，若非能灵丹至药，别无径也。 得之者可以上朝三清，年寿万劫，玉女侍侧，货财千亿。 出《 阴君传》 是天地问正气为之，固得其然也。 自古还丹，有黄帝九鼎丹，老君还丹，琅牙、曲晨、神符、白雪、五灵、二十四丹等。 亦有从西国而来者。 虽流教於世，并无正方。
chunks.translated_text:
The inner flame does not burn the hand—
those who take it will ascend in misty flight,
becoming the exalted True Persons of the highest rank.

The Dao/Way, when grasped by the wise and virtuous intent,
is indeed the fortune and longevity without bound
for the noble ones who attain it.
For the frivolous and dissipated, it brings calamity even to their nine ancestral generations.

Nor should one falsely speak and conceal the Dao/Way—
be cautious not to reveal one’s true purpose to the common mind.

The wise and foolish can be discerned;
it is a matter of observation.

The **Lónghǔ Huán Dān Jié** (龙虎还丹诀, *Formula of the Dragon-Tiger Reversion Elixir*) says:

Great Reversion—ah, how difficult it is!
Thus the scripture states:
*"The Great Reversion is first granted by Heaven,
then returned to humanity.
If one has not accumulated merit through arduous practice,
and aligned with the True,
it cannot be attained."*

The sages have said:
*"Human life flees swiftly, like flowing water;
in an instant, the form decays.
The gateway of life and death is vast—
if not for the possession of wondrous elixirs and supreme medicines,
there is no other path."*

Those who obtain it may ascend to the Three Pure Ones,
live for countless eons,
be attended by jade maidens,
and amass treasures beyond measure.
This comes from *The Transmission of the Dark Lord*—
truly, it is the natural result of Heaven and Earth refining the **zhèngqì** (正气, *true qi*).

Since ancient times, there have been elixirs of Great Reversion:
the Yellow Emperor’s **Jiǔdǐng Dān** (九鼎丹, *Nine Cauldrons Elixir*),
Laozi’s Reversion Elixir,

chunks.original_text: 纵有文字，皆指阴阳托号而言。 圣人共秘斯门，真处不书，书处不真。 若自恃聪智，按文责实，以意推校，用意愈巧，去真逾远，非论惑其南北，黄芽金水之妙，从何得窥。 切在火候受气，若一象不足，则与瓦砾无殊。 而况途程尚遥尔，皆须口受良师，觉悟学者，亦须审其方便，明智专一。 非常之心，而有非常之事。 久受勤苦，而及得成。 不然外名丹壑，绝迹无着，或感神人而授之。 过此皆常徒虚劳生耳，不如且美酒执素也。 余亦非先觉者，给侍长者，苦辛岁久，侧聆斯义。 坎离二卦，为药之根源。 朱砂南方火之位，内含水银也。 黑铅北方水，内含银也。 银是铅中之精，水银是砂中之宝。 精宝既分，各归其根，故为之青龙白虎。 经曰：用铅不用铅，其义可知也。 据此白银是铅中之至精，水银是砂中之真宝。 若将此银及水银为丹药，恐无得理。 故经云：若向铅中求，玄发成白头。 此是世问凡银，岂堪为药。 又若用铅及水银，固不可也，去道远矣，深宜省之。 又别一说，衔银者非真也。 又一说，铅衔银者非真也。 又一说，铅中真铅也。 又一说，嘉州铅能制水银，可使立乾。 然夫修丹之士，须拣名山良地，若非名山良地，即有魔邪等居，不福人为善，鬼神多使人意坏也。 精择同志，只可与三两人，多恐心志不同，损药累功，克取良时吉日，须依禁忌，出在《三洞要筹宝经》中。 外弃尘事，内绝邪想，调治性情，使神气安和，不得令有烦劳。 忌食荤血，见尸冢阴秽，不与女人同食，饥饱喜怒，意思不精，食须面午，卧须首午，七日一浴，不与外人交往邪谈，阴精不伏也。 修药发炉之日，乃修一状，具乡里名氏年月生日名位，讫云：某浊俗小人，愿续余生，愿结正丹。 今备药君臣，求告灵君，求启灵神太一帝君，四方大神，降临菲薄。 请四方神，从午起，各呼其名质色，依本方存神，叩齿二十四遍。 呎日：我结灵丹，灵君降坛。 主覆药君，不散飞天。 又呎曰：我结灵丹，灵神降坛。 保固药神，不失於泉。 心呎之毕，任意启告。 如得药服者，须修行仁义礼智，兼外其身心，择境而居，远其尸秽。 死生之秽，触犯灵药，切在忌之。 凡得灵药，不可令人知见，多鬼亦然也。 古锦袋盛药，须丸数奇，不得偶双，即走失。 古锦去邪也。 金花还丹方 铅八两　水银八两 右二物相和，以左味细研令相入。 以甘土埚泥包裹为球，令乾，入缭炉，用以灰拥其下，着文火养六十日出之。 又以左味重细研，依前入球，又火养六十日。 日满后，即每十日一度，添二两银。 取真好者，错为末，细研令相入。 都八度添，计用八十日，都成二斤药。 如本药是半斤，每度添一两，都成一斤药○伏如希汞，渐有神用也。 又入火养一百六十日，药成，都三百六十日火，一周气足也。 一刀圭可乾一斤水银。 如日服一粒，寿逾万劫。 有歌二首云：寻山河碌碌。 又：白汞生朱砂，黑铅为黄丹。 黄花丹阳方 砒黄性以雄黄略同，大温，有毒，生澧州山谷。 一名熏黄。 久与铅同处，其色变黑如铁。 但金石之中，有含铅气物，与青碌之辈，总不可相近，宜别贮之。 又久见风，亦损颜色。 雄黄亦然。 切畏铅。 若同箱筐，不可久也。 定如铁色，砒黄性与丹阳相宜。

「Though there are written records, all merely point to the correspondence of yin and yang by name.

The sages conceal this gate in common secrecy—
what is truly written is not recorded,
what is recorded is not truly written.
If one relies on cleverness and intelligence,
follows the texts while neglecting their essence,
and speculates with one’s own interpretations,
the more intricate the reasoning,
the farther one strays from the truth.
How then could one hope to glimpse
the mysteries of *Huángyá Jīnshuǐ* (黄芽金水, *Golden Seed and Water of the Yellow*),[^1]
whether through orthodox or heterodox paths?

The key lies in fire refinement and receiving the **qi**.
If a single phase is insufficient,
then the result is no better than worthless clay.
And yet, the journey is still long—
one must first seek a worthy teacher,
hear the teachings with awakened insight,
and also discern the appropriate methods,
cultivating wisdom and singular focus.
Only through extraordinary devotion
can one achieve extraordinary results.
Through prolonged diligence and suffering,
one may finally attain success.
Otherwise, one will merely chase empty reputations,
leaving no trace,
or perhaps encounter a divine adept who grants it.
Beyond this, all efforts are but futile labor—
better to indulge in fine wine and pure silk instead.

I am no pioneer of this knowledge,
but a humble servant to the learned,
having spent years in bitter toil,
listening attentively to these truths.

The *Kǎnlǐ* (坎卦, *Water Hexagram*) and *Lǐqǔ* (离卦, *Fire Hexagram*)
are the foundations of the elixir.

*Cinnabar* (朱砂, *Zhūshā*) belongs to the Southern Fire position,
yet it inherently contains *mercury* (水银, *shuǐyín*).
*Black lead* (黑铅, *hēiqiān*) is of the Northern Water,
yet it inherently contains *silver* (银, *yín*).

Silver is the essence within lead,
and mercury is the treasure within cinnabar.
Once the essence and treasure are distinguished,
each returns to its original root—
thus, they are named *Qīnglóng* (青龙, *Green Dragon*) and *Báihǔ* (白虎, *White Tiger*).
The scripture says:
*"Use lead, yet not lead; its meaning is clear."*
Based on this, *white mercury* (白银, *báiyín*) is the supreme essence of lead,
and *mercury* (水银, *shuǐyín*) is the true treasure of cinnabar.
If one were to use silver and mercury as elixir ingredients,
there would be no proper principle to follow.
Thus, the scripture states:
*"If seeking silver within lead,
one’s hair will turn white before graying."*
This refers to ordinary silver in the world—
how could it suffice as a medicinal?

Again, if one uses lead and mercury,
it is utterly impractical—
far from the Dao.
This must be carefully reconsidered.

Another doctrine claims:
*"The one that holds mercury is not genuine."*
Another states:
*"Lead that holds mercury is not genuine."*
Yet another asserts:
*"Within lead, there is true lead."*
And another says:
*"Lead from Jiāzhōu (嘉州) can subdue mercury,
making it stand firm and dry."*

But truly, those who practice the elixir
must select renowned mountains and auspicious lands.
If not, malevolent spirits may dwell there,
unwilling to bless the virtuous,
often causing practitioners’ intentions to falter.
The selection of like-minded companions
should be limited to three or two at most—
too many may lead to discord in heart and mind,
damaging the elixir and wasting effort.
One must also choose favorable times and auspicious days,
observing prohibitions as outlined in
*The Essentials of the Three Caverns* (《三洞要筹宝经》).

Externally, one must abandon worldly dust,
internally, extinguish impure thoughts.
Regulate and harmonize one’s disposition,
so that spirit and **qi** remain tranquil—
no agitation or labor should be permitted.
Avoid consuming meat or blood,
viewing corpses or filth,
sharing meals with women,
or allowing hunger, satiety, joy, or anger
to cloud one’s clarity.
Meals must be taken at noon,
sleep must begin with the head facing south,
and one must bathe every seven days.
Avoid fraternizing with outsiders or engaging in profane discussions—
otherwise, the vital essence will not be preserved.

On the day of refining the elixir,
one must prepare a single declaration,
recording one’s native place, surname, age,
month, day, and birth hour,
concluding thus:
*"I, a vulgar man of [place],
desire to extend my remaining life,
and to forge the true elixir.
Now, having prepared the master and minister ingredients,
I beseech the Spirit Lord,
I beseech the Spirit God, the Sovereign of Supreme Unity,
and the Four Directions’ Great Deities,
to descend upon this humble offering.

I invite the Four Directions’ Gods,
beginning from the hour of noon,
each calling their own name, quality, and hue,
conforming to their original essence,
reciting twenty-four times with clenched teeth.
I chant:
*'I forge the spirit elixir,
the Spirit Lord descends to the altar.
Master of the Elixir Lord,
do not scatter and fly to the heavens.'*

Again, I chant:
*'I forge the spirit elixir,
the Spirit God descends to the altar.
Preserver of the Elixir Spirit,
do not be lost in the depths.'*
Having finished the heart-chanted verses,
one may freely express their intentions.

For those who obtain and ingest the elixir,
they must practice benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom,
and also purify their body and mind,
choosing a suitable dwelling,
avoiding filth and decay.
The impurities of life and death,
if encountered, will defile the spirit elixir—
this must be strictly avoided.

The elixir, once obtained,
must not be revealed to others—
even spirits cannot endure it.

In ancient times, elixirs were stored in brocade pouches,
and the pills must be an odd number—
never even, lest they vanish.
The brocade repels malevolence.

---
**Golden Flower Reversion Elixir Method** (金花还丹方):
*Black lead* (铅, *qiān*) – 8 *liǎng* (两)
*Mercury* (水银, *shuǐyín*) – 8 *liǎng* (两)

Take these two substances and blend them,
then finely grind the following [ingredients] together,
until they fully amalgamate.

Wrap them in crucible clay,
forming a ball,
and dry it.
Place it in a retort furnace,
supporting it with ash below,
and refine with gentle fire for sixty days.
Remove it.

Once more, finely grind the following [ingredients],
and wrap them into a ball as before,
refining with fire for another sixty days.
When the days are complete,
every ten days, add two *liǎng* (两) of silver.
Take only the purest silver,
crush it into powder,
and grind it finely until fully amalgamate.

After eight additions,
totaling eighty days,
the elixir will be one *jīn* (斤).
If the original elixir was half a *jīn*,
add one *liǎng* (两) each time,
totaling one *jīn* of elixir.
[Refine] as if using *mercury* (汞, *xīyīng*),[^2]
gradually manifesting its divine efficacy.

Refine it further in fire for one hundred and sixty days,
until the elixir is complete—
a total of three hundred and sixty days of fire,
fulfilling the cycle of the year’s **qi**.

A single *guī* (圭, *scepter-shaped pill*) can dry one *jīn* of mercury.
If taken daily as one pill,
one’s lifespan will exceed countless eons.

Two verses sing:
*"Wander the mountains and rivers in vain,
endless toil and strife."*
*"White mercury generates cinnabar,
black lead becomes yellow elixir."*

---
**Yellow Flower Elixir Method of the Sun** (黄花丹阳方):

*Orpiment* (砒黄, *pīhuáng*) shares traits with *realgar* (雄黄, *xiónghuáng*),[^3]
is of a great warmth,
and contains poison.
It grows in the valleys of Lìzhōu (澧州).
Another name for it is *Xūnhuáng* (熏黄, *Fragrant Yellow*).

When kept long with lead,
its color turns black like iron.
But among metals and minerals,
those containing lead’s **qi**—
like orpiment and its kin—
must never be stored nearby,
and should be kept separately.

If exposed to wind for too long,
it will also lose its luster.
Realgar behaves similarly.
They both fear lead.
If kept together in a box or basket,
it cannot be stored for long.

When its hue is fixed like iron,
orpiment’s nature aligns well with the elixir of the Sun.
---」

chunks.original_text: 右经云：铜得伏砒，柔弱自低。 铜得伏雌，久类帝男。 雄黄也。 是四黄雌雄硫砒也正数。 有人飞砂一味，至九九八十一转成丹。 取一丸投亡者口中，立活。 固知砒力不可思议。 既类雄黄，亦应胜五兵，杀蛇虺。 服饵皆飞入人脑，长生不死，理然也。 比见王涣司业，将雄黄和汞，於铁铛子中研不停手，下着文火，不用火玲研亦得。 一日内结成砂子，伏火者得如皂荚子大，成上色黄金。 如无雄黄，用上色澧州砒黄代用亦得。 其力不相弱，是灵药也。 一说雄为君，雌为臣，流为使，砒为将。 按《本草》雄黄生武都，得铜可作金。 砒亦类之。 础黄生数处，并不及澧州者。 雄黄色如鸡冠，向日通红，紧细润腻，实而不硬，有氤氲香气，不并昆黄，就中红赤中带黄色，故曰雄黄。 任以水洗，待乾，一炊久，当生黄衣。 不然以口含之，亦得，并有黄衣上。
chunks.translated_text:
**Further Scriptures Say:**
*Copper* (铜) with *suppressed realgar* (伏雄) becomes soft and weak, self-humbling.
*Copper* with *suppressed cinnabar* (伏雌) grows to resemble the *Celestial Male* (帝男) over time.

*Realgar* (雄黄) also holds this truth.
These four—*realgar* (雄), *cinnabar* (雌), *sulfur* (硫), and *orpiment* (砒)—
are the true count of *male* and *female* yellows.

Some say: *"Flying Sand"* (飞砂) as a single substance,
after ninety-nine revolutions (至九九八十一转),
becomes an elixir.
Taking one pill and placing it in the mouth of the deceased,
they revive instantly.
Indeed, the power of *orpiment* is beyond comprehension.

Since it resembles *realgar*,
it should also overcome the *Five Armies* (五兵),
slaying serpents and *huī* (虺).
When ingested as a medicine,
it ascends to the brain,
granting eternal life and immortality—
this is the natural order.

Recently, I observed Master Wang Huàn (王涣) overseeing affairs,
as he mixed *realgar* (雄黄) and *mercury* (汞),
grinding them tirelessly in an iron mortar (铁铛子).
He applied gentle *Wén* fire (文火),
without using a *fire polisher* (火玲).
Yet still, the transformation succeeded:
Within a day, it congealed into sand,
and the *suppressed fire* (伏火) yielded grains as large as *soapnut* (皂荚子),
shining like pure gold.

If *realgar* is unavailable,
use *high-grade Lìzhōu orpiment* (上色澧州砒黄) as a substitute—
its efficacy is no weaker.
This is a *spiritual medicine* (灵药).

Another account states:
*Realgar* (雄) as the sovereign,
*cinnabar* (雌) as the minister,
*sulfur* (流) as the messenger,
and *orpiment* (砒) as the general.

According to the *Bencǎo* (本草, *Compendium of Materia Medica*),
*realgar* grows in *Wǔdū* (武都),
and when combined with copper, it transmutes into gold.
*Orpiment* behaves similarly.
*Jìhuáng* (础黄) appears in many places,
but none compare to that of *Lìzhōu*.

*Realgar* bears a hue like a *rooster’s comb* (鸡冠),
glowing red when exposed to sunlight,
compact yet smooth, soft yet firm,
with a lingering, fragrant vapor.
It does not blend with *Kūn* yellow (昆黄),
but its core is a deep red,
tinged with yellow—
thus it is called *realgar*.

Even if washed with water,
once dried and heated for a single cycle (一炊),
it will produce *yellow coating* (黄衣).
If that fails,
simply holding it in the mouth will suffice—
it will still yield *yellow coating* (黄衣).

chunks.original_text: 毒蛇见之，立死。 此是真者。 漏天南隽州亦有，并不如武都者。 砒黄虽次雄黄，并不作前件状样，色黄亦鲜明，棱角生硬，有皇气，通红易破者良也。 其丹阳之道，甚难举世。 学者虽多，明晓者殊少。 且丹阳质性难柔，外晕形赤，内怀青黑，铁禀南方阴丁之精，结而成形，故赤。 铜禀束方乙阴之气，结而成魄，故青。 银禀西方卒阴之神，结而为质，故白。 铅锡俱禀北方壬癸之气，故黑。 金禀中宫阴已之魄，故黄也。 甚难制治。 一说晕是铜，铜是晕。 晕尽铜尽，铜尽晕尽，无若非巧能制合。 子母合体，知其性情，刚柔分等。 即须以伏火铅汞，上丹上药，然变其质。 又五金入土，埋之千岁，唯金与银，不变其质余，并化成灰土。 余今此方，抽化质了，入火不变，入土不销，便能翻制，造化阴阳，岂容易哉。 若骨分仙材，宿命素定，早逢灵诀，点制刀圭。 一两二十四铢，六粟为一刀圭。 或揩涂药於埚挺上，入火烧炙，便成真宝。 此是神仙上品，非造次而能知。 若素非此流，必须精详物理，广博方书，辨别君臣，识其忌讳。 其药有刚柔，有制有伏，拒火与伏火，别生用与熟用殊，亦有兼假铅汞，独用四黄。 神仙流教，万法千方，并皆隐闭，悉不明文。 纵传方书，是迷迷相授，后学之士，多无所成。 亦是贤者不苦精研，不得学圣之意，功用微浅。 兼有埚炉钳鞘不全明晓，烧投点化，不究精微，炎黑火中，须臾则过，凭何见其成功。 夫用熟药稍易，生药甚难。 今此一方，悉用生药，遣变质成真，切在销停，及抽换投拔，节候为妙，亦解铅汞傍通。 经云：器内方径一寸，可受水银一斤。 又准筹数，金方一寸，重一斤。 银方一寸，重十四两。 铅锡重九两半，铁重六两，玉重九两，一本云玉重十两。 白石重三两，土重二两。 物各禀气自然之性。 汞者禀五阳神之灵精，不可比校。 其余高下悬殊，唯熟铜与银斤两相类，形质细腻，柔软颇敌。 徐有晕一色，余并相似，实可通变。 且《五金诀》云：雄黄功能变铁，雌黄功能变锡，砒黄功能变铜，硫黄功能变银化汞。 四黄功亦能反铁为铜，反铜为银，反银为金，如谷作米，是天地之中，自然之道。 磁石引针，琥珀拾芥，岂是他灵。 又经云：但有道术士，能制治方便，巧使相入，亦可为宝。 余今化铁为铜，用砒成银，理无二也。 方具如左。 点丹阳方 砒黄三十两澧州者，无夹石，赤如鹦冠，向日通红者良。 诸处者力次之。 雌黄八两状如金叶子者佳。 若黄软如石，不堪。 又有夹雄黄者，虽如，此方不用。 胡同律二两用石律如姜石状，投酽醋中，良久沸不定如。 盐二两取花炒令变色。 右件四味，共四十二两。 先取砒如小枣大，其碎末，别收秤取三十两，纳铁铛中。 准药一斤，用生胡麻油五升，缓火煮之，令垒垒小沸，不得火猛。 如此九日九夜止，若油稠强，即宜抽去之，更添新油，日足讫，便盛於帛袋中，纳饭中，满饭着砂绢袋，於砂中心蒸之七日，油腻并入砂中，即自鲜赤。 本经云：帝男帝女，帝女雌黄必须如此修理。 一且去毒。 毒去能入五金。 二又得霜倍多。 又如无上色好，用次者，虑有顽石，但倒抽一遍，取精者用，亦妙。 其澧州砒有力，诸处者次。 雌黄准砒例修理，但煮时不得同在一器内，余并一也。

When a venomous serpent sees it, it dies instantly.
This is the true substance.

*Realgar* also grows in *Jiānyáng* (隽州) of *Lìngnán* (岭南),
but none compare to that of *Wǔdū*.

*Orpiment* (砒黄), though inferior to *realgar*,
does not exhibit the same transformations.
Its yellow hue is bright and clear,
its edges sharp and rigid,
with a lingering *imperial qi* (皇气),
and the redder and more easily shattered, the better.

The Dao/Way of *Dānyáng* (丹阳) is most difficult to grasp in this world.
Though many study it, few truly comprehend.

Moreover, the nature of *Dānyáng* is hard to soften—
its outer radiance (晕) is red,
its inner core is green and black.
Iron absorbs the *Yīn-Dīng* (阴丁) *qi* of the southern lands,
congealing into form, hence its red.
Copper absorbs the *Yī-Jīn* (乙阴) *qi* of the east,
congealing into essence, hence its green.
Silver absorbs the *Zǔ-Yīn* (卒阴) spirit of the west,
congealing into substance, hence its white.
Lead and tin both absorb the *Rén-Gùì* (壬癸) *qi* of the north,
hence their black.
Gold absorbs the *Yī-Jǐ* (阴已) essence of the central realm,
hence its yellow.
It is most difficult to refine and govern.

Some say: *Radiance* (晕) is copper, copper is *radiance*.
When one is exhausted, the other is exhausted—
no one but a skilled artisan can harmonize them.

The *child-mother* (子母) alchemy unites their natures,
distinguishing between firm and yielding.
Then one must use *hidden-fire lead* (伏火铅) and *mercury* (汞),
upper *Dānyáng* elixir and upper *Yào* (药),
to transmute their essence.

Again, the five metals buried underground for a thousand years,
only gold and silver retain their original essence—
the rest all turn to ash.

This method of mine has extracted and refined their essence,
unaltered by fire or decayed by earth,
making them capable of transformation—
crafting *Yīn-Yáng* (阴阳), how could this be easy?

If one’s bones are the *immortal materials* (仙材),
and one’s fate predestined by the *hosting of past lives* (宿命),
then early encountering the *divine secret* (灵诀),
and refining with the *sacred blade* (刀圭)—
one *liǎng* (两) weighs twenty-four *zhǔ* (铢),
and six *sù* (粟) make one *Dāogùi* (刀圭).

Or, one may scrape and apply the *elixir* (药) onto a crucible’s rod (埚挺),
insert it into the flames,
and it will become true treasure.

This is the supreme alchemy of the *Immortal Dao* (神仙),
not easily known by those who act hastily.

If one is not of this tradition,
one must meticulously study the principles of substances,
consult widely among alchemical texts,
discern the hierarchy of *master-servant* (君臣),
and know their prohibitions.

Its *Yào* (药) has firm and yielding qualities,
methods of suppression and concealment,
repelling fire and hidden fire,
distinct uses when raw and when refined—
sometimes employing lead and mercury together,
sometimes using only the four *huáng* (黄).

The teachings of the *Immortal Dao* (神仙流) encompass myriad methods and countless formulas,
all concealed and never fully revealed.
Even if alchemical texts are passed down,
they are transmitted in confusion,
and most later scholars achieve nothing.

This is because the wise do not diligently refine their understanding,
nor grasp the *saintly intent* (圣意).
Their applications are shallow and ineffective.

They also lack full mastery of crucibles, furnaces, tongs, and sheaths,
and do not probe the subtleties of burning, casting, and refining.
In the furnace’s flames, they rush past the critical moment—
how could they witness success?

Using refined *Yào* (药) is somewhat easier,
but raw *Yào* is far more difficult.
This method employs only raw *Yào*,
transmuting their essence into truth,
depending on precise timing—
stopping and starting, extracting and inserting—
the seasons are key,
and it also resolves the auxiliary lead and mercury.

The *Classics* state:
*A vessel with an internal diameter of one inch*
can hold *mercury* of one *jīn* (斤).
Again, by measure:
*A gold cube of one inch*
weighs one *jīn*,
*a silver cube of one inch*
weighs fourteen *liǎng* (两).
*Lead and tin cubes of one inch*
weigh nine *liǎng* (两) and a half,
*iron cubes of one inch*
weigh six *liǎng*,
*jade cubes of one inch*
weigh nine *liǎng* (一本云玉重十两).
*White stone cubes of one inch*
weigh three *liǎng*,
*earth cubes of one inch*
weigh two *liǎng*.
Each substance naturally absorbs its own *qi*.

*Mercury* absorbs the *five heavenly spirits* (五阳神) of the most refined essence,
unmatched in comparison.
The rest vary greatly—
only refined copper and silver are somewhat similar in weight,
their forms soft and yielding, nearly equal in flexibility.

*Xu* (徐) has a single *radiance* (晕) hue,
while the others resemble one another—
indeed, they can all be transmuted.

Moreover, the *Five Metals Secret* (《五金诀》) states:
*The power of realgar* can transmute iron,
*the power of orpiment* (雌黄) can transmute tin,
*the power of orpiment* (砒黄) can transmute copper,
*sulfur* (硫黄) can transmute silver into mercury.
The four *huáng* (黄) can also reverse iron into copper,
reverse copper into silver,
reverse silver into gold—
like grain turning into rice,
this is the natural Dao/Way of heaven and earth.

Magnetite attracts needles,
amber picks up dust—
how could these be other spirits?

Again, the *Classics* say:
*Only those who master the Dao/Way and its techniques*
can refine and govern with ease,
skillfully combining them,
and thus create true treasure.

This method of mine transmutes iron into copper,
and orpiment into silver—
the principle is identical.

The formula is as follows:

**Refining *Dānyáng* (丹阳) Method**
Thirty *liǎng* (两) of *orpiment* (砒黄) from *Lìzhōu*,
free of mixed stones,
as red as a *parrot’s crest* (鹦冠),
and glowing brightest in sunlight—
this is the finest.
*Orpiment* from other regions is inferior.

Eight *liǎng* of *orpiment* (雌黄) in the form of gold leaves—
the best.
If it is yellow and soft like stone, it is unfit.
If it contains mixed *realgar*, even if similar,
this method does not use it.

Two *liǎng* of *Hútóng* (胡同) *lǜ* (律), using stone *lǜ* resembling ginger root in form,
steeped in strong vinegar until it boils without settling.

Two *liǎng* of salt, roasted with *huā* (花) until its color changes.

These four ingredients total forty-two *liǎng*.

First, take *orpiment* the size of small dates,
grind it finely,
and weigh precisely thirty *liǎng*.
Place it in an iron pan (铁铛).
For every *jīn* of *Yào* (药),
use five *shāng* (升) of raw sesame oil,
and simmer it gently over low fire,
allowing it to bubble softly—
do not let the flames rage fiercely.

Do this for nine days and nine nights.
If the oil becomes too thick,
draw it off and replace it with fresh oil,
until the nine days are complete.
Then transfer it into a silk pouch,
and place it within a meal,
ensuring the pouch is fully buried in the grain.
Steam it in the center of the rice for seven days—
the oil’s grease will seep into the sand,
and the *orpiment* will become fresh and crimson.

The *Classics* state:
*Imperial Male* (帝男) and *Imperial Female* (帝女),
*Imperial Female* (雌黄) *orpiment* must be refined thus—
first, to remove its toxicity.
When the toxicity is gone, it can be combined with the five metals.
Second, it yields *frost* (霜) in abundance.

If the *orpiment* is of the highest quality,
use the inferior—
worried that it may contain stubborn stones—
simply draw off the oil once,
and use the purified residue—
this is also excellent.

*Orpiment* from *Lìzhōu* is the most potent,
while that from other regions is lesser.
*Orpiment* (雌黄) should be refined like *Dānyáng*,
but during cooking, it must not share the same vessel as the others.
The rest follows the same principle.

*Realgar* bears a hue like a *rooster’s comb* (鸡冠),
glowing red when exposed to sunlight,
compact yet smooth, soft yet firm,
with a lingering, fragrant vapor.
It does not blend with *Kūn* yellow (昆黄),

chunks.original_text: 其性甚能柔物，与砒同力成功。 金陵子曰：蒸时同在砂饭内，但相去远，亦无妨碍。 按《铅锡经》云：朱砂三分，雄黄一分，右合研置铜钵内，着酽醋，细细添之汤上，煮醋尽，更添，如是三伏时令乾。 出之，入油铛中，缓火煮令鱼眼沸，两伏时出飞取精，大佳。 若不飞者，即以鸡子白和泥瓷器，盛密盖砂饭中，蒸之一周时出，用大佳。 如不者，和赤盐，点铜成黄，余并在本经中。 胡同律甚难得真者。 一说独将生用，点铜得白金。 但以浆水於瓷器中煮，续添令尽五升，即可用能去黑晕。 一本：不煮生用亦得。 盐用花炒令黄，急用，不待煮蒸，亦得。 末盐，不如颗盐，颗盐不如井盥，井盐不如池盐。 然取前三味同梼，岩砂罗过令匀，以宾投醋中待消，用拌前药令湿，日中暴乾，熟和搅揩矮令相得。 次又拌一遍，日暴，令浥浥，便将入鼎。 一说以桑灰汁拌药。 如用醋，恐损铜。 不知如何，未详。 其药分作两鼎。 每一鼎只可二十余两为准，多少得所也。 以两匙头石灰，和前件拌了药，同拌令匀。 即着石灰藉底，令厚一分已下，按令实。 便下前件药末於鼎内，如锹背装，四面不用苦着炉，微着匙按，即且少着两匙覆上，便以手摩掌药面破，令与石灰相入，以匙微微按，令却如锹形。 更以石灰覆厚二分。 已上微按令得所，即以少水洒上面，至散湿，遂以盆子盖之。 其盆子稍高，於常者一尺五寸。 文武火烧两伏时，比常飞霜文武火，稍文为度。 候寒开之，其霜当总在炉面上已卧讫，下并无脚，作白色，柔软细润可爱，揩臂如粉。 其霜在炉内凝结，为一脾，约厚一寸余，纹理如束丝，不飞上盆子。 余故号日外炉霜。 别有半两，已来在盆子上，颜色不同，当别收，任将别用。 又如有火候失飞不尽者，亦准前任重飞。 其迹炉霜，甚能柔物，不并常霜脆硬。 比见诸法中飞一遍白霜，少用即无力，多用物即硬，是为大病。 此霜任意多用，物终不硬，与诸霜不同，殊於常也。 其砒但将好者成倒抽了，若待用油煮及蒸，便将飞霜用亦得。 又孔氏商量亦云：用一遍白霜，佳。 此两诀亦甚符会。 又成卧炉霜后，取前件霜，每二两点一斤。 已上并用大斤大两。 经修理了者丹阳，可分作两埚，每埚只可着八两，多少为得所乍可。 已下不可过多，又不可少，少则埚中乾。 每一两药，分为六丸。 每一度相续点三丸，待金汁如水，以物直刺到埚底，待入尽，即以炭搅之，更鼓三二十下，又投药。 如此遍遍相似，即泻入华池中，令散作珠子，急用柳枝搅令碎，不作珠子，亦得。 又依前点三丸，亦投入池中，看色白。 未若所点药，不须将火烧，却药其物，即不白。 更须重点一遍，以白为度。 生药点埚甚难，所投点大，须在意玲热相冲，金汁进出埚。 遍遍如此，折损殊多，其埚稍宜深作。 若能使金汁如水点者，为上。 龙虎还丹诀卷上竟 龙虎还丹诀卷下 金陵子述

Its nature is exceedingly capable of softening substances, its efficacy matching that of *orpiment* in achieving results.

The *Jīnlíngzi* says: When steaming, even if placed together within the sand and rice, so long as they are kept apart, there will be no obstruction.

According to the *Lead and Tin Classic* (《铅锡经》):
Take three parts *cinnabar* (朱砂) and one part *realgar* (雄黄), grind them together and place in a copper basin. Add strong vinegar gradually while simmering over boiling water until the vinegar is exhausted, then replenish it. Repeat this process during the three *dog days* (三伏) until dry.

Remove it and place in an oil wok, cooking over slow fire until the oil bubbles like fish eyes (鱼眼沸). After two *dog days*, extract the flying essence—this is excellent.

If it does not fly, mix with egg white and clay in a sealed earthenware vessel, place in a sand-rice bag, and steam for one *watch* (周时). This is also excellent.

If not, mix with red salt and apply to copper to produce gold. The rest follows the original text.

*Hu Tóng Lǜ*’s true method is difficult to obtain.

One method says: Use it raw alone, applying to copper to produce white gold.

But if boiled in a porcelain vessel with water, continuously adding until five *sheng* (升) are used, it can remove black stains.

One version says: Do not boil—use it raw, and it will still work.

Salt should be stir-fried until yellow. If used urgently, without boiling or steaming, it will still suffice.

Powdered salt is inferior to grain salt, grain salt to well-washed salt, and well-washed salt to pond salt.

However, take the three substances first, sift them through *yánshā* (岩砂), and mix evenly. Add them to vinegar to dissolve, then stir into the previous medicine until moist. Dry in the sun, then knead thoroughly until well-amalgamated.

Repeat the mixing once more, dry in the sun until slightly damp, then place in the crucible.

One method says to mix with mulberry ash juice instead. If using vinegar, fear is that it may damage the copper. The method is unclear.

Divide the medicine into two crucibles. Each crucible should hold no more than about twenty *liang* (两)—this is the proper measure.

Take two spoonfuls of lime, mix with the previous medicine, and blend evenly. Spread lime thickly at the bottom of the crucible—at least one *fen* (分) deep—then press the mixture in firmly.

Place the previous powdered medicine inside, shaping it like the back of a hoe, without pressing hard against the furnace walls. Use a spoon to gently press, then cover lightly with two spoonfuls. Break the surface with the palm to let it merge with the lime, pressing lightly with the spoon until it resembles a hoe shape again.

Cover with an additional two *fen* of lime. Press gently to settle, then sprinkle a little water on top until it is just damp. Cover with a basin—slightly taller than the usual one and fifteen *cun* (寸) high.

Burn with alternating gentle and strong fires for two *dog days*. Compared to the usual flying frost method, the fire should be slightly gentler.

When cool, open it—the frost should have settled entirely on the furnace surface, with none remaining at the bottom. It will be white, soft, fine, and smooth, like powder when rubbed on the arm.

The frost that congeals inside the furnace forms a single mass, about one *cun* thick, with striations like bundled silk. It does not fly up into the basin. This is called *external furnace frost* (外炉霜).

Separately, there will be about half a *liang* that has flown onto the basin, differing in color—collect this separately for other uses.

If the fire is misjudged and the frost does not fully fly, repeat the process as before.

This *external furnace frost* is exceptionally effective at softening substances, unlike the brittle hardness of ordinary frost.

Other methods mention flying white frost once, which loses efficacy if used sparingly and causes hardness if overused—this is a major flaw. This frost, however, can be used in any quantity without causing hardness, differing fundamentally from others.

As for *orpiment*, only the best should be used after reverse extraction. If boiled in oil or steamed, the flying frost can also be applied.

Furthermore, *Kǒng Shì*’s calculations also state: Using white frost once is ideal. These two methods are highly consistent.

After producing the *coiled furnace frost* (卧炉霜), take the previous frost, applying two *liang* per *jin* (斤).

All measurements should use large *jin* and *liang*.

After refining *Dānyáng* (丹阳) as per the text, divide it into two crucibles, each holding only eight *liang*—neither too much nor too little, for excess or deficiency will cause drying.

For every *liang* of medicine, form six pills. For each application, insert three pills, waiting until the gold liquid flows like water. Pierce the crucible to the bottom with an object, then let it drain completely. Stir with charcoal twenty to thirty times, then add more medicine.

Repeat this process similarly, pouring the mixture into a *Huá Píng* (华池) to disperse as pearls. If used urgently, break them with willow branches—even if they do not form pearls, it is acceptable.

Again, insert three pills as before, adding them to the *Huá Píng* until the color turns white.

Unlike the applied medicine, this does not require heating—simply apply it to the substance, and it will whiten. A second application is needed to ensure full whitening.

Applying raw medicine to a crucible is difficult; the dosage must be precise, ensuring the heat and medicine interact properly, with the gold liquid entering and exiting the crucible smoothly.

Repeat this process carefully, as losses will be significant. The crucible should be slightly deeper.

If the gold liquid can be made to flow like water upon application, this is the superior method.

*End of Volume One of the Dragon-Tiger Elixir Secrets*
*Volume Two of the Dragon-Tiger Elixir Secrets*
*Narrated by Jīnlíngzi*

chunks.original_text: 按仙经有黄银、白金、红银者，是上药所致。 一名红金，一名红鲜金。 又有离己金，又有青金，又有宝金，亦有丹砂四黄染汞银而成，又有黄花银。 且汞银万化，亦本含此染，若兼染色者，或黄赤红紫，盖随药变。 亦有状如血裹，看如地黄根。 亦有如日色者，似黄不黄，似赤不赤，似红不红，似紫不紫。 盖是神仙上药，非凡情而能测别，其方诀今所载矣。 伏丹砂为红银，以水银和青绿、石胆及诸药矾第，纳铁器中，煮结而成者，状如丹阳，体并有晕。 今亦可使其无晕。 又此门外甚有深玄，比见道者一斤制得一斤，一两制得一两。 亦有投煮不逾时，便成银体。 亦有转相钩制，亦有结出便无晕者，亦有取结银为器，用本色药结者，不用铁器者。 亦有只先取一两水银，结成砂子，以瓷碗地上合之，须臾便硬，即以铁臼梼，加投一两汞，还依前以碗合，须臾即硬。 又梼，又加汞二两，依前制四两，又合硬。 如此一倍倍加，可增至百斤，当日而成，凡数十般法药。 至道玄远，妙理难究。 盖随所遇，非造次而得窥。

According to the Daoist scriptures, there are *huáng yín* (yellow silver), *bái jīn* (white gold), and *hóng yín* (red silver)—these are the products of the highest elixirs. There is also *lí jǐ jīn* (separated self-gold), *qīng jīn* (blue gold), and *bǎo jīn* (treasure gold), as well as *dān shā sì huáng* (cinnabar’s four yellows) staining mercury-silver, and *huáng huā yín* (yellow-flowered silver).

Moreover, mercury-silver undergoes myriad transformations, inherently containing these stains. If further dyed, it may turn yellow, red, purple, or crimson—its hue shifts with the alchemical agent.

Some even craft silver vessels from the refined silver itself, using unadulterated elixirs and forgoing iron tools.

Another method begins with one *liǎng* of mercury, solidified into grains. A porcelain bowl is placed on the ground, and the grains are pressed together—within moments, they harden. chunks.original_text: 又饶信等州银山有矿，质状一如光明砂，其色红紫，鲜明可爱，堪入炉用，鼓铸便成白银，一斤可得十四五两，甚难遇。 今代稀有古经方中，并不见载，遇未详也。 或疑是银之红矿，其红银以青绿及石胆，俗呼为胆子等，所结鼓得四五两，或六七两，色如丹阳者。 且汞和青绿及胆子诸矾等，於铁器中煮结而成。 每一斤汞砂鼓铸了，只得四两红银，此并是铁，非水银也。 或云胆子、青绿等，并是铜苗，其中有铜，故水银钩得，切恐非也，并不干药事。 所得四两已来者，并是水银钩得铁而致，非关汞药。 余曾各秤诸色，分明记录，一度煮结铛，欠五两红银，只得四两半，故都是铁，不虚也，只为证据。 又凡结砂子，若器中绝满，火稍武，其汞进走，细如针锋，不可得觉。 用心森者，失总不知。 又用药淘研，稍若亦化，似尘如灰，随药水而去，不知头头欠折，将为所欠，汞尽为红银也。 令后来学人，见无所成，悉皆抛弃，亦相承皆为水银，却非也。 又有一本，一斤水银也，其红银即是铁，铁本有晕，又加青绿等染来，固合有晕，亦难修治，与铜何殊。 今时辈药道中人，为难制治，亦轻此道。 余今年深学苦，辄议此门，殊可佳尚。 且水银钩铁，皆是铁中精华。 若言汞住，去道则远矣。 若以铁中而求，是上上精华铁也。 用将铸镜，是上色铁镜。 所见铸得者，甚明彻冯结，与常镜殊，是知是铁中精华也。 又何以知之。 且水银至灵，入杂恶类。 今与汞俱是，盖是五金精华。 又看结了器中，又侵削铁器面，铁面上分毫无损。 异日因药力，被汞遥吸出铁精华，便与汞合体，理实灵异。 今将以为镜，是不可思议之物。 今世人只尚此为水银，殊不解重其铁也。 余自恨艺浅功微，不知黄帝之术，傥加以金膏雄黄，法象铸成，昭一其鹦鹉，亦不彼於当时。 今世若将为镜，是上上铁镜，太原古者不如亦无比。 若为铜，亦是上色铁化为铜也。 今世人只呼为红银，见有晕，轻易如熟铜之流，不知是五金精也。 余以水银为红银，红银亦与为铜为铁，作镜化铜为银。 方诀既臻，理无惑也。 伏丹砂成红银法 右以朱砂一斤，上色者不必颗粒成，但光明砂红色者佳。 纳猜脂中，和水煮三十五日，入蜜水中，煮十五日。 入华池，七日。 将向甘土埚中镕铅汁，泻入埚中，下前朱砂，其朱砂以矾泥裹之，投入埚中，直令刺到底，七日当伏火。 入赤土、黄矾、硵砂出色，立成红银矣，亦号曰红金。 外白内隐隐作红色，光鲜可爱。 又方 右取水银，以石硫黄烧成砂，未曾经研淘者。 取砂子一斤，厅打碎，以两重绢袋盛，外更以竹疏袋重成。 即以桑灰淋赤乌左味，淋亦得汁。 中纳黄丹一斤，悬前件袋，於汁中，勿遣着底。 以文火如鱼眼，煮七日当伏火。 后入埚鼓，并成红银色，如桃花，鲜明可爱。 青结红银法 凡青有数十种，’曾青最为上。 其状如黄连，又似贯小真珠，长一寸半寸，或三两枚相缀，或直或曲，或深或翠色，时有金线，还绕其问，光缕璨璨。 句容山谷中有，近甚难得，价重於金。 其空青出於梓州，大小中心皆空，色甚鲜翠，其问有含水者。 昆仑头青似杨梅，峰头飒飒然，大者如弹丸，中心实。 句容、梓州青作片子，如碎钵盂，色青无彩翠，拣择并可用。

The refined silver of the **Liǎng** of **Jìnxīn** and **Shìnxīn** states also has a mine, whose nature resembles **Guāngmíng Shā** (光明砂). Its hue is red-purple, vivid and pleasing, fit for furnace use. When smelted and cast, it becomes pure white silver, yielding fourteen or fifteen **liǎng** per **jīn**, a rarity indeed.

In modern times, such methods are scarcely found in ancient Daoist alchemical texts, and their details remain unclear.

Some suspect it is the red ore of silver, where red silver—when refined with **qīnglǜ** (青绿, *orpiment*), **dǎnzǐ** (胆子, *verdigris*), and other **fán** (矾, *alum*)—yields four or five **liǎng**, or even six or seven, with a color like **Dānyáng** (丹阳, *cinnabar*). Yet when mercury and these minerals are boiled together in iron vessels, they solidify into red silver. For every **jīn** of mercury and ore cast, only four **liǎng** of red silver emerge—this is merely iron, not mercury itself.

Others claim **dǎnzǐ** and **qīnglǜ** are merely **tóngmiáo** (铜苗, *copper essence*), containing iron rather than copper, which is why mercury can extract it. Yet this is not related to alchemical processes. The four **liǎng** obtained are iron extracted by mercury, not a product of the elixir.

I have weighed these minerals carefully and recorded their true nature. When boiling and refining in a single crucible, lacking five **liǎng** of red silver, only four and a half emerge—proving they are all iron, without deception.

Moreover, when refining **shāzǐ** (砂子, *mercury ore*), if the vessel is completely filled and the fire too fierce, the mercury will flee in fine, needle-like threads, imperceptible to the eye. Those who fail to notice this will lose everything without knowing why.

Even when using elixirs to wash and refine, the ore may dissolve slightly, turning to dust or ash, carried away by the liquid. If not properly managed, this loss will accumulate, and the mercury will fully transform into red silver.

Later scholars, seeing no results, abandon the method entirely, all assuming it is merely mercury—yet they are mistaken. Another tradition holds that even a **jīn** of mercury yields only iron, and iron naturally has an iridescence. When mixed with **qīnglǜ** and other dyes, it retains this flaw, making refinement difficult—no different from copper.

Modern practitioners of alchemical **Dào** (道, *Way*) find this method arduous and thus neglect it. Yet I have deeply studied and refined this technique, and it proves most worthy.

Indeed, mercury extracts only the purest essence of iron. If one claims mercury remains unchanged, they stray far from the Dao. If instead one seeks iron’s essence, it is the finest iron of all. When cast into mirrors, it produces mirrors of superior clarity, far surpassing ordinary ones—evidence of its purity.

How else does one know this? Mercury is the most potent of all, capable of purifying impurities. When it interacts with these minerals, they are all refined into the quintessence of the five metals.

Upon refining, the crucible’s iron surface is undamaged, not even a hair’s breadth lost. Later, through the elixir’s power, mercury draws the iron’s essence, merging with it in a manner so wondrous that it defies explanation. When used to cast mirrors, it becomes an object beyond ordinary comprehension.

Yet today’s practitioners dismiss it as mere mercury, unaware of its iron essence. I lament my own shallow skill and inadequate understanding of **Huángdì**’s (黄帝, *Yellow Emperor*) methods. If I were to apply **jīn gāo** (金膏, *gold ointment*) and **xiónghuáng** (雄黄, *realgar*), refining it as per the ancient formulas, its brilliance would rival that of a **yīngwǔ** (鹦鹉, *parrot’s feather*—a fine, lustrous cinnabar), surpassing even the mirrors of antiquity.

Now, if cast into bronze, it would still produce iron of the highest grade transformed into copper. Yet today’s scholars call it only **hóngyín** (红银, *red silver*), seeing its iridescence and treating it like common copper, unaware that it is the refined essence of the five metals.

I consider **hóngyín** (red silver) as both iron and copper, and the method of turning iron into silver through mercury. With the formulas perfected, the principles are now clear.

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar into Red Silver:**
Take **zhūshā** (朱砂, *cinnabar*) one **jīn**, preferably of bright hue and not needing to be granulated. Place it into **cāizhǐ** (猜脂, *a type of animal fat or wax*), mix with water, and boil for thirty-five days. Then immerse it in **mìshuǐ** (蜜水, *honey water*) and boil for another fifteen days.

Next, transfer it to the **Huápó** (华池, *Refined Pool*—likely a mercury solution). After seven days, melt **qiān** (铅, *lead*) in a **gāntǔ** (甘土, *sweet clay*) crucible, pour it into the mixture, and add the **zhūshā**, wrapped in **fánní** (矾泥, *alum clay*). Stir until it sinks to the bottom, then subdue it in fire for seven days.

Upon adding **chìtǔ** (赤土, *red earth*), **huángfán** (黄矾, *yellow alum*), and **zhuōshā** (硵砂, *a type of sulfur or alum*), the color emerges, forming **hóngyín** (红银, *red silver*), also called **hóngjīn** (红金, *red gold*). Its exterior is white, while its interior glows faintly red, radiant and attractive.

**Another Method:**
Take **shuǐyín** (水银, *mercury*) one **jīn**, and burn **shǐliúhuáng** (石硫黄, *sulfur*) into sand without further refining or washing. Crush the sand and place it in a double-layered silk bag, then wrap it again in a bamboo mesh sack.

Extract the juice of **sānghuī** (桑灰, *mulberry ash*) and **chìwūzuǒ** (赤乌左味, *a type of red medicinal substance*). Suspend the bag in the liquid, ensuring it does not touch the bottom. Add **huángdān** (黄丹, *yellow realgar*) one **jīn**, and refine with gentle fire like the eye of a fish for seven days.

Later, smelt the contents in a crucible, and they will all turn into **hóngyín** (红银, *red silver*), resembling peach blossoms, vivid and pleasing.

**Method for Refining Green into Red Silver:**
Green minerals come in many varieties, with **zāngqīng** (曾青, *a type of verdigris*) being the finest. Its form is like **huánglián** (黄连, *coptis*), or small **guàn xiǎo zhēnzhū** (贯小真珠, *strung pearls*), one to three inches long, sometimes paired in twos or threes, either straight or curved, deep or bright green, often with golden threads coiled within, shimmering like fine silk.

**Jùróng** (句容) mountains yield this, though it is now exceedingly rare and costs more than gold. Its hollow variety comes from **Zǐzhōu** (梓州), with a central cavity, its color a vivid, bright green, and its interior containing water.

The **Kūnlún** (昆仑) **tóuqīng** (头青, *head green*) resembles **yángméi** (杨梅, *wax myrtle*), with a jagged peak, large specimens like small shot, and a solid core.

The green minerals of **Jùróng** and **Zǐzhōu** can be broken into fragments like shattered bowls, their color a plain green without luster. Even these can be selected and used.

chunks.original_text: 又有白甘青，生甘土中，鲜翠美颜色，如豆许大，稍软，以指甲捐之得破，破处转鲜翠。 此一味彼土人呼为白甘青，＇古来仙方及本草并不见载。 又长偏青、白青、鱼目及善青散，出饶信等州，并杂青也，亦相类。 今煮结砂子，乃是画人淘研出者，彩色，家多用结水银，甚有力。 又一说老铜化为绿，老绿化为青，其晕最浅少。 结砂子方 白善青一斤末　石脑半斤醋煮　水银一斤 右件相和，以醋浆中，於平底铛中，文火鱼目已下沸，少少添浆水，勿令沸，止一伏时当成，并全作砂子。 更能将铛药汁添水，武火煮三两日，弥佳，物亦增晕，亦稍浅。 然任抽生鼓铸。 当得六两成红银。 大抵用青，不并石胆、土绿等，其晕稍少。 又方 青二两稍好者　白矾六两　句容胆子六两　用水银一斤 右并梼研令细，和汞，依常法煮结言，便以黑豆皮四两，煮得无晕。 青花结砂子方 青花一斤　白矾四两　水银一斤 右青花与白矾，先相令匀然，取两匙头，和水银熟研，纳铛中，武火煮三五十沸，，出之淘洗一度。 纹如此已尽为限，任抽生鼓铸，红色甚浅。 石胆红银法 石胆生蒲州山谷，状似折篦头，如瑟瑟浅碧色，烧之变白色者，是真。 次宣润等州，淋取汁煎煮而成，上者青碧色，作块片数等级。 下者如黄泥烂湿，名为泥胆，唯堪和水银烧为粉。 其宣州者，不如句容，气力悬殊，力倍於十。 其句容上者，状如碎瓦子，坚重，鲜碧色，一半带深绿色，甚可爱。 经夏不润，见风不损。 次於蒲州，今所用结砂子者。 但中色已下，并可用。 又有山谷坑洞裹自然生者，色稍浅於煎成者，亦作片块，忽遇即有，常无采处。 近日市肆人有假伪，将太阴玄精，及句容相和，於铜器中煎成，伪作蒲州石胆。 其句容亦被添宣州相和重煮，合成形，改色理，亦相类，甚难辩识，大须审细。 青矾出太原，一名绿矾，一名皂矾，力胜宣州者。 砂子之道，甚有深妙，胆子全土绿。 天目徐真君有歌赞之。 歌日：

「Moreover, there is **bái gānqīng** (白甘青, *white ganqing*), which grows in sweet soil, its color fresh and green, as large as a bean, slightly soft, and can be broken with a fingernail—its fracture reveals an even fresher green. This single substance is called *white ganqīng* by the local people; neither ancient Daoist prescriptions nor the *Běn cǎo* (本草, *Fundamental Herbal*) records mention it.

There are also **cháng piānqīng** (长偏青, *long-biased green*), **bái qīng** (白青, *white green*), **yú mù** (鱼目, *fish-eye green*), and **shàn qīng** (善青, *fine green*) in powder form, all from **Ráo xìn** (饶信, *Raoxin*) and similar regions, resembling one another and also akin to the *ganqing* above.

Now, the method for **jié shāzi** (结砂子, *congealed sand method*) uses this: **bái shànqīng** (白善青, *white fine green*) one pound, powdered; **shí nǎo** (石脑, *stone brain*) half a pound, cooked in vinegar; and **shuǐ yín** (水银, *mercury*) one pound. Mix these ingredients thoroughly in vinegar paste, then place in a flat-bottomed wok over gentle fire until the *yú mù* (鱼目) has settled below the boiling point. Gradually add more vinegar paste and water, ensuring it does not boil, and let it simmer for one *fú* (伏, *double-hour*). When done, it will all congeal into sand.

Alternatively, one can add water to the wok’s mixture and boil it vigorously for three days, yielding an even finer result. The substance will also become slightly more translucent.

However, one may directly extract **shēng gǔ zhù** (生鼓铸, *raw congealed mercury*), producing about six *liǎng* (两, *troy ounces*) of **hóng yín** (红银, *red mercury*). Generally, when using *qīng* (青, *green minerals*), one does not mix in **shí dǎn** (石胆, *stone gall*), **tǔ lǜ** (土绿, *earth green*), etc., as this slightly reduces its potency.

Another method:
Take **qīng** (青, *green minerals*) two *liǎng* (两, *troy ounces*) of the finer variety, **bái fán** (白矾, *white alum*) six *liǎng*, **jùróng dǎnzi** (句容胆子, *Jùróng stone gall*) six *liǎng*, and **shuǐ yín** (水银, *mercury*) one pound. Grind all into fine powder, mix with mercury, and follow the usual method to congeal it. Then add **hēi dòu pí** (黑豆皮, *black soybean husks*) four *liǎng* to ensure the final product has no translucence.

For **qīnghuā jié shāzi** (青花结砂子, *blue-green congealed sand method*):
Take **qīnghuā** (青花, *blue-green flower*) one pound and **bái fán** (白矾, *white alum*) four *liǎng*. First mix these evenly, then take two spoonfuls and thoroughly grind them with mercury. Place in the wok and boil vigorously until it reaches thirty to fifty bubbles. Remove, wash once, and let the patterns fully settle. Directly extract the **shēng gǔ zhù** (生鼓铸, *raw congealed mercury*), yielding a very faint red hue.

The method for **shí dǎn hóng yín** (石胆红银, *stone gall red mercury*):
**Shí dǎn** (石胆, *stone gall*) grows naturally in the valleys of **Púzhōu** (蒲州). Its form resembles a broken comb, with a shallow, pale green color. When burned, it turns white—this is the true variety.

The inferior kind comes from **Xuānrùn** (宣润) and similar regions, where its juice is extracted and refined through boiling. The superior grade is a bright green, forming blocks or flakes of varying quality. The lower grade resembles damp yellow mud, known as **ní dǎn** (泥胆, *mud gall*), and can only be mixed with mercury and burned into powder.

The **Xuānzhōu** (宣州) variety is not as potent as **Jùróng** (句容). Their *qi* (气) and efficacy differ greatly—the **Jùróng** (句容) type is ten times stronger.

The finest **Jùróng** (句容) **shí dǎn** (石胆) resembles shattered tiles, is dense and heavy, with a vivid green hue half-tinged in deep emerald. It is highly prized, unaffected by summer heat or wind exposure.

The **Púzhōu** (蒲州) variety is commonly used for the *jié shāzi* (结砂子) method. Even the mid-grade and below can be utilized.

There are also naturally occurring specimens found in mountain valleys or caverns, their color slightly paler than those refined through boiling. They form flakes or blocks, but such discoveries are rare.

Recently, merchants have produced counterfeit **shí dǎn** (石胆). They mix **tài yīn xuàn jīng** (太阴玄精, *Great Yin Mysterious Purity*) with **Jùróng** (句容) varieties, then boil them in copper vessels to simulate **Púzhōu** (蒲州) **shí dǎn** (石胆).

The **Jùróng** (句容) variety has also been adulterated by adding **Xuānzhōu** (宣州) types and reboiling, altering its form and color. These fakes are very difficult to distinguish, so one must examine them carefully.

**Qīng fán** (青矾, *green alum*), also called **lǜ fán** (绿矾, *green alum*) or **zào fán** (皂矾, *soap alum*), originates from **Tàiyuán** (太原). It surpasses the efficacy of **Xuānzhōu** (宣州) alum.

The **Dao** (道) of refining sand is profound and subtle. Even pure **tǔ lǜ** (土绿, *earth green*) can be praised in song by **Xú zhēnjūn** (徐真君, *Master Xu of Truth*) from **Tiān mù** (天目). His song goes:」

chunks.original_text: 白珠碧水平铛中，文武微微声渐雄。 一伏三时成半死，再烹经宿变成铜。 将军此朝须舞剑，青腰小儿莫相厌。 白霜理石常煞人，黄矾石胆从来艳。 铁埚土釜各文武，一须五时连夜煮。 开匣见玉须焚香，仙人遇之名长久。 结石胆砂子法 句容石胆子一斤　水银一斤 右先取一平底铛，受五六升，或一斗已下者。 以瓦石尽日揩磨铛内底上，令白净。 就中拣取铛底平细者，即易揩磨，切忌油腻。 如用旧铛，即须烧过，与火色同止，磨洗亦中。 水没汞半寸已来，令容得汞药即得，不可令深。 即下药一两，颗块，不碎总得投於汞上，以文火鱼眼沸己下，如水少，以匙抄热水，散泻於铛，绿令散流．入煮两炊久，一度，演计得一两砂子已上。 须着气力紧演为佳。 遍遍如此，以尽为限。

The white pearl in jade waters boils in the even pan,
As martial and civil voices softly rise to grandeur.

One *fú* of three *shí* yields half-death,
Twice steamed overnight, it turns to copper.

The general must wield his sword at dawn,
Let not the child with the green waist scorn it.

White frost on stone ever slays,
While yellow alum’s stone-bile has ever been resplendent.

Iron crucibles and clay pots—both martial and civil—
Must be boiled through five *shí* in one night.

Open the box to reveal the jade, burn incense,
For immortals who encounter it shall be long-lived.

**Method for Congealing Stone-Bile Sand:**

*Ingredients:*
- **Jùróng** (句容) stone-bile: 1 *jīn* (斤)
- Mercury: 1 *jīn* (斤)

*Procedure:*
Take a flat-bottomed pan, holding five or six *shēng* (升), or one *dòu* (斗) or less.
Scrub the pan’s interior thoroughly with pumice or stone all day until its surface is spotlessly white.
Select the smoothest, flattest section of the pan’s base—this is easiest to polish—*never* allow oil or grease to remain.
If using an old pan, first burn it until it glows like fire, then polish and wash it.

Submerge the mercury to a depth of half an inch or more, ensuring it can fully contain the medicine—*do not* let it be too deep.
Add the medicine in two *liǎng* (两) portions, in whole chunks (do not crush), placing them atop the mercury.
Apply gentle, fish-eye heat until the water boils, then simmer.
If the water is insufficient, ladle in hot water to disperse the heat.
Let it boil for two full cookings (*zhuō*), then remove the sand—*one batch yields two liǎng or more*.
*Strive for vigorous, unremitting refinement.*

Repeat this process until the medicine is exhausted.

chunks.original_text: 所结一炊久，即可演，大抵不如多时。 其句容每度下二两，亦得。 药多结亦校多，口诀是水亦云火须浅火须文，为妙入。 此法只用一味清水，不兼诸药，结时成，不同诸方，甚是上法。 结以口吹水面开，当见水银自遍散，如煎饼状满铛底。 加火临药时更秤意，其水银直上铛四绿来，故知药力气感化也。 收砂子时，每度须以瓷片，於铛底熟刮下令诤，收之遍遍，如此以尽为度。 如用跳子，中结亦得。 又一说：夫石胆砂子，初要出晕，但宜以暖汤水淘研令净，切忌着诸杂药煮。 云被诸药把令，本晕药色却牢，志须在竟，不可轻用。 如要且煮，只可空以白矾，於瓷器中煮之。 绿石胆砂子法 句容胆子一斤　盥一大合　水银一斤 右并相和研，令断星子，纳入铛中，着七分水，以火煮似沸即得。 便以砂盆子合之，以一筋枝令通气，时时以水於砂盆子上，少少淋下，令水散下。 如此两日，当得六两已来砂子。 又如能更加半斤，或一斤，取前砂子重结，向前药汁您留重煮汁，两度迭结了，更都将药汁添水，加煮三日，尤妙。 砂子倍多，晕色却浅，有一出晕。 诀云：如石胆结砂子了，更以新石胆煮能去晕，故知深妙再煮结。 结砂子法 宣州石胆十斤，如结汞不尽，更添三五斤，其法更不得着诸药，只须一味胆子。 若加诸药，其晕即难去，所结并 如常法。 右总结了，取砂子紧演去生者，令尽。 以拔莫根细判，煮两三日，常作庞纸色。 即又入黄土，煮两三日，当白如雪，亦钩留得水银，有三般稍相似。 一日鸡厥，其根节不相对，枝茎长大。 二曰苦杖，叶节目疏，并不堪用，其拔莫根稍紧，细节相对，生叶稍圆，苗细短，此药出晕无比，又皆结。 时曾到此根同一时，结其砂子便白。 况更入煮此药，只出得石胆晕，诸药不相当。 又一说：其拔莫先於别器中，煮令浓稠，用添煮砂子，亦妙。 一本云：煮一月日定白。 又一说：金刚根生银山者，赤色，藤子小高三数尺者，其藤有制汞之功。 一名银苗，生於银山者，即堪。 每结一斤砂子，并结后重煮。 都用十六斤藤子，煮后炙蘸三日，便当恋伏火。 其蘸药汁法，用赤乌清水，及黄矾一斤，二味熟和搅用之。 胆子团汞法 此法及转胆子为红银类，故录入此。 右取汞一两，胆子一两，与左味二合已来相和，文火煮半日。 又入胆子末半两，渐渐添米醋煮之，并不得令沸。 时时演取砂子，令汞尽了。 又将砂子与胆子末五两煮，当五日五夜，药成如茶末。 一两末化三两汞成砂子。 作药七日，末一两伏四两汞作药。 十二日一两，上手团汞七两，成砂子。 其火只可一两已来，若您结成砂子了，即火微急亦无妨。 土绿结红银法 土绿有数般，生宣州、饶信州、道永等州山谷，但有铜处即生。 乃是铜坑中般出壤土，经雨便生，色浅软，烂如胡粉块子，以手捻便成粉末者佳，硬如软石者次。 其北地亦有，状如澄了绿米粉，好颜色，软细无脚。 结红银砂子 土绿道永洲者，只用半斤，软者上半斤　盥二两　白矾四两先成灰　汞一斤 右先点米醋研药，后汞相和熟研，令断星子。 然后以铁匙抄纳铛中，如鱼皮相。 次平布於铛底，中心留一寸余地，莫令合。 便以浆水有醋味者，煮前粉物良留。 白矾二两，盐一两，并末之，待布药入铛着水了，并散药於汞药上，水合才没一指已来，火令至文鱼目以下，铛底犹着得手。

「The medicine takes one full cooking to congeal, after which it can be refined, though it is generally better to let it settle longer.

For *jùróng* (句容) mercury, two *liǎng* (两) portions are added per batch, which is acceptable.

When the medicine is abundant, the sand yield is likewise greater. The secret lies in this: the water must be shallow, and the fire gentle—this is the key to success.

This method employs only pure water, no other medicines. The congealing happens as it is prepared, differing from other methods, and is truly superior.

To begin, blow gently across the water’s surface until it ripples, then watch as the mercury spreads evenly, like a thin pancake covering the base of the pan.

When heating, pay close attention as the mercury rises straight up to the pan’s four sides—this proves the medicine’s *virtue/power* (气) has transformed it.

When collecting the sand, use a porcelain shard to scrape the bottom of the pan thoroughly, gathering it batch by batch until all is exhausted. If using a *tiàozi* (跳子) sieve, refining mid-process is also effective.

Another account states: At first, the stone *dǎn* (胆) sand must exhibit a *yùn* (晕) glow. Simply rinse and wash it with warm water to purify it; avoid mixing it with other medicines when boiling. If other medicines are added, their colors will cling to the sand’s original *yùn*, and the goal will not be achieved—do not use it lightly.

If boiling is necessary, only white alum may be added, and it must be done in a porcelain vessel.

**Method for refining stone *dǎn* (胆) sand:**
Take *jùróng* mercury (胆子) one *jīn* (斤), alum one *dàhé* (大合), and mercury one *jīn*—all mixed and ground until no stars remain. Place in the pan with seven-tenths of a *hé* (合) of water and boil gently until it reaches the point of effervescence.

Then transfer to a sand pan, using a single *sīn* (筋) branch to allow ventilation. Periodically add water to the sand pan, letting it drip slowly until the water disperses. After two days, six *liǎng* (两) or more of sand should be obtained.

If an additional half *jīn* (斤) or even one *jīn* is used, take the previously refined sand and congeal it again, retaining the earlier medicine broth for repeated boiling. After two successive refinings, add the broth to fresh water and boil for three more days—this is even more refined.

The sand will yield twice as much, but the *yùn* (晕) glow will be lighter, with one batch producing a clear *yùn*.

The secret states: If stone *dǎn* (胆) sand has been refined, re-boiling it with fresh stone *dǎn* (胆) can remove the *yùn* (晕), proving that deeper refinement through repeated boiling and congealing is truly marvelous.

**Method for refining mercury sand:**
Take ten *jīn* (斤) of *Xuānzhōu* stone *dǎn* (胆). If the mercury is not fully refined, add three to five *jīn* more. The method remains unchanged, using only stone *dǎn* (胆)—no other medicines. If other medicines are added, the *yùn* (晕) will be harder to remove, and the refined sand will not differ from the usual method.

Once all is refined, take the sand and refine it vigorously to remove any impurities, ensuring it is fully pure.

Boil it with *bámò* (拔莫) root for two to three days—it will turn the color of coarse paper. Then add yellow earth and boil again for two to three days—it will become as white as snow, retaining traces of mercury, resembling three stages of refinement.

The first is called *jījié* (鸡厥), where the root nodes do not align, and the stems are long and thick. The second is *kǔzhàng* (苦杖), with sparse, coarse leaves—these are useless. The *bámò* (拔莫) root is slightly tighter, with fine nodes that align, round leaves, and short, slender sprouts. This medicine’s *yùn* (晕) glow is unmatched, and it congeals perfectly.

I once saw this root refined at the same time, and the sand turned white immediately. Even more, when boiling this medicine, only the stone *dǎn* (胆) *yùn* (晕) appears—other medicines do not correspond.

Another account says: First, boil the *bámò* (拔莫) root in a separate vessel to make it thick and concentrated, then add it to the boiling sand—this is also effective.

One text states: Boiling for a month guarantees whiteness.

Another account says: The *jīngāng* (金刚) root from silver mines, which is red, and the vines that are three to five *chǐ* (尺) tall, possess the function of controlling mercury. Known as *yínmiáo* (银苗), it grows on silver mountains—this is the best.

For every *jīn* (斤) of refined sand, including the post-refining re-boiling, sixteen *jīn* of the vine are used. After boiling, the vine is fried and steeped for three days, then left to rest near the fire. The method for steeping the medicine broth uses pure water from *Chìwū* (赤乌), along with one *jīn* of yellow alum. The two are mixed and ground thoroughly for use.

**Method for congealing mercury with stone *dǎn* (胆):**
This method, along with *zhuǎndǎn* (转胆子) for red silver, is recorded here.

Take one *liǎng* (两) of mercury and one *liǎng* of stone *dǎn* (胆), along with two *hé* (合) of the previous medicine, and mix them. Boil gently with fire for half a day.

Then add half a *liǎng* of stone *dǎn* (胆) powder, gradually introducing rice vinegar while boiling—*do not* let it boil over. Continuously refine and collect the sand until the mercury is fully exhausted.

Again, boil the sand with five *liǎng* of stone *dǎn* (胆) powder for five days and nights—when complete, the medicine will resemble tea powder. One *liǎng* of powder can congeal three *liǎng* of mercury into sand.

If prepared as medicine for seven days, one *liǎng* of powder can congeal four *liǎng* of mercury. On the twelfth day, one *liǎng* of powder can congeal seven *liǎng* of mercury.

The fire may be slightly more intense once the sand has formed—if the sand is already refined, even a quicker flame poses no harm.

**Method for refining red silver with *tǔlǜ* (土绿):**
There are several kinds of *tǔlǜ* (土绿). Found in *Xuānzhōu* (宣州), *Ráoxìn* (饶信州), and *Dàoyǒng* (道永) mountainous regions, it grows wherever copper is present.

Dig it from copper pits, where it is unearthed from the soil. After exposure to rain, it grows, appearing soft and pale, like crumbled *húfěn* (胡粉, orpiment). The best is when it crumbles to powder with a touch; the second-best is when it is hard like soft stone.

In the north, it resembles settled green rice flour—soft, fine, and without residue—and has a pleasing hue.

**Refining red silver sand with *tǔlǜ* (土绿):**
For *Dàoyǒng* (道永) *tǔlǜ* (土绿), use half a *jīn* (斤) of the soft variety, or slightly more. Take two *liǎng* (两) of alum, four *liǎng* of white alum, and one *jīn* of mercury—first grind the alum with rice vinegar, then mix and grind the mercury thoroughly until no stars remain.

Next, use an iron spoon to transfer the mixture into the pan, spreading it like fish skin. Then lay a flat cloth at the bottom of the pan, leaving a one-inch gap in the center—*do not* let it touch.

Use a vinegar-flavored paste to moisten the powder before boiling. Add two *liǎng* of white alum and one *liǎng* of salt, all ground into powder. After placing the cloth and medicine in the pan and adding water, sprinkle the powdered medicine evenly atop the mercury mixture. The water level should barely submerge the mixture by one finger’s breadth. Apply a fire just below the gentle *yúyǎn* (鱼眼, fish-eye) heat, ensuring the pan’s base remains warm enough to hold by hand.»

chunks.original_text: 如此半日，即渐加火，令如小鱼眼已下疏疏然。 又半日文，又渐加火，常如鱼眼。 半日，又加火加水煮。 半日都两伏时，并成砂子。 一法说初结时，取三二两先结了砂子，打破作小块子，散投於铛内，初此相钩转。 又砂子总成了，却布於铛底，还着一斤或半斤土绿，更煮一两日，倍得砂子，并退晕浅去。 又一说：但以前所结了药汁，莫弃之，并收取，重煮结砂子，亦云倍多，兼晕却浅。 右并入钵研，以水淘洗抽生，约鼓得十两成。 结砂子法本出刘君 青矾五两北地者上　汞一斤　土绿一斤用北地者，状如澄了绿米粉颜色，软细无脚 右件汞药，入钵内，点醋熟研，纳入新铛中。 铛不用揩磨。 以武火煮一伏时，并成乾砂，总无水银膏也。 当时秤得砂子二十两。 又取此砂子於砂盆中，入白矾煮一日。 即以蚌粉研，淘洗三两度。 又和盥淘半日，又以白矾和乌梅煮一日，又入砂糖煮】日，又以皂荚煮一日。 每度皆研淘出黑汁，总令乾净。 即入黄丹一两同研，研了炒熬又研，又入霜一两，熟研令相得。 即分作十六分，以盐裹散，刺作小孔子，曝令极乾。 入炉或铛上，以灰盖。 初文养一日，便放武火，烧鼎底令红。 寒开，霜药总化不见，令汞并在上釜，收取球子砂鼓，得四两红银。 此常者色退一半，扣之无声，甚软。 取入火烧试，微有烟晕甚浅。 尊师云：球内所生霜，其砂子便令全伏，白如玉也。 此是神仙上品也。 结砂子法红银 硵砂一斤　土绿一斤　白矾一斤 右三物相和研，入瓶子内，以少盥薄为柜，养烧一伏时。 临了用大火烧得通过，即以风化灰一斗，赤乌一斗，以醋浆水投石灰中取清，以石灰汁煮令热，淋赤乌，取汁中煎砂子。 其汞先以熟药十两，用研下铛中，结一伏时，总尽其盐柜，便入铛，用同结砂子更妙，时时搅之不用频。 如经一伏时，并结了如砂，并无生汞也。 如又淘却，更入四五两熟药，重结当总伏，妙不可言。 每一斤入四两白铅，於埚中熟搅，泻於模中，令薄作砣。 然以砣於灰中着上，以猛火烧，以鞘吹亦得。 当作孔镂铿铅，并泻入灰，红银独在。 又入埚销，又投铅成埚令薄，又入灰中沥，如此者三。 即更鼓空沥三两遍，铅当出尽，即又入埚，以壁土，又盐搅略，又出却余铅并净矣。 晕至少，物甚柔。 又一说：此物和丹阳及银，三停入，甚好。 白铅法 右铅一斤，用松脂二斤生者，以猛火炒铅为水，即下少许脂，又少着些盐，即以物搅之。 又续下脂及盥，令脂遍遍，尽二斤铅，但成灰粉，即堪以成为度，即入甘埚，鼓成水，当得十余两，如雪。 结砂子法 土绿一斤　白矾五两　盥五合 右件并相和研，以好黄土一斤，纸筋熟铸为泥，作一箱样，可厚二寸许。 用裹前件药，渐令乾，武烧一火，勿令箱子破裂。 寒开之，作紫赤色，可结一斤。 汞和同研一时下，时时演之。 此药重重用，可结十斤、二十斤。 每斤土 绿，可分作两，土箱为准。 华池法：石灰和好酒熟搅，如煎饼缅用之。 又法：凡结土、绿砂子，和黄土结晕。 又方 土汞二斤　白矾八两 右并梼罗，以二升米醋，少少洒洒，炒令尽。 如无，好糠醋亦得。 又梼罗成粉，臧取一半药，和一斤水银，熟研令相入，纳平底铛中，以醋浆中常没一寸，如鱼，眼沸，煮经半日，当并成砂子，更无生者。
chunks.translated_text:
After half a day, gradually increase the fire so that it is like the small fish-eye below, sparse and flickering. Another half day of gentle heat, then gradually increase the fire again, keeping it constantly like a fish-eye. After half a day, add more fire and water to boil. After another half day, when the heat reaches two *fú* (伏, layers of heat), the mixture will become sand-like.

One method states: when it first congeals, take three or two *liǎng* (两) of the congealed sand, crush it into small pieces, and scatter them into the pan. Initially, this causes a hook-like reaction. Once all the sand has formed, lay it at the bottom of the pan, adding one *jīn* (斤) or half a *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), and boil it for another day or two. The yield of sand will double, and the darkening around its edges will fade.

Another method says: simply use the congealed medicine liquid from before—do not discard it, but collect and boil it again to form sand, which is also said to double in quantity, and the darkening will fade.

All of this is then transferred to a mortar for grinding. Rinse with water to extract the pure essence, repeatedly pounding until you obtain ten *liǎng* of refined sand.

The method for forming sand-like *hóng yín* (红银, red silver) originates from Master Liu. Use *qīng fán* (青矾, green vitriol) five *liǎng*, the finest from the Northern lands, one *jīn* of mercury, and one *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar). The Northern *tǔ lǜ* resembles settled green rice flour in texture, soft and fine, with no impurities.

Take these ingredients, place them in a mortar, grind with vinegar until thoroughly mixed, and transfer to a new pan. The pan should not be scoured or polished. Boil with intense fire (*wǔ huǒ*, 武火) for one *fú*, until it becomes dry sand, with no trace of mercury residue. At this point, you should have twenty *liǎng* of sand.

Next, take this sand and place it in a sand basin, adding white alum to boil for a day. Then grind it with *bàng fěn* (蚌粉, mother-of-pearl powder), rinsing three times. Mix again with alum and grind for half a day, then boil with white alum and *wū méi* (乌梅, black plum) for a day. Finally, boil with *sāng táng* (砂糖, rock sugar) for a day and with *zào jiá* (皂荚, soapberry) for another day. After each step, grind and rinse out the black impurities until it is completely pure.

Add one *liǎng* of *huáng dān* (黄丹, litharge), then grind together. After grinding, parch and refine it again, then add one *liǎng* of frost (*shuāng*, 霜), grinding until thoroughly mixed. Divide into sixteen portions, wrap each with salt, and pierce them into small conical shapes (*xiǎo kǒu zǐ*, 小孔子). Dry them under the sun until completely desiccated. Place them in a furnace or on a pan, covering with ash. Initially, nurture with gentle heat for a day, then apply intense fire, heating the crucible’s base until it turns red. Once cooled, the frost within will dissolve, leaving only the mercury. Collect the sand-like globules (*qiú zǐ*, 球子) from the pan, yielding four *liǎng* of red silver.

This is the common grade—its color fades by half, and when struck, it makes no sound, being very soft. When ignited, it emits only a faint, shallow smoke.

The revered teacher said: the frost generated within the globules causes the sand to fully congeal, becoming as white as jade. This is the supreme grade of the Daoist elixir.

The method for forming sand-like red silver:
Take one *jīn* of *niè shā* (硵砂, calcined realgar), one *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), and one *jīn* of white alum. Grind these three ingredients together, place them in a bottle, and seal with a thin layer of alum paste. Nurture and heat for one *fú*. When nearly finished, apply a strong fire to complete the process. Use one *dǒu* (斗) of wind-sifted ash and one *dǒu* of *chì wū* (赤乌, red crow medicine, possibly red lead or cinnabar), mix with vinegar paste and water to dissolve the ash, then strain to obtain clear lime water. Boil the lime water until hot, pour over the *chì wū*, and extract the liquid to refine the sand.

The mercury should first be treated with ten *liǎng* of refined medicine, ground and placed in the pan, congealed for one *fú*. Once all the salt residue is exhausted, transfer it to the pan and use the same method as forming sand, but even more refined. Stir it occasionally without overdoing so.

After one *fú*, it will fully congeal into sand, with no trace of raw mercury. Rinse again, then add four or five *liǎng* of refined medicine, congealing it repeatedly until fully refined—this is beyond description.

For each *jīn* of this, add four *liǎng* of white lead (*bái qiān*, 白铅), stir and refine in a crucible, pour into a mold, and flatten it into a *tuó* (砣, pestle). Then place the pestle in ash and burn it fiercely, using a bellows to blow as well. This should be shaped into a perforated lead mold (*kǒng lòu kuàng qiān*, 孔镂铿铅), poured into the ash, leaving only the red silver.

Refine it again in a crucible, pour lead into the crucible to thin it, and then strain it through ash three times. The lead will be fully exhausted, leaving only the red silver. Rinse it again in a crucible with *bì tǔ* (壁土, furnace clay) and a little salt, then strain and remove the remaining lead, which will be clean.

The darkening will be minimal, and the substance very soft. Another method states: mix this with *dān yáng* (丹阳, possibly a type of cinnabar or red lead) and silver, in a ratio of three parts to one, and it will be even better.

The method for white lead (*bái qiān*):
Take one *jīn* of lead, mix with two *jīn* of raw *sōng zhī* (松脂, pine resin). Parch the lead with intense fire until it becomes liquid, then add a small amount of resin and a little salt, stirring thoroughly. Continue adding resin and alum until the resin is evenly distributed throughout the lead, which should now be entirely transformed into ash powder. This can then be used as a measure (*dù*, 度). Place it in a sweet crucible, pound into liquid, and you will obtain over ten *liǎng* of white lead, resembling snow.

The method for forming sand:
Take one *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), five *liǎng* of white alum, and five *hé* (合) of alum. Grind all together, mix with one *jīn* of fine yellow soil and *zhǐ sīn* (纸筋, paper fiber) to form a paste, and shape it into a box about two *cùn* (寸) thick. Wrap the previous mixture inside this box, allowing it to dry gradually, then bake with intense fire without breaking the box.

When cooled, it will turn a purple-red color and yield one *jīn* of sand. Grind the mercury together with it for an hour, stirring continuously. This medicine can be repeatedly used to form sand in quantities of ten *jīn* or twenty *jīn*. Each *jīn* of *tǔ lǜ* can be divided into two, with the box of yellow soil as the standard.

The *Huá Chí* (华池) method: mix stone lime with good wine and stir thoroughly, using it like a thin pancake.

Another method states: whenever forming sand with *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), mix it with yellow soil to congeal.

Another prescription:
Take two *jīn* of *tǔ gōng* (土汞, calx of mercury), and eight *liǎng* of white alum. Grind them together, then add two *shēng* (升) of rice vinegar, sprinkling it gradually while parching until fully refined. If no rice vinegar is available, use good bran vinegar instead. Grind the mixture into powder, then take half of it and mix with one *jīn* of mercury, grinding until thoroughly combined. Place it in a flat-bottomed pan, keeping it submerged in vinegar paste to a depth of one *cùn* (寸). Boil like a fish-eye until it reaches a rolling boil for half a day, and it will fully congeal into sand, with no trace of raw mercury remaining.
