chunks.original_text: 如无浆水，以醋和水亦得。 如此了，又将砂子，又依前入一斤药，相和研，依前煮结，亦用半日。 然后淘研令净，抽生鼓铸，当七两成，甚佳。 不并寻常者。 结砂子方 右取桑柴灰约三斗，禳草藉蒸热汤淋淋，取三斗更重淋取粉脚，约准量二大斗，每斗重八斤。 如块大，即打破如弹子大，不得细研，恐泥淋不过，甚难调治。 前件热暖淋得汁赤，不中。 如得碧绿色，乃堪用之。 前汁淋之，用煎汞三升已上，器鼎中煎三日，添汁浸之，如常法，演之如常法，唯紧是务耳。 又用砒黄飞霜三遍，和水汞。 竹筒除皮，如两张纸厚，可长三寸余。 且将前灰汁煮之，管中满着，铛中亦满，管中黑，即倾之。 如此三度，即苦酒亦尔。 热汤汤石灰清亦如法。 用苦酒拌，一如飞四神丹法，得霜。 用太阳、太阴、玄精、黄矾石如金色者上。 硵砂青黑者上。 此五物和合末，着盥藉细捣，盥遍副铛着边，如一粒米厚，上覆亦尔。 用炭固济，一伏时，文八武四，亦不过一斤炭，急即不堪用。 得霜了白噶火软，辫之如两纸厚，用裹上物为丸，丸如小弹子大。 又用煮五合钙将为池，池六升已上，入埚子镕，投累至三丸一入池，如此五度可止。 后用博上克作痕，为模深作，用油拭之，令甚润湿可泻。 又云：先入炼白矾灰为妙。 其法用桑火烧坑内，绝净扫，用苦酒拌之，趁热投乾矾於坑中盆合，固济之。 待玲开，用一两投一斤，先於铛中熬令乾，入坑为柔用投霜，不用作丸。 结红银法 土绿五两绿色青软者，手捻如胡粉好　白矾五两已上亦得　赤乌半斤已下亦可 右以汞一斤，相和熟研，入铛子，文火结半日，至午全伏，并成砂子。 便任抽生鼓，只得四两已来抽生。 铛底先布盥，厚一寸余，即细梼白矾末，布於盐中心，少布些些，即以薄绢裹砂子，捻令相着，绢才裹足即休，勿令剩。 安铛内上，又着白矾盖绢，便一时拨盐，拥其上霜盆固之，武火半日止。 后法 汞一斤　绿子六两　赤石脂二两　铅二两续添 右三味，於砂盆中，取少许盐，和左味槌研，可百余下。 候铛沸，即以铁匙挑下之，武火煮，从寅至辰，银线得之了。 一斤用黄丹一两，炒和研，可抽生便用之。 飞出汞抽生法 右取砂子，以寒水石为柜，稍薄，着砂子不然，重重隔之。 上又着盐盖，盥上又着灰。 固济，文武火飞，至鼎底乃止。 其寒水石，即须生烧一火，通赤令熟，即急去火，以盆合固济缝。 待玲开，即堪用。 倒抽砂子法 右取一甘埚子，以砂子於埚底，上以浥浥汁盥，满埚实紧按了，即火边炙令盥乾。 便合於地坑瓶子口上，瓶内着少水，以筋泥泥之，渐渐着火候，埚受火，便放一笼武火，寒开收之。 凡抽砂子了，所收得生水银，宜先以醋煮。 即以暖浆水研淘洗，次以暖水洗，更以盐和研，方得序。 赤乌砂子方 赤乌者，腻粉之脚也，本是泥胆及盐为之。 淮南者胜於向北，新好者佳。 如经时月多力，在地停贮者少力，计每斗重八斤。 紧实者良。 右取赤乌，不限多少，以大瓷盛沸汤，投之搅令匀，以小木槌子熟搅打令匀，便於热汤中破散，更连头投热汤。 候总散碎了，即投於玲水，亦无妨。 满瓷盛停一日一夜，当并澄清。 即以物掠取上清者，切不可用浓浊者，入釜中煎煮一饭久，便以薄口杓於釜底，刮掠取砂子。
chunks.translated_text:
If no brine is available, mix vinegar with water instead.

Once refined, take the sand again and, following the previous method, add one *jīn* of medicine, blending and grinding thoroughly. Cook and congeal it as before—it also requires half a day.

Then sift and wash until pure, and extract the *shēngshēng* (生生, vital essence) by pounding and casting. The yield will be about seven *liǎng* (两), which is excellent.

This is not the common method.

**Prescription for Congealing Sand:**

Take approximately three *dǒu* (斗) of mulberry twig ash, sift with bamboo grass through hot water, and collect three *dǒu* of the heavier sediment, roughly equivalent to two large *dǒu* in volume, each weighing eight *jīn* (斤).
If the lumps are too large, break them into the size of a *dànzi* (弹子, marble), but do not grind them finely—fear that the sediment will not pass through the sifting, making it difficult to refine.
The ash should be sifted through hot water until the liquid turns a deep red—this is not acceptable. If it turns a greenish hue, it is suitable for use.

Use this liquid to sift the ash, and place three *shēng* (升) of mercury in a crucible, cooking it for three days. Add the liquid to soak it repeatedly, as in the usual method, but ensure it is tightly sealed.
Then apply *píhuáng fēishuāng* (砒黄飞霜, arsenic sublimate) three times, mixing it with mercury.
Take a bamboo tube, remove its skin, and cut it into strips about two sheets of paper thick, with a length of over three *cùn* (寸).
Pour the prepared ash liquid into the tube, filling it completely, and also fill a flat-bottomed pan with the same liquid. If the liquid in the tube turns black, pour it out.
Repeat this process three times—even with bitter vinegar, the same method applies.
Sift the stone lime (石灰) through hot water to obtain a clear liquid as before.
Mix it with bitter vinegar, following the method of *sìshén dān* (四神丹, Four Spirits Pill) sublimation, until a frost forms.

Use *tǎiyáng* (太阳, cinnabar), *tǎiyīn* (太阴, realgar), *xuánjīng* (玄精, refined realgar), and *huángfán shí* (黄矾石, yellow alum) that resembles gold in color—all of the highest quality.
Use *qīngshā* (硵砂, green arsenic) that is blackish-green—also of the highest quality.
Combine these five ingredients into a powder, place them in a mortar, and pound them finely. Spread the powder around the edges of a secondary pan, about the thickness of a grain of rice, and cover the center similarly.
Use charcoal to seal and roast it for one *fúshí* (伏时, hour), with a ratio of eight parts gentle fire to four parts strong fire. Do not exceed one *jīn* of charcoal—if done too quickly, it will not be usable.
Once frost is obtained and it turns white, soften it with fire, then twist it into strips as thick as two sheets of paper. Wrap these strips around the upper material to form pills, each the size of a small *dànzi* (弹子, marble).
Then use five *hé* (合) of lime to create a pool, with six *shēng* (升) or more. Place the pills in a crucible and melt them, adding them to the pool until three pills are immersed per batch. Repeat this process five times.

Afterward, use *bóshàng kè* (博上克, refined borax) to mark the surface, creating a mold. Apply oil to smooth it, ensuring it is very moist and can be easily removed.
It is also said: First, add the refined white alum ash as a marvelous aid.
The method involves burning a pit with mulberry wood, sweeping it thoroughly clean, mixing the lime with bitter vinegar, and while it is still hot, placing dry alum in the pit to cover it. Seal it tightly.
When the *líng* (玲, condensation) opens, add one *liǎng* (两) to every *jīn* (斤). First, roast it in a pan until dry, then place it in the pit for softening before applying the frost—do not form pills.

**Prescription for Congealing Red Silver:**

Take five *liǎng* (两) of *tǔ lǜ* (土绿, cinnabar), preferably green and soft, such that when rubbed between the hands it feels like *húfěn* (胡粉, powdered lead).
Also take five *liǎng* (两) or more of white alum.
And half a *jīn* (斤) or less of *chìwū* (赤乌, red arsenic)—also acceptable.

Combine one *jīn* (斤) of mercury with these ingredients, blending and grinding thoroughly. Place the mixture in a pan and cook it with gentle fire for half a day until noon, when the full heat is applied. It will congeal into sand.
Then, extract the *shēngshēng* (生生, vital essence) by pounding and casting—only about four *liǎng* (两) will be obtained.

Before casting, lay a layer of salt in the bottom of the pan, about one *cùn* (寸) thick. Spread the finely ground white alum powder in the center of the salt, sparingly. Wrap the sand in thin silk, twisting it so that it adheres to the salt. Once the silk is just wrapped around the sand, stop—do not let it remain loose.
Place the pan inside another, then cover the sand with another layer of salt-wrapped silk. Immediately stir the salt, pressing it down to form a tight crust. Roast it with strong fire for half a day.

**Later Method:**

Take one *jīn* (斤) of mercury,
six *liǎng* (两) of *lǜzi* (绿子, green arsenic),
and two *liǎng* (两) of *chìshí zhī* (赤石脂, red pitchstone).
Add two *liǎng* (两) of lead (铅), which should be added gradually.

Grind these three ingredients together in a mortar with a small amount of salt, pounding them about a hundred times.
When the pan boils, use an iron spoon to stir the mixture down into it. Cook with strong fire from the *yín* (寅, 3 AM) hour until the *chén* (辰, 7 AM) hour, and the silver threads will be obtained.
For one *jīn* (斤) of mercury, add one *liǎng* (两) of *huángdān* (黄丹, cinnabar), parch and grind it together. Extract the *shēngshēng* (生生, vital essence) immediately after.

**Method for Extracting Mercury by Sublimation:**

Take the sand and place it in a crucible with *hánshuǐ shí* (寒水石, alum) as a barrier, but keep the layer thin. If the sand touches the alum, layer them thickly.
Cover the top with salt, and then with ash.
Seal it tightly and sublimate with gentle and strong fire until the bottom of the crucible is reached.
The alum must then be burned once more with fire, turning it completely red. Immediately remove it from the fire, cover it with a basin, and seal the edges.
When the *líng* (玲, condensation) opens, it will be ready for use.

**Method for Casting Sand:**

Take a crucible and place the sand at its base. Pour a thin layer of moistened liquid over it, filling the crucible completely and pressing it down tightly. Then roast it by the fire until the liquid is dry.
Place the crucible over a bottle mouth in a pit on the ground, with a small amount of water inside. Seal it with sinew and clay, gradually increasing the heat until the crucible is heated. Apply a strong fire, then quickly remove it when the condensation opens.

In general, after casting the sand, the extracted vital mercury (*shēngshēng*, 生生) should first be boiled with vinegar.
Then, wash it with warm vinegar and warm water, and finally grind it with salt to achieve the proper sequence.

**Prescription for Red Arsenic Sand:**

*Chìwū* (赤乌, red arsenic) is the sediment of *níchūn* (腻粉, refined lead powder), originally made from mud gall and salt.
The *huáinán* (淮南, southern variety) is superior to the northern one, and fresh, good-quality material is best.
If it has been stored for a long time or left on the ground, its potency will be diminished. Each *dǒu* (斗) should weigh eight *jīn* (斤).
The tightly compacted variety is superior.

Take any quantity of *chìwū* (赤乌), place it in a large porcelain container filled with boiling water, and stir it until evenly dispersed. Use a small wooden pestle to grind and stir it until smooth, then break it up in the hot water. Add it all together to the hot water.
Once it is completely dispersed into fine particles, immerse it in clear water—this will not hinder the process.
Fill the porcelain container and let it settle for one day and night; it will become clear.
Use a tool to skim off the clear liquid on top—do not use the thick, turbid portion. Place it in a pot and boil for the duration of a meal. Then, with a thin-mouthed ladle at the bottom of the pot, scrape and collect the sand.

chunks.original_text: 砂子似蚕砂，甚虚软，安於一瓷碗中，碗中须着少药汁养砂子。 时时掠之，以尽为限。 釜中汁少更添，亦以尽为限。 其瓷中水尽更添水，以物熟搅，候澄又煎煮，亦有砂子在其瓷中者，亦以尽为限。 待总了，计釜中汁只有一二斗，即止火，拔釜出於明处。 其釜底人有询千，以才日下收之，与前者一也。 总收得砂子了。 都纳入瓷瓶中，还以赤乌汁，清煮四伏时，数搅之，一日一度研淘。 即却他成水银，得砂了至少。 如不淘研及不数搅，但莫令着底，总成砂子。 一说其清水秤重，每升重一两，待后作时，先秤水，然后取赤乌清水，秤即知之。 又一法：以药头汁煮砂子四伏时，数数搅，切勿令着底，火须武。 每至一伏时，须略淘去稠恶旧汁，更添新汁煮，煮日数满，后缚令乾，秤知两数。 又一本方虽云：四伏时煮，其所出晕，将此砂子一两，入二两汞中，用皂荚梅浆煮，与诸家煮晕方非相类。 如不要白添金，名红金，本方说如此。 又一说：赤乌汁俱入釜中煮，总不用旋旋略刮，日满汁尽，其砂并自着釜底，任收之。 又釜中煮了汁，纳瓦盆中，经宿尽结成长大，消石长尺余，赢如两指，白色，质状一如消石，见风亦不化变，有人呼为白石胆。 云将结得砂子无晕，亦堪作柜用。 又其瓶子中曾煎煮来药汁，点着砖石，如空青色，经久不变。 结赤乌砂子法 右以厅谷糠二斗，已来衬赤乌。 更以少糠抑赤乌，令相和一出又淋之，可着如停，隔日即泥。 须淋取尽其汁，别更澄待清，煮得成结子多，又少晕，不知何也未详。 余意恐难淋，不如前说。 一又余意前拌砂子，煮时加句容胆子，必应易伏少晕，亦宜寥子灰，至良。 只依前大例煮砂子，更以寥子灰煮，是上法。 又见宿上人云：比煮赤乌，但一出手煮釜底，收取砂子，更入柴灰中，煮三伏时，并成上好乾砂子，每一斤鼓得十余两。 后被崔中丞因造金器物，都有四五十两，一时投入金中，用却去其金，甚好。 故知前说云堪添金，亦不虚也。 此物性至柔甚柔，於诸色红金，亦柔於金银也。 又以汞三斤，已来砂盆子中，和赤乌点酽醋脚，研之如缅糊。 两炊久已来，不用着火，以水淘之，又加赤乌，又续续点酽醋研，候汞中有砂子，即演取，以数足为限。 然净淘洗砂子，以余甘子煮，又以甘草煮，去晕无毒，得成银膏。 燠伏砂子法 凡诸色砂子，每结一斤水银，以伏多者为煮多少晕，易为修变，常手只是四两已下，如能结得七八两已上者，甚得其妙。 若善能燠伏，更钩制得水银，加得两数，或全伏者，为含水银多，物自无晕，深在燠伏。 又法 右取砂子，莫令成粉末，以绢及竹疏袋子重盛，以赤乌清水，水中加黄丹四两，煮下七日。 然后入赤乌，煎成白胆子柜，中伏七日，便全伏火，不用抽生。 又如不入柜，但一出手，二七日煮，亦得。 又法 右砂子要全伏者，取土汞一斤，加胆子半斤，结总了，用所结了土汞等，煮令乾，和少盥熟梼作柜，於铛中固济，烧养十日，全伏。 又法 盥一斤　消石四两　白矾四两 右件相和入瓶，烧一火，令至镕。 寒开之，又取矾石五两，蜜陀僧一两，已上相和，又武火烧一伏时。 然取前件等，更加磁石五两，却梼研为柜，文武火七日，至妙。

The sand resembles silkworm excrement (*cánshā* 蚕砂), being very light and soft. Place it in a single porcelain bowl, with a small amount of medicinal liquid in the bowl to nurture the sand. Skim it repeatedly until the liquid is exhausted.

If the broth in the pot is insufficient, add more, but also until it is exhausted. When the water in the bowl is depleted, add fresh water, stir thoroughly with a tool, and wait until it clarifies again before boiling. Even if some sand remains settled in the bowl, do not use it beyond its exhaustion.

Once all is collected, the broth in the pot will total only one or two *dǒu* (斗). Then extinguish the fire, remove the pot, and set it in a bright place. The sediment at the bottom of the pot is known as *rénxī* (人询), which should be gathered the following day, just like the earlier portion.

After gathering all the sand, store it in a porcelain bottle. Reboil it with *chìwū* (赤乌) broth, simmering for four *fú* (伏) periods, stirring frequently. Once a day, grind and wash it. Then discard the remaining mercury (*tóng* 铜, here meaning *gōngtóng* 锌汞, "quicksilver") and collect the sand, which will be minimal.

If not ground and washed nor frequently stirred, but simply kept from settling, the sand will fully solidify. Another account states: When measuring the clear water, each *shēng* (升) weighs one *liǎng* (两). To prepare it later, first weigh the water, then take the *chìwū* clear water, and weigh it to determine the quantity.

Another method: Boil the sand with the concentrated broth for four *fú* periods, stirring it repeatedly and ensuring it never settles. The fire must be strong (*wǔ* 武). Every time one *fú* period passes, skim off the thick, impure, and old broth, then add fresh broth to continue boiling. When the boiling day is complete, bind the sand and let it dry, then weigh to know its quantity.

Another prescription reads: Boil the sand for four *fú* periods. The resulting *yùn* (晕, "vaporous residue") is taken—one *liǎng* (两) of this sand is added to two *liǎng* of mercury (*gōngtóng* 锌汞), cooked with *zàojiá méi* (皂荚梅浆, "soapberry and plum juice"), differing from other methods of producing *yùn*.

If no additional gold is desired, it is called *hóngjīn* (红金). The prescription states this method.

Another account says: Boil all the *chìwū* (赤乌) broth together in the pot, never skimming or scraping it. When the broth is exhausted in a day, the sand will naturally settle at the bottom of the pot, and you may collect it as you wish.

When the broth has been boiled, place it in a ceramic basin (*wǎpén* 瓦盆). After a night, it will solidify into long, thick *xiāoshí* (消石, "calcined alum") rods, over a *chǐ* (尺) in length, as thick as two fingers, white in color, and with the same texture as *xiāoshí*. Even when exposed to wind, it will not dissolve or change. Some call it *báishídǎn* (白石胆, "white stone gall").

It is said that if the sand is solidified without any *yùn* (晕), it can also be used for refining.

Again, if the medicinal broth from previous boiling is used to paint on bricks or stones, it will appear as an empty green (*qīng* 青) color, remaining unchanged for a long time.

**Method for Solidifying *Chìwū* Sand (赤乌砂子法)**
Take two *dǒu* (斗) of *tīnggǔ* (厅谷) husks and layer them with *chìwū* (赤乌). Then press the *chìwū* with a small amount of husks, ensuring they are well-mixed. After one pressing and washing, it will settle like sediment (*tíng* 停). The next day, it will become mud (*ní* 泥).

The broth must be skimmed until fully exhausted, then separately clarified and set aside. The resulting solidified sand will have more *yùn* (晕), but it is unclear why.

In my opinion, it may be difficult to skim, so the previous method is preferable. Another thought: When mixing the sand earlier, add *jūróngdǎn* (句容胆子, "Jurong stone gall") during boiling. This should make it easier to solidify with less *yùn*, and *liáo* (寥) ash is also suitable—it is the finest method.

Simply follow the earlier major method for boiling the sand, then boil it again with *liáo* ash—this is the superior approach.

Another account from an elder (*sùshàngrén* 宿上人) states: When boiling *chìwū* (赤乌), after one pressing, boil it at the bottom of the pot, collect the sand, and then place it in *chái* (柴) ash. Boil for three *fú* periods, and it will become excellent dry sand, yielding over ten *liǎng* (两) per *jīn* (斤). Later, *Cuī Zhōngshēng* (崔中丞) used this to craft gold instruments, obtaining over forty or fifty *liǎng* of sand at once. He then added it to gold in one go, successfully removing the impurities from the gold—an excellent result.

Thus, it is known that the earlier claim that this sand can be added to gold is not unfounded.

This substance is extremely soft, even softer than other red golds (*hóngjīn* 红金), and softer than gold and silver (*jīnyín* 金银).

Another method: Take three *jīn* (斤) of mercury (*gōngtóng* 锌汞), place it in a sand basin (*shāpénzi* 砂盆子), and mix with *chìwū* (赤乌) and concentrated vinegar (*niècuì* 酽醋). Grind it until it resembles *miǎn* (缅) paste. After two *chuāo* (炊) periods, do not apply fire. Instead, wash it with water, then add more *chìwū* (赤乌) and repeatedly grind with concentrated vinegar. When sand appears in the mercury, collect it until the quantity is sufficient.

After thoroughly washing and purifying the sand, boil it with *gānzǐ* (甘子, "sweet fruit") and *gāncǎo* (甘草, "licorice root"), then remove the *yùn* (晕) and any toxicity. It will yield *yín gāo* (银膏, "silver paste").

**Method for Boiling and Solidifying Sand (燠伏砂子法)**
For all types of sand, when one *jīn* (斤) of mercury (*gōngtóng* 锌汞) is solidified, the more *fú* (伏) periods used in boiling, the less *yùn* (晕) there will be. This makes refinement easier, and the usual amount is four *liǎng* (两) or less. If one can solidify seven or eight *liǎng* (两) or more, it is truly masterful.

If skilled in boiling and solidifying, and further refining the mercury, the quantity will increase, or it may become fully solidified, containing no *yùn*—this is the essence of boiling and solidifying.

Another method: Take sand that requires full solidification, place it in a silk or bamboo mesh bag (*zhǔlǚdài* 疏袋), and boil it with clear *chìwū* (赤乌) water, adding four *liǎng* (两) of *huángdān* (黄丹, "yellow cinnabar"). Boil it for seven days.

Then add *chìwū* (赤乌) and simmer until it forms a white *dǎnzi* (胆子, "stone gall") for refining. Leave it to solidify for seven days, then fully solidify it with fire—no need to extract the raw material.

Another method for fully solidifying sand: Take one *jīn* (斤) of raw mercury (*tǔgōngtóng* 土汞) and half a *jīn* of *dǎnzi* (胆子). After solidifying, use the resulting mercury to mix with a small amount of *liáo* (寥) ash, kneading it into a paste for refining. Fix it in a pan (*chēng* 铛) and roast for ten days until fully solidified.

Another method:
*Liáo* (寥) ash – one *jīn* (斤)
*Xiāoshí* (消石) – four *liǎng* (两)
*Báifàn* (白矾) – four *liǎng* (两)
Combine these ingredients in a bottle and ignite them until they melt (*róng* 镕).

After cooling, take five *liǎng* (两) of *fánshí* (矾石, "alum stone") and one *liǎng* (两) of *mìtuó sēng* (蜜陀僧, "mellite or honeyed alum"). Mix these and ignite with strong fire (*wǔhuǒ* 武火) for one *fú* period.

Then take the previous mixture, add five *liǎng* (两) of *císhí* (磁石, "lodestone"), and knead it into a paste for refining. Roast with alternating strong and gentle fire (*wénwǔhuǒ* 文武火) for seven days—this is the finest method.

chunks.original_text: 又如不用鼓盐者，此盐作柜，宜先於火上烘令至极乾。 每斤可加伏火消石五两，於铁臼中熟梼如面，唯宜梼烂熟，便可为柜，亦不必用鼓了者。 又其盥炒至赤，佳。 又法 右出晕了者，更空，以白矾浆水煮一食久，然后燠成银之时，自然红软於铛底。 先布盐可厚一寸余，即细梼白矾末，便於盥中心少布些些，即以薄绢却裹砂子，稍捻令相着所裹绢，才裹足即休，勿令有剩绢。 即燠虽出，便坐砂子裹，於白矾上，又着少许白矾盖绢头。 便一时拨取盐，拥却绢役头，便以霜盆盖，却便固济细密，以铁关楔令牢。 恐汞力亮起，似有漏气，汞即走出。 以武火，烧火唯猛，佳。 从平明至晚间。 即去火，待玲开之，盆子中当有霜有汞相和，即拨开盐，收取紫粉，以物击之，作金声，便堪入炉任用。 出红银晕法 夫出红银晕，其中甚难。 何者，所用皆非至药。 比有修铅汞之士，其问稍差，点制犹不入，岂可能将诸石及草为药，生熟又殊，而欲望变凡为真，不亦难乎。 今於此得者，须各辨反恶，知其情性，用药有多少，合和有前后，若合其理，与真无别，稍失其道则乖。 学者详而用之。 淘研煮洗砂子晕法 右应诸色砂子等，并不宜玲水，须用暖汤，切不宜着杂药研淘煮洗，为被外药把捉，砂子晕却深牢，转难得出其砂子。 但且先空，以暖水研淘，唯变数多即诤。 续加以盐，及和饭研之，然以大麦、仁浆水、乌梅、盥，大瓷盛糠火养十日，令极醋。 临用时，加章陆根，用煮砂子，至相宜。 经此后，任将入诸色修理。 出红银砂子晕方 右取煮洗了砂子，作小挺子，以风化石灰纳铁莆中散安，将挺子插於灰中，固济，不固亦得。 文武火养一月日已上，鼓之，每斤得十两，成无晕。 抽生出晕法 右取砂子，以寒水石二两，矾石一两，章陆根一两，与一斤砂子，相和熟研，三五炊久，唯研多转佳。 即淘洗，又依前着上件三味药同研，又淘洗，如此三度，止。 晕当出尽。 即重演却生汞，便入寒水石柜，於铛中，以醋和。 寒水石下厚半寸，上厚一寸，其中砂子以寒水石末格之，不然薄作片亦得。 柜上着盥，盐着灰，飞之文武火，一伏时。 然后入埚销，投入寒水石池内。 池法 右以盐水，调寒水石，如缅糊，投三两遍，白如雪。 烧寒水石法 右取一火，急去火，以盆合固济缝，待玲用之。 点红银晕法 粉霜一两毒者　句容胆子半两已上相和细研。 右先取石灰，一如淋灰法热暖，白马尿淋之，约得二升已来汁，向瓷瓶子中盛。 纳二味於中，以重汤武火煮两伏时止。 待玲，去余汁药带泥，便和半两伏火消石，同拌和为团，又入药柜中，文武火伏之两日。 当伏火，每一两点一斤如雪。 药柜法 特生矾石二两　青半两厅者　蜜陀僧一两　句容胆子半两 右相和醋拌，纳一小瓷瓶中，烧七日。 每日一度入醋，又烧，即堪为柜。 又此柜重用多时转，佳。 伏消石法 右取消石一两为末，纳瓷盏子中，按令平紧，上布两钱盥末，按令平。 以瓷盏盖，不用固济。 文武火候，消盥汁尽，即伏。 点红银晕法 右取铅八两，水银二两，并相和，纳瓷器中，不用固济，火养令如水，勿令火过，但才作水，即得。 十日后研作砂子，以砒黄及消石、白矾、盥等，出晕，研淘二十余遍，即还以出晕药煮一日，又添半两汞，入铅中，又火养十日。

「If salt is not to be used with *gǔyán* (鼓盐), then this salt, when made into a paste, should first be thoroughly dried over a fire. For each *jīn* (斤) of salt, add five *liǎng* (两) of *fúhuǒ xiāoshí* (伏火消石, "roasted alumstone"). In an iron mortar, grind it finely like flour—ensure it is ground to a smooth paste before forming the mixture; there is no need to use *gǔyán* (鼓盐) in this case. Additionally, if the *liáo* (寥) ash is roasted until it turns red, it is superior.

Another method:
Take the *yún* (晕, "haloed") residue, empty it, and boil it in a solution of *báifàn* (白矾, "alum") for the duration of a meal. Then, when refining into silver, it will naturally soften and turn red at the bottom of the pan (*chēng* 铛).

First, spread the salt to a thickness of over one *cùn* (寸). Then, finely grind *báifàn* (白矾) powder and sprinkle a little at the center of the *liáo* (寥). Wrap the sand in thin silk, gently twist it to adhere to the wrapped silk, and stop once fully wrapped—ensure no excess silk remains. Even if the refining is complete, place the wrapped sand on the *báifàn* (白矾), covering the silk with a little more *báifàn* (白矾). Quickly remove the salt, unfold the wrapped silk, cover it with a frost basin, and seal it tightly with an iron clamp to ensure no leaks. If the *gǒng* (汞, "mercury") force rises and there is any sign of leakage, the mercury will escape. Use strong fire (*wǔhuǒ* 武火) and burn fiercely—this is optimal. From dawn until dusk, remove the fire and wait for it to cool. The basin should contain frost and mercury mixed together. Then, remove the salt and collect the purple powder (*zǐfěn* 紫粉). Strike it with an object to produce a metallic sound—it is then ready for use in the furnace.

**Method for Extracting Red Silver Halo (*hóngyín yún* 红银晕):**
Obtaining red silver halo is extremely difficult. Why? The materials used are not of the highest quality. Even those skilled in refining lead and mercury (*qiān gǒng* 铅汞) may have slight discrepancies in their techniques, let alone attempting to use ordinary stones and herbs as medicines—where raw and processed materials differ so greatly—yet hoping to transform the mundane into the true. How could this not be difficult?

Now, when using these methods, one must carefully distinguish impurities, understand their nature, and measure the ingredients precisely—whether in sequence or proportion. If the process aligns with principle, it will not differ from the genuine. The slightest deviation will lead to failure. Students must study this thoroughly and apply it carefully.

**Method for Washing and Refining Sand Halo (*shāzi yún* 砂子晕):**
All colored sands must not be washed with cold water; warm water should be used instead. Avoid mixing with other medicines during grinding, washing, or boiling, as external medicines may bind the sand halo, making extraction even more difficult. First, empty the sand and wash it with warm water—repeat this process several times. Then, add salt and rice gruel, grinding it thoroughly. Use barley grain broth, *wūméi* (乌梅, "black plum"), and *liáo* (寥) ash, storing it in a large porcelain container over a chaff fire for ten days until thoroughly decomposed. Before use, add *zhānglù gēn* (章陆根, "stem of *Achyranthes bidentata*") and boil the sand until it reaches the desired consistency. After this, it can be used in any refining process.

**Method for Extracting Red Silver Sand Halo (*hóngyín shāzi yún* 红银砂子晕):**
Take washed sand, shape it into small rods, and place wind-dissolved lime (*fēnghuà shuǐhuā* 风化石灰) in an iron crucible. Insert the rods into the lime and seal the crucible—it may also be left unsealed. Refine with alternating strong and gentle fire (*wénwǔhuǒ* 文武火) for one month or more. After pounding, each *jīn* (斤) yields ten *liǎng* (两) of pure, halo-free product.

**Method for Reviving Halo from Raw Mercury (*chōushēng chūyún* 抽生出晕):**
Take sand and mix it with two *liǎng* (两) of *hánshuǐshí* (寒水石, "cold water stone"), one *liǎng* (两) of *fánshí* (矾石, "alum stone"), and one *liǎng* (两) of *zhānglù gēn* (章陆根, "stem of *Achyranthes bidentata*") per *jīn* (斤) of sand. Grind them thoroughly together for three to five meals' duration—the more grinding, the better. Wash and repeat the process with the same three ingredients twice more. The halo should now be fully extracted. Then, regenerate the raw mercury (*shēng gǒng* 生汞) and mix it with *hánshuǐshí* (寒水石) paste in the pan (*chēng* 铛), using vinegar as a binder. Place a half-*cùn* (寸) layer of *hánshuǐshí* at the bottom and a one-*cùn* (寸) layer on top, with the sand sandwiched between layers of *hánshuǐshí* powder—or shape it into thin sheets if preferred. Cover with *liáo* (寥) ash and salt, then refine with alternating strong and gentle fire (*wénwǔhuǒ* 文武火) for one *fú* period. Afterward, place it in a crucible and melt it into the *hánshuǐshí* pool.

**Method for Preparing the *Hánshuǐshí* Pool (*shí fǎ* 池法):**
Mix *hánshuǐshí* (寒水石) with saltwater into a paste like *miǎn* (缅, "Myanmar") glue, applying it in three layers until it turns as white as snow.

**Method for Roasting *Hánshuǐshí* (烧寒水石法):**
Take *hánshuǐshí* (寒水石), quickly remove it from the fire, seal the basin tightly, and wait for it to cool before use.

**Method for Pointing Red Silver Halo (*diǎn hóngyín yún* 点红银晕):**
One *liǎng* (两) of toxic frost (*dú fēng* 毒霜) and half a *liǎng* (两) of *jùróng dǎnzi* (句容胆子, "cholecyst from Jurong")
Mix these finely.

First, prepare lime by heating it as in the *lín huī* (淋灰, "lime leaching") method and leach it with white horse urine, obtaining about two *shāng* (升) of liquid. Place this in a porcelain bottle. Add the two ingredients, boil with strong fire (*wǔhuǒ* 武火) for two *fú* periods, then cool. Remove the residual liquid and impurities, mix with half a *liǎng* (两) of *fúhuǒ xiāoshí* (伏火消石, "roasted alumstone"), and knead into a paste. Place it in a medicine container and refine with alternating strong and gentle fire (*wénwǔhuǒ* 文武火) for two days. During refining, each *liǎng* (两) of medicine can treat one *jīn* (斤) of material like snow.

**Medicine Container Method (*yàogū fǎ* 药柜法):**
Two *liǎng* (两) of raw *fánshí* (矾石, "alum stone"),
Half a *liǎng* (两) of *qīng* (青, "indigo" or "blue vitriol"),
One *liǎng* (两) of *mìtuó sēng* (蜜陀僧, "mellite or honeyed alum"),
Half a *liǎng* (两) of *jùróng dǎnzi* (句容胆子, "cholecyst from Jurong")
Mix these with vinegar and place them in a small porcelain bottle. Roast for seven days, adding vinegar daily before roasting. This mixture is then ready for use as a container. Repeated use over time improves its efficacy.

**Method for Roasting *Xiāoshí* (伏消石法):**
Take one *liǎng* (两) of *xiāoshí* (消石, "alumstone") and grind it into powder. Place it in a porcelain cup, pressing it flat. Sprinkle two *qián* (钱) of *liáo* (寥) ash on top and press it down evenly. Cover with a porcelain lid without sealing. Refine with alternating strong and gentle fire (*wénwǔhuǒ* 文武火) until the *liáo* (寥) and *xiāoshí* (消石) juices are fully consumed—this completes the roasting.

**Alternative Method for Pointing Red Silver Halo (*diǎn hóngyín yún* 点红银晕):**
Take eight *liǎng* (两) of lead (*qiān* 铅) and two *liǎng* (两) of mercury (*shuǐyín* 水银), mix them thoroughly, and place them in a porcelain vessel without sealing. Refine with fire until they liquefy like water—do not overheat, only until they reach a liquid state. After ten days, grind into sand. Add *píhuáng* (砒黄, "orpiment") along with *xiāoshí* (消石), *báifàn* (白矾), and *liáo* (寥) to extract the halo, washing and grinding it twenty or more times. Then, boil it with halo-extraction medicine for a day, add half a *liǎng* (两) of mercury (*gǒng* 汞) to the lead, and refine with fire for another ten days.

Combine these two substances, grinding until extremely fine—ideally, grind for an entire day, with meticulous effort yielding the best results. Add half a *liǎng* (两) of the previously subdued *báifàn* and other ingredients, then mix with the mercury medicine, grinding until fully refined.

「The method of forming a crucible and removing the *yùn* (晕, "haze/impurity")—when the crucible rises and emits a faint haze:

- **Lime (石灰):** 1 part
- **Yellow soil (黄土):** 2 parts
- **Salt (盐):** 1 part

Combine these three ingredients to form the **crucible base (挺子)**. Use a stirring crucible (搅埚) and consider the base effective when it no longer emits haze upon heating. Once all haze has dissipated, the residue will be even more potent and can be used repeatedly without limit.

Lime is particularly effective in removing haze, but it is brittle and difficult to work with. If using a stirring crucible (搅埚), it is best to stir before adding the **primary substance (母)**. If the primary substance has already been added, stirring may risk damaging the silver.

Another method: Mix **talc powder (滑石末)** with vinegar (醋) and apply it to the crucible and the base (砣挺). Upon heating, the residue will burn away silently, effectively sealing the haze. A single application suffices—afterward, the haze will not reappear upon heating. It is advisable to conduct this process in a secluded room where no drafts (风) reach.

**Method for removing haze from sand and other substances:**

Take fine sand (砂子) and knead it thoroughly. Mix with **lodestone (磁石)**, **alum (消石)**, **white alum (白矾)**, **pumice (朴消)**, **salt (盐)**, **cold water stone (寒水石)**, and **mother-of-pearl (母蛎)**. Add a small amount of **sticky rice (糯米)** to form a paste, then grind and shape into a **pill (饼)**.

Wrap the sand in a layer of cloth (布), knead it until thin, then dig a hole two *chǐ* (尺) deep and bury it for **one hundred days (一百日)**—this will remove the haze. If the haze does not fully dissipate after one hundred days, burying it for a year or more is even better, until the haze is completely gone. Burying without the medicine is also acceptable.

Another method for **crucible bases (埚挺)**: Simply pound them thin and bury them—they will also lose their haze.

This is the method revered by **Mountain Master Li Jingyang (山人李景阳)**.

Another method:
Refine **dragon liver (伏龙肝)**, lime (石灰), **mineral charcoal ash (矿炭灰)**, and **mulberry ash (桑灰)**. Boil until the mixture is white and free of haze.

Another method:
Use the **residue of sweet persimmon (余甘子)** for boiling—it can effectively remove haze.

Another method:
Wash the mixture with **limewater (石灰淋)** to eliminate the bitter taste of the ash.

Another method:
Soak the mixture in water (浸), then boil (蒸) and wash (淋) repeatedly—no matter how many times, the purest result is best. Boil and wash in cycles of three to five times, then repeatedly grind and wash the sand with this ash, until it is completely free of haze.

Another method:
If the haze persists, boil the mixture again. Use **two *liǎng* (两) of refined cold water stone (寒水石)** to boil, as the resulting liquid will be deeply black—this indicates the haze has been removed. Test repeatedly until the mixture turns white. This method is derived from boiling **stone gall (石胆)** and **orpiment (砒黄)** together, though it is unclear whether other medicines can be similarly refined.

Another method:
Mix **two *liǎng* (两) of realgar (础黄)**, **two *liǎng* (两) of cold water stone (寒水石)**, and **one *liǎng* (两) of alum (盥)**, then boil. Do not use iron utensils—this yields the best results.

Another method:
Grind **alum (盥)** for three days, washing it daily until it produces a milky residue. The haze will then be completely removed.

Another method:
Boil **aconite (附子)** in its raw form with the residue of **red silver (红银)** and **refined mercury (汞了)**. After three boilings, the haze will be eliminated.

Another method:
Use **horse teeth juice (马齿汁)** to extract a concentrated decoction (煎取浓), then mix with **alum (消石)**, **pumice (朴消)**, and **sweet persimmon juice (甘子汁)**. Stir while heating the **red silver (红银)**. After three applications, the haze will be removed.

Another method:
Grind **hogweed root (章陆根)** with ginger (姜), then boil or wash to remove haze.

Another method:
Boil sand in **limewater (石灰清)** extracted from **silkworm cocoon ash (蚕砂汁)**—this will eliminate haze.

Another method:
Boil sand in **sesame oil (荏子油)** ten times to remove haze. Some say this method can specifically eliminate **iron haze (铁晕)**.

Another method:
Mix **refined red silver (红银)** with **refined mercury (汞了)** and boil with **raw aconite (生附子)**—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Collect **urine from wine shop patrons (酒家酒客小便)** in a pool, then use it for boiling substances—this will remove haze. Some say the urine of **elderly men (老人尿)** is even more effective due to its prolonged storage.

Another method:
Boil sand in a **sand basin (砂盆)** with **orpiment (砒黄)** and add **alum (盥)**. Do this for seven days or two cycles of seven days—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Mix **refined red silver (红银)** with **refined mercury (汞了)** and boil with **fennel (茴草)**—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Boil sand with **white plum (白梅)** to remove haze. Some say white plum is slightly more effective than **black plum (乌梅)**, and both should be used without their pits.

Another method:
Grind **yellow sprouts (黄芽)** and boil for seven days in a **sand basin (砂盆)**—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Boil with **bat guano (伏翼粪)**—this will remove haze.

chunks.original_text: 蝙蝠也。 又法 梼莲子草汁为饼，阴乾，以备非时用，煮洗，去晕。 又法 每研洗砂子，须着少蚌粉和研，良。 又法 口含水停少时，手中洗，去晕。 又法 红银及砂子、松脂煮，无晕。 又法 白章柳根、胶清、朴消、石灰研煮，无晕。 又法 黄土、石胆包烧煮，无晕，甚妙。 又法 烂蒸草屈水，出晕。 亦能去丹阳晕。 又法 多和汞飞在下者，黄土和盥，研为泥包烧，去晕。 又法 钴羊角及松明木，搅埚，重淋来灰，去晕。 又法 砂子入糠灰汁中煮，数数换池，七日晕尽。 须每一日六七度，换汁淘诤。 又法 理石、玄精等分为末，销砂子作水投入，去晕。 丹阳亦得。 又法 红银销薄，或未鼓，入梦灰汁中，去晕。 一云：梦子灰煮，得霜伏。 又曾将砂子如银膏状者，和梦灰，研作末，便和灰，煮半日已下，便成。 乾碎即当时有故便止不终篇，此灰甚觉结砂子有力。 又大抵灰和研甚，与晕最相当。 孔氏以烧灰中具述。 燠出砂子红银晕法 右取砂子紧族了者，二斤。 先以暖盐浆水於钵内，以柳木槌研淘，旋没洗却药，淘洗二十遍，令白挣。 即散破纳一瓷器中，以糯米浆中煮，纳乌梅一升去核。 如用酒家醇浆，亦得。 煮两日，不得更别着药。 每日四度淘研，并用暖浆中淘研，前后并不得入玲水。 淘研下时，每遍着少胡同律，一钱止分为四度用为准。 其胡同律者，性情铜铁俱宜，甚能去晕。 又以远年土壁土－为汤，亦佳。 其问用石灰少者，水於钵内，以柳木槌研淘，旋没洗却药，汹洗二十遍。 碗中着浆水，强半碗浸之。 每一斤砂子，用硵砂一分，於浆水中放，婉微暖处，一伏时，其砂子药自见。 以篦搅，以水淘研，手中授洗令诤。 然后取大铁臼，以砂子和盐二升，壮夫梼□□当如青泥。 每日三度淘洗，和盥铸，致□□以小便淋来灰煮一日。 又和盥梼一日，每日亦三度。 换盥，又用小便灰汁煮一日，并合堪用也。 如未更梼煮，计三日煮，并当无晕。 一说其汞经此梼后，汞亦易制伏。 又如尚有晕，即更入醋浆中煮，合纳白矾二两，盐二两，乌梅二升，寒水石二两，洗了。 用砒霜半两，础也得。 硵砂一钱，朴消二两，章柳根细梼一茶碗，煮两日，每日出砂子三两度。 依前用胡同律研淘，壁土为汤，其物当晕尽也。 又如未了，即将砂子，投入伏龙肝、白善各二两，石灰矿一分，来灰炭灰中口两日，亦依前淘研，当白无晕。 又如未了，□每斤入一两黄丹，於瓷器内，微火炒令相入熟研，即入砂糖一斤，少着水，煮一日，不用淘洗。 沙糖能去黑晕。 又入浓米醋，如无糠醋，亦得内加皂荚，煮两日，能去黑晕。 便即数淘洗令诤。 日满后，

「Bat guano as well.  Another method:
Grind **dried lotus root (梼莲子)** and **fennel (茴草)** juice into cakes, dry in shade, and store for later use. Boil and wash with it—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Every time you grind and wash sand, you must mix it with a small amount of **powdered clam shell (蚌粉)** and grind thoroughly—this is effective.

Another method:
Hold water in your mouth for a brief moment, then wash with your hands—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Boil **refined red silver (红银)** with sand and **pine resin (松脂)**—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Grind **white willow root (白章柳根)**, **glue essence (胶清)**, **magnolia bark (朴消)**, and **lime (石灰)**, then boil—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Wrap **yellow soil (黄土)** and **stone gall (石胆)** in cloth and boil—this will remove haze, and it is very effective.

Another method:
Steep **rotten hemp (烂蒸草)** in water, then strain—this will remove haze. It can also remove **Dan Yang haze (丹阳晕)**.

Another method:
For cases where **mercury (汞)** is mixed with much **flying mercury (飞汞)** at the bottom, mix **yellow soil (黄土)** and **alum (盥)**, grind into paste, wrap, and burn—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Grind **cobaltite (钴羊角)** and **pinewood (松明木)**, stir in a crucible, and repeatedly rinse with water to collect the ash—this will remove haze.

Another method:
Boil sand in **rice husk ash (糠灰)** juice, frequently changing the liquid. After seven days, the haze will be gone. You must rinse and grind it six or seven times daily, always using warm juice for washing. After washing, let it settle.

Another method:
Pound **calcite (理石)** and **realgar (玄精)** equally into powder, then dissolve sand to make a solution and add it—this will remove haze. It is also effective for **Dan Yang haze (丹阳晕)**.

Another method:
Dissolve **refined red silver (红银)** thinly, or before it becomes granular, into **ash of *meng* plant (梦灰)** juice—this will remove haze. Some say: boil **ash of *meng* plant (梦灰)** to obtain **congealed ash (霜伏)**.

Another method:
Once sand has been ground into a paste like **silver ointment (银膏)**—mix it with **ash of *meng* plant (梦灰)**, grind into powder, then boil with **ash of *meng* plant (梦灰)** for half a day or more—it will be ready. Dry and crush it immediately; if there is a delay, stop the process. This ash is very effective at binding sand.

Another method:
Generally, mixing and grinding ash thoroughly is most effective against haze.

**Master Kong’s (孔氏)** method for removing haze from sand and **refined red silver (红银)**:
Take sand that has been thoroughly refined, two *jin* (斤). First, use warm **salt brine (盐浆)** water in a bowl, and grind and wash the sand with a **willowwood pestle (柳木槌)**, repeatedly submerging and rinsing the medicine. Wash it twenty times until it becomes white and pure.

Then, break it up and place it in a **porcelain vessel (瓷器)**, and boil it in **glutinous rice (糯米)** brine. Add **two *sheng* (升) of *wu mei* (乌梅)** without pits. If you use **strong wine brine (酒家醇浆)** from an inn, it is also acceptable.

Boil for two days, without adding any other medicines. Every day, wash and grind it four times, always using warm brine for the process. Do not use **cold water (玲水)** at any stage, before or after.

When washing and grinding, add a small amount of **Barbary wolfberry (胡同律)**—one *qian* (钱) divided into four doses as a guideline. This **Barbary wolfberry (胡同律)** is suitable for both copper and iron, and very effective at removing haze.

If using **aged earthen wall soil (远年土壁土)** as a broth, it is also excellent.

For cases where **lime (石灰)** is used sparingly, place water in a bowl, and grind and wash the sand with a **willowwood pestle (柳木槌)**, repeatedly submerging and rinsing the medicine. Wash it twenty times.

Put **brine (浆水)**—about half a bowl—into a **porcelain vessel (瓷器)** and immerse the sand. For every *jin* (斤) of sand, use **one *fen* (分) of *li* sand (硵砂)** in the brine. Place it in a warm spot, and after one *fu* (伏) time, the medicine will naturally appear.

Stir it with a **rake (篦)**, then wash and grind it with water, kneading by hand until it settles.

Then, take a **large iron mortar (大铁臼)**, mix sand and **salt (盐)**—two *sheng* (升)—and grind with a strong man until it resembles **green mud (青泥)**. Every day, wash and grind it three times, mix with **alum (盥)**, and cast into a mold. Rinse with **urine ash (小便来灰)** juice and boil for one day.

Again, mix with **alum (盥)** and grind for one day, also three times daily. Change the **alum (盥)**, and boil again with **urine ash (小便灰)** juice for one day—this will be fully effective.

If you do not boil it again with **alum (盥)**, calculate three days of boiling, and it will be fully free of haze. Some say that after this process, **mercury (汞)** will also be easier to control.

If haze remains, boil the sand in **vinegar brine (醋浆)**. Add **two *liang* (两) of white alum (白矾)**, **two *liang* (两) of salt (盐)**, **two *sheng* (升) of *wu mei* (乌梅)**, and **two *liang* (两) of alum (寒水石)**—rinse thoroughly. You may also use **half *liang* (两) of orpiment (砒霜)**.

For **one *qian* (钱) of *li* sand (硵砂)**, use **two *liang* (两) of magnolia bark (朴消)** and **one tea bowl of finely ground white willow root (白章柳根)**. Boil for two days, rinsing the sand three times daily. Follow the previous method of grinding with **Barbary wolfberry (胡同律)** and using **aged earthen wall soil (壁土)** as a broth—this will remove all haze.

If haze persists, take sand and boil it with **two *liang* (两) each of *fu long* liver (伏龙肝)** and **white lead (白善)**, **one *fen* (分) of lime (石灰矿)**, and **two *liang* (两) of *meng* plant ash (梦灰)** and **urine ash (来灰)** for two days. Then, follow the previous method of washing and grinding—this will make the sand white and free of haze.

If haze still remains, for every *jin* (斤) of sand, add **one *liang* (两) of yellow cinnabar (黄丹)**. In a **porcelain vessel (瓷器)**, roast it over low heat until the sand is fully incorporated, then grind it. Add **one *jin* (斤) of sugar sand (砂糖)**, a small amount of water, and boil for one day—no rinsing needed. **Sugar sand (沙糖)** can remove **black haze (黑晕)**.

If you use **concentrated rice vinegar (浓米醋)**, or if you do not have **vinegar without dregs (无糠醋)**, add **soap pods (皂荚)** instead. Boil for two days—this can also remove **black haze (黑晕)**.

Then, rinse and grind it repeatedly until it settles. When the day is complete,」

A Method:

After cooking, take the sand and form it into small pellets. Place wind-dissolved lime into the iron mortar, scatter the sand over it, and insert the pellets into the lime. Secure tightly and subject to fire-nurturing for one month.

Later, pound it—it will be free of haze. For every *jin* of sand, yield fifteen *liang* or more. Dry the sand thoroughly.

The sand before and after must never be exposed to cold water. For every *jin* of sand, mix with one *liang* of *fúshuāng* (伏霜), grinding until fully incorporated. If *fúshuāng* is unavailable, raw *shuāng* (霜) may be used instead.

Divide into sixteen pill-sized balls, coating them with salt. First, refine the salt finely, then wrap each ball in clay, sealing them individually. Pierce each ball with a pin, creating three to five small holes, and dry them. Place them in a crucible—an iron pan (*tǎng* 铛) may also be used. Cover with fine yellow earth or lime. Alternatively, spread charcoal ash on top, seal tightly, and nurture with gentle fire for one day. Gradually increase to strong fire until the crucible’s base glows red. Once cooled, open it and collect the vaporized mercury.

If mercury remains on the ash, collect it entirely. Leave the pan undisturbed, placing it horizontally over charcoal fire, and burn through with strong flame until fully red. Once cooled, break the balls, recover the sand, and mix with *wūméi* (乌梅), *bái fán* (白矾), and salt. Boil for half a day until dry. Add *níqiú yán* (泥球盐) and fire once more, then introduce the medicine and boil again for half a day. If further mercury is added and ground to blend, place it back in the crucible and vaporize three to five times. The mercury will ascend, drawing out the haze.

Then, place it in a small crucible, covering with cow dung ash and a touch of salt. Nurture with slow fire. [Unclear text]—whether the juice’s potency is deep or shallow—pound as if already known.

When initially pounding, add the mother substance (*mǔ* 母) simultaneously—this is excellent, surpassing adding it in the second round.

Sand that has undergone repeated leaching and grinding is light and porous, easily dispersed by wind. Great care must be taken to prevent loss. The method of strong-fire burning in the pan is superior—it ensures the substance is fully refined and retains its medicinal power. Placing it in the crucible also prevents dispersion and avoids fragmentation.

For the pill balls, some say to use Persian white alum (*bó sī bái fán* 波斯白矾) and *hú tóng lǜ* (胡同律), which is also excellent.

Once the substance is refined into a liquid and dried, it is better to immerse it in a *huá chí* (华池, "flower pool"). The pool method uses water and wine, dissolving *pú xiāo* (朴消) and *bái fán* (白矾), with no grease present.

Another method: mix salt and water to form a pool, making it slightly concentrated and soft. Alternatively, use *zào jiá* (皂荚) for the pool, which should be thick and potent. The resulting substance will be soft, white, and free of haze.

chunks.original_text: 如未可，即更入埚销。 每斤用霜药二两已下，依丹阳方法抽点，泻为砣。 即将砣入泥球包一日，又投三十遍，又入泥球包。 即重入埚销，每十两入二两母，其母切须真好，是本山泽者，切须自试，无分毫杂者，此是要节。 於埚中熟搅和，又泻池中，令成埚稍薄。 作此物中，先有黄丹，每入埚中之时，大须在意，令铅出尽。 如不出，自是一病。 即又投三十遍，又泥球包一日，即入埚销。 又每十两，更入□□两，熟搅泻入池内，令成埚。 并成□□□光白。 又如尚未十成，即须更入六两母，都成二十两，是对添也。 入埚熟搅，以壁土、白矾、硵砂、盥投埚，去面上恶，令清净，然泻为埚挺，稍令薄。 纳火中烧通赤，钤出令玲。 又烧三四遍。 即以盛揩洗令净。 即入瓶煮一炊久，出之。 又烧又煮，每一度煮，即一遍入埚销。 如此七遍，销无晕。 又如尚未尽得断了，即须入后件逐法中，并各得成真宝。 逐红银法 金陵子曰：因读丹经，忽悟斯理。 其红银□□依丹阳例逐的无晕。 如不可，即取红银□□色修理一切了者，错为末，入汞同研，少着汞，多即被把晕难出。 又煮洗修理并了然，即更加水银，并投入铅中，熟搅和入炉中，平布固济，飞之。 其炉以黄土纸筋为泥，衬炉裹。 更以乾黄土末，下藉五第，上覆一寸。 第一日文火养，勿令汞上。 第二日稍加火，第三日武火迫上水银。 寒开之上釜，收取上釜，收取汞。 其炉中取铅，入埋池定白也。 其炉中并不得别着矾等，恐汞成霜也，亦损铅力。 如犹不断手脚，更再坏，无不成也。 又一说红银砂子不限多少，但紧演投入铅中，如此生了者，亦得。 加□一两同研，入逐也无晕。 又一说，逐法□□细罗水拌，令浥浥为窠，安少盥於逐中，□□铅等用火，依常法。 红银遂子法 右取红银，以药抽点包拔一切诤了者，八两，加二两好山泽，每埚都成十两为准，其母更多亦无妨，熟搅为砣，令厚薄匀。 即取一稍深铛子，用水银三斤，以埚平安水银，上固济，火当底着，用文火如盛夏日即得。 后渐加火。 每两日开，如有水银飞上，即略下火力，但汞才及微微上，即得不用。 □□如此二十日满，即重铸一遍为砣。 □□□作二十日满，又铸一遍。 睹烧养六□□□其晕并尽，便为真宝。 一本六两折二。 □□□砣子。 第一遍着时，须甩硵砂及少胆子，以汞煮一日，其砣并着底，与汞相入为妙。 一说其砣子四两，以北庭硵砂一两，石胆一两，骇鳞蜴一分，三物和研，以米醋调如膏涂上，以黄土为泥包裹之，可厚一寸二分。 便於糠火中，烧三七日，然以白炭烧三日。 去泥取之本方，入汞四两。 出《丹砂经》。 一本云：其器物中，先以黄丹和胡粉为，泥铛底然，内水银及砣子，即一出手□□十日便无晕，多少亦随人意，所无□□□十两为准。 又一云：遂子着消石□□□□日正一日倒，都七日了，当作黑灰□□□研淘，然抽生鼓便白。 遂子法 夫遂子之道，且须本物少晕则易口功，如思稍难也，此是诀语。 右取抽点州切了者红银一斤，和母四两，都成二十两，作一埚子稍薄作，如厚即打之。 打了更须烧与火同色，更煮洗令净，用汞三斤，并纳於铛中，以少石胆，及硵砂口水煮一日，其汞与砣当相入，砣着铛底□尽，便固济，出阴气。
chunks.translated_text:
If the method is not yet complete, then return it to the crucible for refining.
For every *cāng* (斤) of substance, use no more than two *liǎng* (两) of the refined powder, following the *Dān Yáng* method to extract the essence and form *dàn* (砣).

Then wrap the *dàn* in a clay ball for one day, then subject it to thirty *diǎn* (点) treatments, and wrap it again in a clay ball.
Next, return it to the crucible for refining, adding two *liǎng* of the mother substance for every ten *liǎng* of the refined material. The mother substance must be of the finest quality—preferably from the original mountain or marsh—and must be tested personally, free of any impurities. This is a critical step.

Stir thoroughly within the crucible, then pour it into the pool to form a thin *dàn*.
Before refining, ensure that *huáng dān* (黄丹) is present in the mixture. When placing it in the crucible, be especially mindful that all lead is fully expelled. If not, this is a flaw.

Then subject it to thirty more *diǎn* treatments, wrap it in a clay ball for another day, and return it to the crucible for refining.
For every ten *liǎng* of the substance, add another two *liǎng* of the mother substance, stir thoroughly, and pour it back into the pool to form a *dàn*. The result should be smooth, white, and free of haze.

If it is still not fully refined, add another six *liǎng* of the mother substance, making a total of twenty *liǎng* (this is the "paired addition"). Refine it again in the crucible, stirring well, then add *bìtǔ* (壁土), *bái fán* (白矾), and *kuángshā* (硇砂) to purify the surface, ensuring clarity. Pour it into the pool to form a thin *dàn*.

Heat it in the fire until it glows a deep red, then remove it and let it cool to a bright luster.
Repeat the heating process three or four times, then wash it thoroughly with a cloth to ensure purity.
Place it in a bottle and boil for a full cycle, then remove it. Repeat the heating and boiling process—each cycle of boiling counts as one refining in the crucible.

Do this seven times until no haze remains.
If the substance is still not fully refined, proceed to the subsequent methods to achieve the true treasure.

---
**On the Method of *Hóng Yín* (红银):**
The *Jīn Líng Zǐ* (金陵子) says: Upon reading the *Dān Jīng* (丹经), he suddenly understood this principle.
The *hóng yín* (red silver) should be refined according to the *Dān Yáng* method until no haze remains.
If this is not possible, take the *hóng yín* that has already been refined to a red-silver hue and grind it into a powder, then mix it with *gǒng* (汞). Use a small amount of *gǒng*—too much will cause haze and make it difficult to refine.

After thoroughly washing and refining, add more *gǒng* and mix it with lead, stirring well before placing it in the furnace. Secure it with flat cloth and let it sublimate.
The furnace should be lined with yellow soil and paper fibers, then covered with dry yellow soil, five *cùn* (寸) thick, with an additional one *cùn* layer on top.

On the first day, use gentle fire to nurture it without allowing the *gǒng* to rise.
On the second day, gradually increase the heat, and on the third day, apply strong fire to drive the *gǒng* upward.
Open the furnace when it cools, collect the *gǒng* from the upper vessel, and retrieve the lead from the furnace, then immerse it in the pool to achieve whiteness.
Do not add any *fán* (矾) or other substances to the furnace, as this may cause the *gǒng* to crystallize into frost and weaken the lead’s potency.
If the lead still shows impurities, break it down again—it will eventually succeed.

Another method states that the amount of *hóng yín* sand is not limited; simply refine it thoroughly and mix it with lead. Even if it is not fully refined, it will still yield results.
Add one *liǎng* of [missing term] and grind it together before refining—this will prevent haze.

Another method involves sifting the refined substance through fine silk and mixing it with water until it forms a moist, granular mass. Place a small amount of *xiǎn* (盥) in the mixture, then refine the lead and other substances using the standard method.

---
**Method for *Suì Zǐ* (遂子) from *Hóng Yín*:**
Take one *jīn* (斤) of thoroughly refined *hóng yín* (red silver), mix it with four *liǎng* of the mother substance, making a total of twenty *liǎng*. Form a thin *dàn* in a crucible—if it is too thick, pound it until even.

After pounding, heat it until it matches the fire’s hue, then boil and wash it clean. Use three *jīn* of *gǒng* (汞), place the *dàn* flat in the *gāng* (铛), and secure it tightly. Apply gentle fire, like that of a midsummer day, then gradually increase the heat.

Open the furnace every two days. If *gǒng* rises, slightly reduce the fire—only enough to prevent it from rising further.
After twenty days, recast it into a *dàn*. Repeat this process for another twenty days, then recast again.
After refining and nurturing for six [missing term], all haze will disappear, and it will become the true treasure.
(Note: One version states "six *liǎng* folded into two.")

When first refining, add a small amount of *kuángshā* (硇砂) and *dǎnzǐ* (胆子), then boil the *gǒng* for a day. The *dàn* should adhere to the bottom of the *gāng*, fully integrating with the *gǒng*—this is ideal.

Another method states: Take four *liǎng* of the *dàn*, mix one *liǎng* of *Běi Tíng kuángshā* (北庭硇砂), one *liǎng* of *shí dǎn* (石胆), and one *fēn* (分) of *jié lín yì* (骇鳞蜴). Grind these three substances together, then mix with rice vinegar into a paste and coat the *dàn*. Wrap it in yellow soil, one *cùn* and two *fēn* thick, and bake it in husk-fire for three days. Then burn it with white charcoal for three more days.
Remove the soil and place it in the original vessel with four *liǎng* of *gǒng*. (From the *Dān Shā Jīng* (丹砂经).)

Another version says: Before refining, line the vessel with *huáng dān* (黄丹) and *hú fěn* (胡粉) to form a paste. Place the *gǒng* and *dàn* inside, and after one refining cycle of ten days, there will be no haze—whether the quantity is large or small, it is at the user’s discretion, with ten *liǎng* as the standard.

Another version states: For *suì zǐ*, mix with *xiāoshí* (消石) and refine it for seven days, alternating between upright and inverted positions each day. After seven days, it will turn into black ash. Grind and wash it thoroughly, then refine it until it becomes white and fluffy.

---
**The Dao of *Suì Zǐ*:**
The essence of *suì zǐ* lies in its minimal haze—this makes oral ingestion easier. If the process seems difficult, this is the key insight.
Take one *jīn* of thoroughly refined *hóng yín* (red silver), mix it with four *liǎng* of the mother substance, making a total of twenty *liǎng*. Form a thin *dàn* in a crucible—if it is too thick, pound it until even.

After pounding, heat it until it matches the fire’s hue, then boil and wash it clean. Use three *jīn* of *gǒng* (汞), place the *dàn* in the *gāng* (铛), and add a small amount of *shí dǎn* (石胆) and *kuángshā* (硇砂) water. Boil for a day—the *gǒng* and *dàn* should fully integrate, with the *dàn* adhering to the bottom of the *gāng*. Then seal it tightly and let the *yīn* (阴) energy emerge.

Another method: mix salt and water to form a pool, making it slightly concentrated and soft. Alternatively, use *zào jiá* (皂荚) for the pool, which should be thick and potent. The resulting substance will be soft, white, and free of haze.

chunks.original_text: 初文，后渐武二两□□度用飞上者略下。 如此二十日满，□□抽却生汞，但入埚，还依前釭作砣□□□前安汞中，亦依前法，二十日满。 又去□□成埚子，依前入汞出鼓，如此三度，都六□日晕尽，山泽不如。 金陵子日：所经过煮□及经养红银，其汞皆被污，可以盐、白矾等淘研，及饭研亦佳。 令汞诤了，重用微佳。 又余见七篇丹砂诀中，以药烧养金埚子至是上法。 今红银亦宜依此准例作之，殊上。 其所用药涂埚子烧者，以北庭硵砂一两，石盐一两，麒鳞竭一两，此三物和研，以□酒调如膏，涂於砣子四面，令药尽□□黄土为泥包裹之，可厚一寸二分，□□□中烧二七日，然后白炭武烧三日□□□之上件方，本说如此。 今烧白物药□□□总可加喊入，遂子用良也。 又法 如烧银埚子，可以白矾灰一两，硵砂一两，消石一两伏火者，盐二两。 右涂之，亦用左味和其泥包裹，糠火七日，白炭一伏时为准。 龙虎还丹诀卷下竟

The *Suì Zǐ* Method Continued:

At first, use two *liǎng* of *wǔ* (武), then gradually increase to two *liǎng* of *wén* (文). Use only the finest, most volatile *fēi shàng* (flying mercury), slightly refined.

Thus, after twenty days, remove the excess *shēng gǒng* (raw mercury), leaving only what fits in the crucible. Again, form a *dàn* as before, placing the mercury inside, and proceed as earlier. After twenty days, repeat this process.

A third time, form the crucible anew, and once more introduce the mercury to produce the *dàn*. In this way, over six cycles, the haze will fully dissipate, surpassing even mountain and river ores.

The *Jīnlíng Zǐ* says: The mercury used in each boiling and in refining the red silver will become impure. It can be purified by washing with salt, alum, or even rice washing—this is excellent.

Once the mercury is cleansed, use it again with refined results.

Moreover, I have seen in the *Qī Piān Dānshā Jué* (Seven Chapters on Cinnabar Secrets) that medicinal substances are used to nurture the gold crucible through this very method. Now, red silver should likewise be prepared according to this principle—it is superior.

The medicinal mixture applied to the crucible before firing consists of:
- One *liǎng* of northern *kuángshā* (硇砂),
- One *liǎng* of rock salt (*shí yán*),
- One *liǎng* of *qílín jié* (麒麟竭).

Grind these three together, mix with a small amount of wine to form a paste, and coat the crucible evenly. Then, wrap it in yellow clay, one *cùn* and two *fēn* thick, and fire it in the furnace for fourteen days. Afterward, burn with white charcoal for three days, following the prescribed method.

When firing white substances, the medicinal coating can be added directly, making the *Suì Zǐ* even more potent.

Another method for firing the silver crucible:
- One *liǎng* of alum ash (*bái fán huī*),
- One *liǎng* of *kuángshā*,
- One *liǎng* of *xiāoshí* (消石, niter),
- Two *liǎng* of salt, roasted in hidden fire.

Apply this mixture, wrap it in clay as before, and fire with husk fuel for seven days, then burn with white charcoal for one hidden period—this is the standard.

*End of the Lower Scroll of the Dragon-Tiger Reunion Elixir Secrets.*
